elements.content: More than 1000× uranium exists in the oceans than exists in terrestrial ores. With nuclear power generation expected to increase over the coming decades, access to this unconventional reserve is a matter of energy security. With origins in the mid-1950s, materials have been developed for the selective recovery of seawater uranium for more than six decades, with a renewed interest in particular since 2010. This review comprehensively surveys materials developed from 2000–2016 for recovery of seawater uranium, in particular including recent developments in inorganic materials; polymer adsorbents and related research pertaining to amidoxime; and nanostructured materials such as metal–organic frameworks, porous-organic polymers, and mesoporous carbons. Challenges of performing reliable and reproducible uranium adsorption studies are also discussed, as well as the standardization of parameters necessary to ensure valid comparisons between different adsorbents.

elements.content: Limited resource availability and unchecked population growth have motivated interest in identifying and utilizing unconventional reserves for industrial metals and minerals. This is especially true when social, political, or environmental factors could affect supply security, resulting in severe global economic repercussions. The primary source of uranium is the ore uraninite, U3O8, which is largely concentrated in several regions across the earth. Australia and Kazakhstan contain approximately 33% of all economically recoverable uranium, with only 15 countries possessing a quantity adequate to facilitate nuclear power generation. Uranium reserves are predicted to be sufficient for sustained power generation at the current rates of consumption for the next 80–120 years, but global energy requirements are expected to double by 2050 as emerging economies drive annual growth and the global population surpasses 13 billion. Despite per capita energy consumption gradually declining in the United States and developed nations, globally it has increased by more than 30% over the past two decades. It is projected that nuclear power generation will double by 2040 to address this growing energy demand, making uranium availability a matter of energy security.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Limited resource availability and unchecked population growth have motivated interest in identifying and utilizing unconventional reserves for industrial metals and minerals. This is especially true when social, political, or environmental factors could affect supply security, resulting in severe global economic repercussions. The primary source of uranium is the ore uraninite, U3O8, which is largely concentrated in several regions across the earth. Australia and Kazakhstan contain approximately 33% of all economically recoverable uranium, with only 15 countries possessing a quantity adequate to facilitate nuclear power generation. Uranium reserves are predicted to be sufficient for sustained power generation at the current rates of consumption for the next 80-120 years, but global energy requirements are expected to double by 2050 as emerging economies drive annual growth and the global population surpasses 13 billion. Despite per capita energy consumption gradually declining in the United States and developed nations, globally it has increased by more than 30% over the past two decades. It is projected that nuclear power generation will double by 2040 to address this growing energy demand, making uranium availability a matter of energy security.

elements.content: Uranium exists in seawater at a concentration of 3.3 μg L–1, forming a highly stable Ca2[UO2(CO3)3] complex. Though dilute, this amounts to an estimated 4.5 billion tons of uranium, which is approximately 1000× more than is available from conventional sources such as terrestrial ores. Even considering dramatic increases in nuclear power generation and ignoring any waste reprocessing, the quantity of uranium in seawater is sufficient to ensure sustained power generation for thousands of years. Development of technology capable of economical uranium extraction from seawater would afford a financial backstop, ensure resource accessibility to nations devoid of uranium reserves, and impede any dramatic fluctuations in the uranium supply chain, thereby promoting investment in this mature, low-carbon source of base load power generation.

Development of technology capable of economical uranium extraction from seawater would afford a financial backstop, ensure resource accessibility to nations devoid of uranium reserves, and impede any dramatic fluctuations in the uranium supply chain, thereby promoting investment in this mature, low-carbon source of base load power generation.

elements.content: The purpose of this review is to summarize the current state of knowledge regarding materials developed for recovery of uranium from seawater. Although select seminal articles predating the era of interest will be touched upon, this work is primarily focused on developments occurring from 2000–2016. Numerous other reviews have been published, especially pertaining to efforts in the late 1970s through 1996. Government reports also provide an often untapped information stream, with a two volume work prepared by the U.S. Department of Energy providing a truly exhaustive survey of the field through 1979, including a list of all known materials tested for the extraction of uranium from environmental seawater and two separate bibliographies with references to all known related publications. Of particular interest, one volume includes meeting notes from trips to Europe (specifically Italy, Germany, and Great Britain) and Asia (Japan and China), discussing the current effort by those countries at the end of the 1970s. This document provides a capstone for the early work on uranium extraction from seawater, as inorganic adsorbents had been investigated for almost 30 years and may be where research on organo-functionalized chelating resins is mentioned for the first time. A seminal report by Tamada was published in 2009 providing a high-level overview of significant Japanese contributions, including two of their pilot-scale studies with polymer adsorbents. Finally, a 2010 report from Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory summarizes more recent international efforts, organized by country.

elements.content: It is important to note the aforementioned reviews often address, at least in part, many of the engineering and site identification challenges related to extracting uranium from seawater. These aspects were of particular importance during the early years at the height of debate over fixed vs fluidized beds and whether active pumping or passive methods over inorganic adsorbents would provide sufficient extraction of uranium to mitigate the energy requirements of the pumping itself. Indeed, Kelmers from Oak Ridge National Laboratory noted, “At 100% uranium recovery efficiency, an ocean stream equivalent to 25 times the annual Mississippi River flow would have to be processed to recover 10,000 tons/year. This scale of operation raises fundamental engineering questions...” While there remain essential challenges to surmount prior to large scale deployment, the engineering questions are ultimately a function of the adsorbent to be deployed. Research with braided polymer adsorbents, the current state of the art technology, was initiated in the 1990s, and the accompanying engineering questions have not changed significantly in recent years.

elements.content: Several further clarifications in the scope of this review are also important to address at this juncture. First, the focus of the review is on materials which have been intentionally designed and developed. That is to say, this review does not cover the adsorption of uranium on minerals, diatomaceous earth, pyrolyzed organic matter, or other such materials which occur naturally or have not been rationally synthesized. Second, materials developed for the pre-concentration of uranium specifically for analytical purposes are also not covered. Although related in several respects, the intent behind the design of such materials and the methods for evaluating their performance do not facilitate adequate comparison with materials developed with environmental deployment for selective uranium recovery as the end goal. Finally, the application of the material is the recovery of uranium from environmental seawater, not simply aqueous solutions. As discussed below, seawater is a highly complex matrix, replete with high ionic strength and competing ions and possessing an incredibly low concentration of uranium. The ionic strength (specifically, the presence of the carbonate anion CO3 2–), concentration, and pH of the aqueous solution dictate the speciation of uranium, which in turn dramatically influences the adsorption properties. In general, materials are not included if they are only investigated for uranium uptake from aqueous media, with no consideration for the concentration and salinity challenges that accompany seawater deployment.

elements.content: The noteworthy exception to the preceding statement is , Nanostructured Materials, which includes research on porous carbon, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), covalent organic frameworks (COFs), porous organic polymers (POPs), porous silica, and genetically engineered proteins. In contrast to more technologically mature materials, such as traditional metal oxides or graft-polymer adsorbents, most of the aforementioned nanostructured materials have not been developed to the point where deployment in environmental seawater is practical, even on a small scale. As a result, uranium extraction studies are often performed at lab-scale on systems which are far less complex than environmental seawater. Significant work has been performed to develop these new classes of adsorbents, and to the best of our awareness no comprehensive review exists summarizing their capabilities for seawater uranium recovery. Such materials often display dramatic improvements in selectivity or uranium adsorption capacity as well, suggesting at high levels of success should technological development be pursued further. Nanostructured materials represent the very cutting-edge of materials research for seawater uranium recovery and are far behind adsorbent polymers with regards to material development and deployment. Nevertheless, in an effort to provide a comprehensive review on the materials developed for seawater uranium recovery, they are included in the final section.

elements.content: Starting with a brief overview of the history of seawater mining of uranium and followed by a discussion of the challenges associated with performing this research, this review will categorically summarize developments in synthesized adsorbent materials. Inorganic sorbents were one of the earliest technologies developed, and though falling out of favor in the 1980s, recently renewed efforts are articulated. Synthetic polymers represent the category of adsorbent most capable of large-scale deployment in the near term. Research pertaining to modifications of the trunk material, new developments in polymer functionalization, tuning material properties through postsynthesis treatment, and the use of computer-guided design for the preparation of highly selective ligands are all covered in . Nanostructured materials constitute the newest avenue for potential uranium adsorbents, leveraging extremely high surface areas and readily tailorable properties to achieve unprecedented uranium capacities. Research performed in this area includes porous carbon, MOFs, organic framework materials (e.g., COFs and POPs), and mesoporous silica. Finally, this review concludes with a research summary and the authors’ perspectives regarding where ongoing efforts should be focused to achieve greatest impact.

elements.content: The extraction of uranium from seawater has been a topic of active research by various state entities for more than six decades (). The first mention of this research area in the open literature occurs in 1964 by Davies and colleagues, as is often cited in recent articles. While there are no citations in the aforementioned work to earlier publications explicitly regarding uranium extractions, even a casual reading makes apparent that the article is in fact reviewing an extensive research effort. The genesis of this research dates back to “Project Oyster”, initiated in the early 1950s in the United Kingdom. In the wake of WWII and the initiation of both nuclear power and weapons programs, a sense of urgency developed as it was realized sparse terrestrial reserves would force reliance on potentially volatile international markets and create vulnerability in both defense and power production. It is noteworthy that similar concerns motivate the current research effort, as well as efforts to harness unconventional reserves of other critical minerals, despite sparse economic opportunity. Declassified documents available from the U.K. Archives recount the pioneering investigations with early inorganic adsorbents, liquid- liquid extractions, and identification of promising sites for establishing adsorbent beds and recovery facilities.
elements.clean_text:
Brief History of the Recovery of Seawater Uranium

The extraction of uranium from seawater has been a topic of active research by various state entities for more than six decades (). The first mention of this research area in the open literature occurs in 1964 by Davies and colleagues, as is often cited in recent articles. While there are no citations in the aforementioned work to earlier publications explicitly regarding uranium extractions, even a casual reading makes apparent that the article is in fact reviewing an extensive research effort. The genesis of this research dates back to "Project Oyster", initiated in the early 1950s in the United Kingdom. In the wake of WWII and the initiation of both nuclear power and weapons programs, a sense of urgency developed as it was realized sparse terrestrial reserves would force reliance on potentially volatile international markets and create vulnerability in both defense and power production. It is noteworthy that similar concerns motivate the current research effort, as well as efforts to harness unconventional reserves of other critical minerals, despite sparse economic opportunity. Declassified documents available from the U.K. Archives recount the pioneering investigations with early inorganic adsorbents, liquid- liquid extractions, and identification of promising sites for establishing adsorbent beds and recovery facilities.

elements.content: Development of representative adsorbent technologies throughout history for the extraction of uranium from seawater. Only adsorbents contacted with environmental seawater are displayed. The majority of samples are exposed to seawater for 20–60 days, with the shortest contact times less than 1 day (denoted with *) and the longest contact time 240 days (denoted with †). References for displayed materials are provided in brackets. Triangular markers denote open ocean deployments.

References for displayed materials are provided in brackets. Triangular markers denote open ocean deployments.

elements.content: Efforts of these early decades focused on development of inorganic adsorbents deployed either as fixed or floating adsorbent beds. The performance of 81 different inorganic materials are reported as of 1979, with lead sulfide, lead naphthalene, and hydrous titanium dioxide all achieving uranium capacities exceeding 1 mg of uranium/g of metal in adsorbent. Despite the ultimate consensus that hydrous titanium dioxide was the best material, the number of lead-based inorganic adsorbents that were investigated is approximately equal to the number of nonlead-based adsorbents.

The performance of 81 different inorganic materials are reported as of 1979, with lead sulfide, lead naphthalene, and hydrous titanium dioxide all achieving uranium capacities exceeding 1 mg of uranium/g of metal in adsorbent. Despite the ultimate consensus that hydrous titanium dioxide was the best material, the number of lead-based inorganic adsorbents that were investigated is approximately equal to the number of nonlead-based adsorbents.

elements.content: In the early 1980s the technology for extracting uranium from seawater changed dramatically. While several organo-functionalized polymers had been investigated late in the preceding decade, unremarkable capacities and speculation regarding biofouling and limited stabilities in seawater made them more of a novelty than a research emphasis. In 1979 and 1980, Egawa and colleagues first reported the application of an amidoxime-functionalized polymeric adsorbent, formed by treating poly­(AN-co-divinylbenzene) (AN = acrylonitrile) beads with hydroxylamine. Using this resin-based amidoxime adsorbent in a column system, more than 80% of uranium could be recovered from a volume of seawater 4 orders of magnitude larger than the volume of the adsorbent. A subsequent report articulated the recovery of 450 μg of uranium/g of adsorbent following 130 days of continuous contact with seawater, as well as an average 82.9% uranium recovery over ten recycles of the adsorbent. In 1982, a seminal work by Schwochau and co-workers articulated the key parameters for adsorbents for recovering uranium from seawater. Large-scale availability at low cost, stability under seawater conditions, physical resilience, ease of deployment, rapid binding kinetics, high loading capacity, and facile elution were listed as essential requirements to merit further investigation. These criteria were then used to assess the results of a screening study of approximately 200 organo-functionalized resins, with the authors determining cross-linked poly­(acrylamidoximes) to be the most promising candidate. This work was quickly followed by a more detailed investigation using amidoxime and imidoxime functionalized resins, as well as the first crystallographic investigation of how amidoxime binds uranyl. Simultaneous with and independent of Schwochau’s submission, an MIT report comparing performance of hydrous titanium oxide and four experimental ion exchange resins was submitted to the U.S. Department of Energy. The authors indicate an amidoxime functionalized resin matched the performance of the hydrous titanium oxide, and displayed considerably superior mechanical properties. They speculated improvements in performance upon optimization, which they subsequently observed and published in a separate report submitted later in the same year. The fact that amidoxime- functionalized adsorbents are still state of the art attests in part to the validity of the aforementioned investigations, but should also hint at an area for potential advances in the field. After over 30 years of further research, it is not unthinkable that materials eliminated by Schwochau due to failing a key metric could be developed more economically and achieve superior performance than amidoxime.

elements.content: From 1981 to 1988, an experimental plant was operated in Japan using a hydrous titanium dioxide sorbent. However, low adsorption capacities of approximately 0.1 mg of uranium/g of sorbent led to discontinuation of the project. Economic factors such as the poor mechanical resistance of the sorbent and the necessity of mechanical pumping of seawater across the adsorbent bed made the approach unsustainable. Forming the sorbent into pellets increased mechanical durability, but intraparticle diffusion dramatically decreased the sorption that was achieved.
elements.clean_text: From 1981 to 1988, an experimental plant was operated in Japan using a hydrous titanium dioxide sorbent. However, low adsorption capacities of approximately 0.1 mg of uranium/g of sorbent led to discontinuation of the project. Economic factors such as the poor mechanical resistance of the sorbent and the necessity of mechanical pumping of seawater across the adsorbent bed made the approach unsustainable. Forming the sorbent into pellets increased mechanical durability, but intraparticle diffusion dramatically decreased the sorption that was achieved.

elements.content: Major developments in preparation of amidoxime-functionalized fibers were made in Japan over the 1980s and 90s. Discovering poly­(amidoxime) to have poor mechanical strength, Tamada and co-workers used radiation-induced graft polymerization (RIGP) to functionalize a strong polymeric trunk fiber, such as polyethylene, with poly­(AN) which could be subsequently transformed to poly­(amidoxime). The polyolefin trunk provided the necessary strength for the adsorbent, while the poly­(amidoxime) graft chains were accessible for uranium binding. Electron beam radiation of the trunk fiber under an inert atmosphere generateed free radicals in the polymer. The fibers could then be placed in solutions of AN to graft poly­(AN) onto the sites of the free radicals. Comonomers, such as methacrylic acid, were included to increase the hydrophilicity of the final polymer fiber. Finally, a treatment with KOH deprotonated the carboxylic acids and induced swelling of the polymer fiber for contact with seawater.
elements.clean_text: Major developments in preparation of amidoxime-functionalized fibers were made in Japan over the 1980s and 90s. Discovering poly(amidoxime) to have poor mechanical strength, Tamada and co-workers used radiation-induced graft polymerization (RIGP) to functionalize a strong polymeric trunk fiber, such as polyethylene, with poly(AN) which could be subsequently transformed to poly(amidoxime). The polyolefin trunk provided the necessary strength for the adsorbent, while the poly(amidoxime) graft chains were accessible for uranium binding. Electron beam radiation of the trunk fiber under an inert atmosphere generateed free radicals in the polymer. The fibers could then be placed in solutions of AN to graft poly(AN) onto the sites of the free radicals. Comonomers, such as methacrylic acid, were included to increase the hydrophilicity of the final polymer fiber. Finally, a treatment with KOH deprotonated the carboxylic acids and induced swelling of the polymer fiber for contact with seawater.

elements.content: Large scale marine experiments were also performed by the Japanese, with the longest lasting from 1999–2001. Noting the additional energy demand from pumping seawater across an adsorbent bed, they sought to use passive diffusion of seawater through adsorbent stacks deployed in the ocean. Adsorbent stacks were prepared from amidoxime-functionalized polyethylene fabric, which was then cut into smaller sheets. 144 adsorbent stacks were placed into a 16 m2 adsorption bed, of which three were suspended from an 8 m × 8 m floating frame anchored to the seafloor. displays an example of the adsorbent stack as well as a scheme of the floating frame and adsorbent beds. A crane ship extracted adsorbent beds every 20–40 days for fractional elution with 0.5 M HCl. Over the two year study, approximately 1 kg yellowcake was collected, affording an average of 0.5 mg uranium/g-adsorbent every 30 days.

elements.content: It was determined the most expensive part of the experiment with sorbent stacks was the floating frame. An innovative redesign involved preparation of a braided adsorbent that could be anchored to the seafloor, creating a sorbent bed biomimetic of a kelp farm. Attaching a float to the top of the sorbent braid allowed their suspension in seawater, and upon wireless release from the anchor, facilitated their recovery with a fishing boat. After 30 days of soaking, the polymer fiber recovered 1.5 mg uranium g–1 adsorbent. displays the proposed deployment system for the braided adsorbent.

elements.content: Proposed deployment system for braided amidoxime-functionalized polymer sorbents, intended to simulate kelp fields.

elements.content: Noteworthy results from Korea from 1999 to 2000 articulated the postsynthetic installation of a cationic site within the adsorbent polymer, advantageous from the perspective of increasing hydrophilicity, facilitating mass transport through Coulombic repulsion-induced swelling of graft chains, and promoting electrostatic concentration of the anionic UO2(CO3)3 4– in seawater.
elements.clean_text: Noteworthy results from Korea from 1999 to 2000 articulated the postsynthetic installation of a cationic site within the adsorbent polymer, advantageous from the perspective of increasing hydrophilicity, facilitating mass transport through Coulombic repulsion-induced swelling of graft chains, and promoting electrostatic concentration of the anionic UO2(CO3)3 4- in seawater.

elements.content: Simultaneously, research from Turkey and Japan afforded a wealth of information further developing RIGP processes for the design of polymeric adsorbents for uranium recovery from seawater. Systematic investigations were performed to thoroughly studied poly­(amidoxime-co-methacrylic acid) adsorbents, while several new avenues were developed for the development of amidoxime-functionalized polymers. Work initiated by Güven, Seko, and Tamada reported the preparation of glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) grafted by RIGP to a polyolefin support. This approach allowed for ring-opening of the epoxide group on the GMA by a nucleophile, such as a sterically unencumbered amine, enabling the postgraft installation of functional groups which are not amenable to RIGP conditions or designer chelating moieties such as bis-amidoximes. Emulsion polymerization was also investigated for the first time for development of uranium adsorbents. Literature from the mid- to late-2000s is dominated by India, with studies reporting application of multidentate chelating ligands grafted on resin, hydrogels composed of various copolymers, amidoxime-based polypropylene sheets, and in-field demonstration experiments in the Trombay Estuary.
elements.clean_text: Simultaneously, research from Turkey and Japan afforded a wealth of information further developing RIGP processes for the design of polymeric adsorbents for uranium recovery from seawater. Systematic investigations were performed to thoroughly studied poly(amidoxime-co-methacrylic acid) adsorbents, while several new avenues were developed for the development of amidoxime-functionalized polymers. Work initiated by Güven, Seko, and Tamada reported the preparation of glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) grafted by RIGP to a polyolefin support. This approach allowed for ring-opening of the epoxide group on the GMA by a nucleophile, such as a sterically unencumbered amine, enabling the postgraft installation of functional groups which are not amenable to RIGP conditions or designer chelating moieties such as bis-amidoximes. Emulsion polymerization was also investigated for the first time for development of uranium adsorbents. Literature from the mid- to late-2000s is dominated by India, with studies reporting application of multidentate chelating ligands grafted on resin, hydrogels composed of various copolymers, amidoxime-based polypropylene sheets, and in-field demonstration experiments in the Trombay Estuary.

elements.content: Since 2011, there has been renewed enthusiasm in the United States for extracting uranium from seawater, stemming from the formation of an interdisciplinary, multi-institution working group founded by the Office of Nuclear Energy. Starting with the goal of doubling the adsorption capacity of the Japanese materials, multifaceted efforts were pursued leveraging advances in high performance computing, advanced characterization instruments, and nanoscience to enable technical breakthroughs. This multifaceted effort involved seven key thrusts: (1) investigation of uranium coordination and application of computation to ligand design; (2) thermodynamic, kinetic, and structural characterization; (3) development of advanced polymeric adsorbents through RIGP; (4) preparation of novel nanoscale adsorbents; (5) establishment of marine testing for performance assessment; (6) improving durability and reusability; and (7) cost analysis and deployment modeling. At the time of writing, these efforts are ongoing, with major contributions including development of high surface-area trunk materials for polymer adsorbents, two optimized polymer formulations prepared by RIGP, application of atom-transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) for adsorbent preparation with record-setting performance, and the first instance of a metal–organic framework (MOF) for uranium recovery from seawater. Most recently there has been an explosion of pertinent literature from China, with select noteworthy reports including a promising organic–inorganic composite adsorbent, a graphene-oxide/amidoxime hydrogel, amidoxime-functionalized on ultra high-molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE), and electrospun polyamidoxime with polyvinylidene fluoride (PVF) to enhance bulk mechanical robustness.

elements.content: Over more than six decades, the extraction of uranium from seawater has processed through several different material generations, with representative seawater capacities displayed in . From the initial studies in Project Oyster involving fixed bed adsorbents of hydrous titanium dioxide, to organic chelating resins of the 1980s, to the ocean-deployable polymer adsorbents in the 1990s, to the current generation of high surface area fibers, a steady multi-national effort has persisted throughout and is expected will continue for the foreseeable future.
elements.clean_text: Over more than six decades, the extraction of uranium from seawater has processed through several different material generations, with representative seawater capacities displayed in . From the initial studies in Project Oyster involving fixed bed adsorbents of hydrous titanium dioxide, to organic chelating resins of the 1980s, to the ocean-deployable polymer adsorbents in the 1990s, to the current generation of high surface area fibers, a steady multi-national effort has persisted throughout and is expected will continue for the foreseeable future.

elements.content: The complexity of seawater constitutes one of the greatest challenges in the development of effective adsorbents for uranium extractions, as well as one of the greatest difficulties in analyzing or reproducing the performance of adsorbents reported in the literature. Rigorous application of the scientific method requires variation of only one parameter per experiment, and with respect to developing materials for extracting uranium from seawater, this variable is routinely a difference in adsorbent or treatment process. However, the composition and acidity of seawater can be attributed to a wide range of environmental and biological aspects, in turn creating numerous other parameters which must be adjusted or, at the very least, monitored and normalized. Such effort requires an extensive investment in manpower and resources, ostensibly beyond what is reasonably achievable by most independent research groups, despite the necessity for reproducible and relevant extraction data. While extraction of uranium from one batch of seawater would ensure matrix consistency, the extremely low concentration (approximately 3.3 μg L–1) requires either extremely large volumes of water (at least one liter per mg of adsorbent, assuming a capacity not exceeding 3 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent) or the addition of a uranium spike, increasing the concentration to something more readily detected, but which is not actually representative of the environmental conditions it is intended to depict. As the binding of uranium by any chelating group is inherently an equilibrium reaction, increasing the concentration of uranium in solution will necessarily increase the quantity of uranium bound by the adsorbent material, resulting in exaggerated performance which is not representative of performance in actual seawater.
elements.clean_text:
Challenges of Working with Seawater

The complexity of seawater constitutes one of the greatest challenges in the development of effective adsorbents for uranium extractions, as well as one of the greatest difficulties in analyzing or reproducing the performance of adsorbents reported in the literature. Rigorous application of the scientific method requires variation of only one parameter per experiment, and with respect to developing materials for extracting uranium from seawater, this variable is routinely a difference in adsorbent or treatment process. However, the composition and acidity of seawater can be attributed to a wide range of environmental and biological aspects, in turn creating numerous other parameters which must be adjusted or, at the very least, monitored and normalized. Such effort requires an extensive investment in manpower and resources, ostensibly beyond what is reasonably achievable by most independent research groups, despite the necessity for reproducible and relevant extraction data. While extraction of uranium from one batch of seawater would ensure matrix consistency, the extremely low concentration (approximately 3.3 μg L-1) requires either extremely large volumes of water (at least one liter per mg of adsorbent, assuming a capacity not exceeding 3 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent) or the addition of a uranium spike, increasing the concentration to something more readily detected, but which is not actually representative of the environmental conditions it is intended to depict. As the binding of uranium by any chelating group is inherently an equilibrium reaction, increasing the concentration of uranium in solution will necessarily increase the quantity of uranium bound by the adsorbent material, resulting in exaggerated performance which is not representative of performance in actual seawater.

elements.content: Preparation of simulated seawater could afford a reproducible surrogate for environmental seawater, but due to the low concentration of uranium in seawater, similar challenges are encountered as discussed above. Importantly, a representative simulant must be of appropriate pH and composition, including total dissolved solids, organic content, and competing ions. Perhaps the best experimental seawater simulant has been reported very recently by the group of Wu and colleagues, where the simulant was prepared from sea salt dissolved in DI water, further adjusted to the environmentally relevant salinity, pH, and metal concentration. At the very least, a salt solution should be utilized which affords relevant concentrations of carbonate, ionic strength, and pH. It is well-known that adsorption of uranium is greatly enhanced at low pH, while speciation of uranium is known to vary as a function of both pH and concentration, and adsorbents have superior performance when deployed in matrixes of low ionic strength. While awareness of these difficulties is necessary for the design and engineering of advanced adsorbents, manipulating these established parameters to achieve the highest uranium uptake also appears to be a common practice. Some of the major challenges of working with seawater are summarized in this section.

elements.content: As mentioned previously, uranium is dissolved in seawater at a relatively uniform 3.3 μg L–1. (In this review we refer to ppb and μg L–1 synonymously even though the density of seawater is not precisely 1 kg L–1. Minor differences in uranium distribution as well as experimental error intrinsic in analytical analysis of trace elements in seawater surpass any significant difference between whether the quantity of seawater is 1 L or 1 kg, making the discrimination largely semantic for our purposes.) As displayed in , numerous other elements spanning the periodic table are also dissolved at detectable concentrations in seawater, many at higher concentrations, creating the need for a material which selectively binds with uranium. Importantly, different adsorbents will display different affinity for the various metals present in seawater. For instance, the aforementioned amidoxime-functionalized polymers are generally known to extract large amounts of vanadium, iron, and copper, in addition to the alkali and alkali earth cations. The relative concentration of competing ions in the seawater has the potential to dramatically affect the uranium capacity of the adsorbent material.
elements.clean_text:
Conservative vs Nonconservative Metals

As mentioned previously, uranium is dissolved in seawater at a relatively uniform 3.3 μg L-1. (In this review we refer to ppb and μg L-1 synonymously even though the density of seawater is not precisely 1 kg L-1. Minor differences in uranium distribution as well as experimental error intrinsic in analytical analysis of trace elements in seawater surpass any significant difference between whether the quantity of seawater is 1 L or 1 kg, making the discrimination largely semantic for our purposes.) As displayed in , numerous other elements spanning the periodic table are also dissolved at detectable concentrations in seawater, many at higher concentrations, creating the need for a material which selectively binds with uranium. Importantly, different adsorbents will display different affinity for the various metals present in seawater. For instance, the aforementioned amidoxime-functionalized polymers are generally known to extract large amounts of vanadium, iron, and copper, in addition to the alkali and alkali earth cations. The relative concentration of competing ions in the seawater has the potential to dramatically affect the uranium capacity of the adsorbent material.

Concentration of Selected Elements in Seawater, as Reported in ref <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref58" specific-use="ref-style=base-text"></xref> concentration in seawater element mg kg–1 (ppm) mol L–1 Cl 19 400 0.546 Na 10 800 0.468 Mg 1290 53 × 10–3 Ca 413 10.3 × 10–3 K 400 10.2 × 10–3 Li 0.18 26 × 10–6 Ni 0.005 8 × 10–9 Fe 0.0034 0.5 × 10–9 U 0.0033 14 × 10–9 V 0.00183 36 × 10–9 Cu 0.001 3 × 10–9 S 0.0009 28 × 10–3 Pb 0.00003 0.01 × 10–9 TIC 0.00029 24.2 × 10–3 DIP 0.00071 2.3 × 10–6

Total Inorganic Carbon.

Dissolved Inorganic Phosphorus.

While a rigorous discussion of marine geochemistry is beyond the scope of this review, for the sake of discussion metals dissolved in seawater can be loosely divided into the categories of conservative and nonconservative, based on the extent to which it participates in biological, chemical, or geological processes, relative to its original concentration. Uranium is a conservative metal, meaning the overall concentration is relatively homogeneous throughout the oceans, uranium complexes interact only weakly with suspended particles, and the residence time of uranium exceeds 105 years. In contrast, aluminum interacts strongly with suspended particles and displays a short oceanic residence time, giving it a nonconservative scavenged-type distribution. Iron and copper have distributions which are influenced by both recycling and scavenging processes, making them nonconservative and displaying a hybrid distribution.

Uranium is a conservative metal, meaning the overall concentration is relatively homogeneous throughout the oceans, uranium complexes interact only weakly with suspended particles, and the residence time of uranium exceeds 105 years. In contrast, aluminum interacts strongly with suspended particles and displays a short oceanic residence time, giving it a nonconservative scavenged-type distribution. Iron and copper have distributions which are influenced by both recycling and scavenging processes, making them nonconservative and displaying a hybrid distribution.

elements.content: Perhaps the most important competing ion in extracting uranium from seawater is vanadium, as increased concentrations of vanadium are known to dramatically reduce uranium uptake. While it has been known for a long time that competing ions have deleterious effects on uranium extraction, the extent to which these effects are realized is a function of the both the adsorbent and the local seawater composition.

elements.content: The speciation of uranium in seawater is an area that has been extensively investigated and is reasonably well understood. Early work reported on uranium extraction from seawater regarded uranium speciation as forming the anionic triscarbonato-uranyl complex, UO2(CO3)3 4–, resulting in development of adsorbents capable of extracting a highly anionic complex. However, the literature abounds with instances of M nUO2(CO3)3 2(2‑n)‑ complex identification, particularly in areas of geochemical research and environmental remediation. The first work to report an aqueous Can[UO2(CO3)3]2(2‑n)‑ complex involved the application of time-resolved laser fluorescence to seepage waters of a mine tailing pile. The authors proposed the neutral Ca2[UO2(CO3)3] as the dominant species, which was independently supported shortly thereafter. X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS) has been applied at various points, and while Can[UO2(CO3)3]2(2‑n)‑ complexes can be identified, precise quantification of the Ca coordination number is impeded by spectral overlap in the extended XAFS (EXAFS) region with the distal oxygen of the carbonate group, which is further complicated by the presence of a NamCan[UO2(CO3)3](2(2‑n)‑m)‑ complex. More recently, Endrizzi and Rao used calcium ion selective electrode potentiometry and optical absorption spectrophotometry to provide precise equilibrium constants for Ca and Mg complexation with UO2(CO3)3 4–. These data were then used to calculate the speciation of uranyl in environmental seawater, with enthalpies of complexation determined for Ca­[UO2(CO3)3]2– and Ca2[UO2(CO3)3]. It was observed that more than 90% of the overall uranium dissolved in seawater could be accounted for in Ca2[UO2(CO3)3] and Mg­[UO2(CO3)3]2– complexes, as displayed in the updated speciation diagram in . The same team recently reviewed the efforts to determine uranium speciation in seawater, as well as investigated the solubility products for several uranyl- containing minerals in seawater. The reader is directed there for more comprehensive discussion.
elements.clean_text:
Uranium Speciation

The speciation of uranium in seawater is an area that has been extensively investigated and is reasonably well understood. Early work reported on uranium extraction from seawater regarded uranium speciation as forming the anionic triscarbonato-uranyl complex, UO2(CO3)3 4-, resulting in development of adsorbents capable of extracting a highly anionic complex. However, the literature abounds with instances of M nUO2(CO3)3 2(2-n)- complex identification, particularly in areas of geochemical research and environmental remediation. The first work to report an aqueous Can[UO2(CO3)3]2(2-n)- complex involved the application of time-resolved laser fluorescence to seepage waters of a mine tailing pile. The authors proposed the neutral Ca2[UO2(CO3)3] as the dominant species, which was independently supported shortly thereafter. X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS) has been applied at various points, and while Can[UO2(CO3)3]2(2-n)- complexes can be identified, precise quantification of the Ca coordination number is impeded by spectral overlap in the extended XAFS (EXAFS) region with the distal oxygen of the carbonate group, which is further complicated by the presence of a NamCan[UO2(CO3)3](2(2-n)-m)- complex. More recently, Endrizzi and Rao used calcium ion selective electrode potentiometry and optical absorption spectrophotometry to provide precise equilibrium constants for Ca and Mg complexation with UO2(CO3)3 4-. These data were then used to calculate the speciation of uranyl in environmental seawater, with enthalpies of complexation determined for Ca[UO2(CO3)3]2- and Ca2[UO2(CO3)3]. It was observed that more than 90% of the overall uranium dissolved in seawater could be accounted for in Ca2[UO2(CO3)3] and Mg[UO2(CO3)3]2- complexes, as displayed in the updated speciation diagram in . The same team recently reviewed the efforts to determine uranium speciation in seawater, as well as investigated the solubility products for several uranyl- containing minerals in seawater. The reader is directed there for more comprehensive discussion.

elements.content: In addition to speciation as a function of dissolved alkali and alkali earth cations, uranium concentration, ionic strength, and pH are also known to affect speciation and even result in formation of polynuclear complexes. Work by Krestou and Panias reports the calculated speciation of uranium as a function of concentration, pH, ionic strength, and carbonate. In all instances, the free uranyl cation (UO2 2+) is calculated at low pH < 4, while UO2(CO3)3 4– is obtained above pH 8.5. However, formation of polynuclear (UO)2CO3(OH)3 – is enhanced over pH 6–8 as uranium concentration is increased. While conditions representative of seawater were not investigated, a speciation diagram was calculated for a solution similar to many uranium-spiked brine simulants reported in the literature (ionic strength of 0.31 M, uranium concentration 1 × 10–5 M). UO2 2+ dominates until approximately pH 4.5, where UO2(OH)2 accumulates, peaking at pH 6. From pH 6.5–7.5, the polynuclear complex (UO2)2CO3(OH)3 – is most abundant, replaced by UO2(CO3)3 4– from pH 7.5–10. Comparison of this speciation, likely representative of many screening solutions, with that calculated for environmental seawater underscores the necessity of realistic sorption conditions and one of the major challenges in developing adsorbents for extraction of uranium from seawater.
elements.clean_text:
Salinity and pH Effects

In addition to speciation as a function of dissolved alkali and alkali earth cations, uranium concentration, ionic strength, and pH are also known to affect speciation and even result in formation of polynuclear complexes. Work by Krestou and Panias reports the calculated speciation of uranium as a function of concentration, pH, ionic strength, and carbonate. In all instances, the free uranyl cation (UO2 2+) is calculated at low pH < 4, while UO2(CO3)3 4- is obtained above pH 8.5. However, formation of polynuclear (UO)2CO3(OH)3 - is enhanced over pH 6-8 as uranium concentration is increased. While conditions representative of seawater were not investigated, a speciation diagram was calculated for a solution similar to many uranium-spiked brine simulants reported in the literature (ionic strength of 0.31 M, uranium concentration 1 × 10-5 M). UO2 2+ dominates until approximately pH 4.5, where UO2(OH)2 accumulates, peaking at pH 6. From pH 6.5-7.5, the polynuclear complex (UO2)2CO3(OH)3 - is most abundant, replaced by UO2(CO3)3 4- from pH 7.5-10. Comparison of this speciation, likely representative of many screening solutions, with that calculated for environmental seawater underscores the necessity of realistic sorption conditions and one of the major challenges in developing adsorbents for extraction of uranium from seawater.

elements.content: Salinity, the amount of salt dissolved in a body of water, is another important factor governing uranium chemistry and concentration, thereby affecting adsorbent performance. Laboratory research has revealed that the presence of sodium chloride, calcium, magnesium, and bicarbonate significantly retards uranium adsorption kinetics to braided fiber adsorbents, as revealed in . Standardization of seawater simulant and normalization of uranium extraction data from environmental seawater is essential for valid head-to-head comparisons of material performance. For example, in an effort to compare samples screened at different locations around the United States, the DOE-NE Fuel Resources team chose to normalize the seawater data to 35 practical salinity units, a universally accepted value for seawater salinity around the world, roughly equivalent to 35 parts-per-thousand. As uranium concentration scales with salinity, it was prudent to normalize to this value. Moreover, salinity normalization also provides a basis for comparison between locales where salinity differs.

elements.content: The application of normalizing uranium uptake as a function of salinity was first reported in the work of Tsouris and colleagues, who observed a salinity concentration of 28.5 practical salinity units (psu) in the environmental seawater used for their uranium uptake experiments. Previous work identified uranium concentrations in seawater from the coast of Savannah (Georgia, U.S.A.) and Charleston (South Carolina, U.S.A.), 3.6 and 3.2 ppb, respectively, which differed from the 2.85 ppb uranium concentration in Sequim Bay (Washington, U.S.A.). The same adsorbent displayed different performance when deployed under these conditions, with uptake of 3.94, 3.36, and 2.7 mg of uranium/g achieved in Savannah, Charleston, and Sequim Bay seawater. When the salinity and uranium concentration of the Sequim Bay seawater was normalized to 35 psu and 3.3 ppb, consistent with open ocean conditions, the uranium uptake was determined to be 3.3 mg of uranium/g. An adsorbent provided by the JAEA was also tested simultaneously for comparison, affording an uptake of 1.1 mg of uranium/g in Sequim Bay seawater, which normalized to 1.3 mg of uranium/g. This approach was replicated in subsequent publications to normalize uranium uptake obtained from deployment in low salinity seawater to values anticipated following deployment in the open ocean.

elements.content: Biofouling is the surface accumulation of microorganisms, algae, plants, and eventually animals. Due to potential deployment under environmental conditions, the effects of biofouling also constitute a challenge for the development and screening of adsorbents for uranium extraction. Biofouling is considered to occur in four stages, beginning only seconds after immersion in seawater where surfaces are coated with a thin organic film. The second stage is characterized by the settling and colonization of bacteria and diatoms on the surface of the material. These are followed by the development of microbial films, constituting the third stage, which create rough surfaces which trap additional particles and organisms. The final stage occurs when macroorganisms, such as barnacles or mussles, begin to grow from the fouled surface. Design features commonly considered advantageous for adsorbents, such as large porosities or nanotexturing, may promote the rate of biofouling and ultimately render the materials unusable.
elements.clean_text:
Biofouling

Biofouling is the surface accumulation of microorganisms, algae, plants, and eventually animals. Due to potential deployment under environmental conditions, the effects of biofouling also constitute a challenge for the development and screening of adsorbents for uranium extraction. Biofouling is considered to occur in four stages, beginning only seconds after immersion in seawater where surfaces are coated with a thin organic film. The second stage is characterized by the settling and colonization of bacteria and diatoms on the surface of the material. These are followed by the development of microbial films, constituting the third stage, which create rough surfaces which trap additional particles and organisms. The final stage occurs when macroorganisms, such as barnacles or mussles, begin to grow from the fouled surface. Design features commonly considered advantageous for adsorbents, such as large porosities or nanotexturing, may promote the rate of biofouling and ultimately render the materials unusable.

elements.content: Initial reports indicate biofouling on inorganic materials was not directly observed, but more advanced microscopy techniques applied to organic chelating resins reveal filling of pore structures with unidentified debris after seawater contact, consistent with biofouling. Indian literature articulates the preparation of adsorbents containing silver nanoparticles which display marked improvements in biofouling resistance and are amenable to deployment in bioaggressive environments (). Japanese literature reports the facile removal of biofouling by simply immersing the adsorbent in fresh water prior to elution of uranium, with the change in ionic strength sufficient to dissolve the biological growth. Recent investigations have been performed to investigate the effects of biofouling on amidoxime-functionalized polymer adsorbents used for seawater extraction of uranium. The adsorbents were tested in the presence or absence of light to simulate deployment in shallow or deep marine environments, with continuous flow of environmental seawater designed to represent natural ocean currents. After 42 days of exposure, uranium uptake was 30% lower for the fiber exposed in light, with numerous algal cells observed by microscopy ( and ). A major conclusion of this work is that deployment of the adsorbents below the photic zone may be necessary to mitigate biofouling effects. Time and temperature are also known to affect the extent of biofouling, influencing the length of any campaign, as well as the location of adsorbent deployment.

elements.content: The influence of temperature on adsorbent performance is truly multifaceted, and ocean temperatures can vary dramatically depending on location and season. Computational and thermochemical titrations demonstrate chelation of uranyl by amidoxime is an endothermic process. Accordingly, increasing solution temperature is expected to improve adsorbent performance. While such investigations cannot account for the effect of the polymer support itself, complementary work has been performed on seawater-contacted adsorbent polymers, confirming the results obtained from small molecule studies, and putatively affording extension to nanoscale adsorbents as well. However, as discussed above, biofouling is also known to correlate with temperature, which may dramatically reduce the performance of an adsorbent. Nevertheless, achieving the right balance between promoting an endothermic reaction and mitigating biofouling is not necessarily obvious. For example, in-field demonstration experiments performed at the intake and outfall canals of the Tarapur Atomic Power Station in India’s Trombay Estuary correlated uranium uptake with fouling, deployment time, temperature, and other parameters. More than a 30% increase in uranium uptake was observed at the outfall canal due to the increased temperature, despite the increased biofouling that was observed.
elements.clean_text:
Temperature

The influence of temperature on adsorbent performance is truly multifaceted, and ocean temperatures can vary dramatically depending on location and season. Computational and thermochemical titrations demonstrate chelation of uranyl by amidoxime is an endothermic process. Accordingly, increasing solution temperature is expected to improve adsorbent performance. While such investigations cannot account for the effect of the polymer support itself, complementary work has been performed on seawater-contacted adsorbent polymers, confirming the results obtained from small molecule studies, and putatively affording extension to nanoscale adsorbents as well. However, as discussed above, biofouling is also known to correlate with temperature, which may dramatically reduce the performance of an adsorbent. Nevertheless, achieving the right balance between promoting an endothermic reaction and mitigating biofouling is not necessarily obvious. For example, in-field demonstration experiments performed at the intake and outfall canals of the Tarapur Atomic Power Station in India's Trombay Estuary correlated uranium uptake with fouling, deployment time, temperature, and other parameters. More than a 30% increase in uranium uptake was observed at the outfall canal due to the increased temperature, despite the increased biofouling that was observed.

elements.content: Temperature control can be readily achieved under laboratory conditions, as well as by judicious choice of deployment location and date, making it one of the difficulties most easily addressed. Furthermore, while there is some effect of temperature, the sensitivity is not overly remarkable, and lab-based adsorption studies performed under ambient conditions will not vary dramatically based on modest changes in room temperature. Nevertheless, adsorbent design will be optimized when uranium binding is exothermic, allowing for deployment below the oceanic phototrophic layer or at reduced temperatures to suppress the rate of biofouling.

elements.content: Accurate, reproducible quantification of uranium concentrations in seawater is significantly more difficult than in simplistic uranium-spiked brines. For the latter, various avenues for quantitation are available, including spectrometric detection by chelation of free uranium using the Arsenazo III dye, allowing facile analysis by UV–vis spectroscopy. Such an approach can afford a reasonably accurate measure of uranium remaining in solution, but is also known to bind Ca2+, preventing its use in environmental seawater or representative simulants. The complex matrix effects resulting from a large amount of total dissolved solids (TDS) in seawater further compounds problems, requiring dilution (either of matrix or in plasma) or sample preconcentration with seawater matrix elimination. For the latter, several publications have indicated metal recovery from seawater of approximately 67%, 80–107%, and above 90%, as analyzed by electrothermal atomic absorption spectrometry, graphite-furnace atomic absorption spectrometry, and inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry, respectively. In these approaches, seawater samples were preconcentrated by reductive precipitation with a mixture of sodium borohydride with iron and palladium. The precipitate was collected and dissolved with nitric acid for analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Analytical Considerations

Accurate, reproducible quantification of uranium concentrations in seawater is significantly more difficult than in simplistic uranium-spiked brines. For the latter, various avenues for quantitation are available, including spectrometric detection by chelation of free uranium using the Arsenazo III dye, allowing facile analysis by UV-vis spectroscopy. Such an approach can afford a reasonably accurate measure of uranium remaining in solution, but is also known to bind Ca2+, preventing its use in environmental seawater or representative simulants. The complex matrix effects resulting from a large amount of total dissolved solids (TDS) in seawater further compounds problems, requiring dilution (either of matrix or in plasma) or sample preconcentration with seawater matrix elimination. For the latter, several publications have indicated metal recovery from seawater of approximately 67%, 80-107%, and above 90%, as analyzed by electrothermal atomic absorption spectrometry, graphite-furnace atomic absorption spectrometry, and inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry, respectively. In these approaches, seawater samples were preconcentrated by reductive precipitation with a mixture of sodium borohydride with iron and palladium. The precipitate was collected and dissolved with nitric acid for analysis.

elements.content: In contrast, simple dilution of the matrix can afford more reproducible and accurate measurements, but requires use of an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) to achieve the necessary limits of detection. Recent work articulates this approach, diluting seawater 20× in DI water and implementing standard addition calibration to match the matrix of the standards to the samples. When used to analyze standard reference material as a quality control, the uranium recovery ranged from 93–99% for 15 replicates, while recovery of uranium-spiked seawater samples ranged from 93–109% for seven replicates. The analytical approach is clearly articulated in the aforementioned work, and constitutes a robust and validated method for quantifying trace concentrations of uranium in high TDS matrixes. Alternative methods are also available for using online preconcentrating chelating ion exchange resins have also been reported. Finally, a very recent publication compares eight different methods for quantifying uranium in seawater, revealing the method of standard addition calibration (discussed above) and offline preconcentration with an ion-exchange resin afford the most accurate and reproducible results. The previously discussed reductive precipitation method was one of the least effective methods and produced results consistent with direct analysis of environmental seawater.

Alternative methods are also available for using online preconcentrating chelating ion exchange resins have also been reported. elements.content: Performing realistic studies to assess material performance for seawater uranium recovery is inherently difficult. Ideal studies will involve deployment in the open ocean or utilize continuously replenished environmental seawater in order to achieve the most accurate data. However, access to such capabilities is rare, expensive, and generally unreasonable for independent research groups. Batch contact with seawater provides a more feasible option, but the large volume required to achieve an appreciable quantity of uranium presents a different challenge, as does the analytical rigor necessary for reproducibly accurate and precise quantification. Adequate seawater simulants are available in the literature, which afford environmentally relevant pH, ionic strength, uranium concentration, and competing trace metals. While alleviating some of the difficulties, the low uranium concentration nevertheless retains the analytical and volumetric challenges discussed above. At the bare minimum, consideration of appropriate pH and ionic strength are essential for any degree of relevance. Temperature, salinity, and biofouling also affect adsorbent performance, often through both direct and indirect avenues, and while temperature can be easily controlled in laboratory settings, the influence of biofouling cannot be readily separated from some form of marine testing.
elements.clean_text:
Summary of Challenges

Performing realistic studies to assess material performance for seawater uranium recovery is inherently difficult. Ideal studies will involve deployment in the open ocean or utilize continuously replenished environmental seawater in order to achieve the most accurate data. However, access to such capabilities is rare, expensive, and generally unreasonable for independent research groups. Batch contact with seawater provides a more feasible option, but the large volume required to achieve an appreciable quantity of uranium presents a different challenge, as does the analytical rigor necessary for reproducibly accurate and precise quantification. Adequate seawater simulants are available in the literature, which afford environmentally relevant pH, ionic strength, uranium concentration, and competing trace metals. While alleviating some of the difficulties, the low uranium concentration nevertheless retains the analytical and volumetric challenges discussed above. At the bare minimum, consideration of appropriate pH and ionic strength are essential for any degree of relevance. Temperature, salinity, and biofouling also affect adsorbent performance, often through both direct and indirect avenues, and while temperature can be easily controlled in laboratory settings, the influence of biofouling cannot be readily separated from some form of marine testing.

elements.content: Inorganic adsorbents were early extractants for uranium adsorption dating back to the 1960s, due to low cost, high surface area, tunable pore structure, and easy preparation. The inorganic adsorbent research in that time is mainly focused on hydroxides; oxides; and sulfides of metals such as titanium, aluminum, and magnesium. Among all of the tested adsorbents, hydrous titania has given the best results. The highest uranium adsorption capacity for a hydrous titania reported was 1.2 mg of uranium/g of titanium (0.58 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent). However, due to the poor selectivity, durability, and deployment challenges, the metal oxides were abandoned for more selective organic-based sorbents such as chelation polymers. More recently, the research on inorganic adsorbents has primarily focused on porous silica as a support or as an organo-silica hybrid where the silica is impregnated with organic chelation ligands. The silica research will be discussed more within due to the nanostructured porosity present; however, it is important to note the instability of silicas under basic conditions, which may mitigate large- scale use within the oceanic environment. Nevertheless, several inorganic materials have recently been reported which display particular innovation and hold promise as potential “game-changing” technologies in the field of uranyl extraction.
elements.clean_text:
Inorganic Adsorbents

Inorganic adsorbents were early extractants for uranium adsorption dating back to the 1960s, due to low cost, high surface area, tunable pore structure, and easy preparation. The inorganic adsorbent research in that time is mainly focused on hydroxides; oxides; and sulfides of metals such as titanium, aluminum, and magnesium. Among all of the tested adsorbents, hydrous titania has given the best results. The highest uranium adsorption capacity for a hydrous titania reported was 1.2 mg of uranium/g of titanium (0.58 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent). However, due to the poor selectivity, durability, and deployment challenges, the metal oxides were abandoned for more selective organic-based sorbents such as chelation polymers. More recently, the research on inorganic adsorbents has primarily focused on porous silica as a support or as an organo-silica hybrid where the silica is impregnated with organic chelation ligands. The silica research will be discussed more within  due to the nanostructured porosity present; however, it is important to note the instability of silicas under basic conditions, which may mitigate large- scale use within the oceanic environment. Nevertheless, several inorganic materials have recently been reported which display particular innovation and hold promise as potential "game-changing" technologies in the field of uranyl extraction.

elements.content: Recent work has been published by the Kanatzidis group regarding the use of sulfide-functionalized ion exchangers for the extraction of uranyl from seawater. A previously reported K2MnSn2S6 (KMS-1) was deployed in various water sources, including environmental sources from Lake Michigan and the Gulf of Mexico. Upon contact with uranyl-containing solutions, the K+ ions exchange for uranyl which locate in the interlayer space, based upon analysis of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data. Based on the change in interlayer spacing and the difference in diameters between UO2 2+ and K+, it was proposed the dehydrated uranyl cation intercalates parallel to the KMS-1 planes (). Even in high concentrations of competing ions such as Na+, Mg2+, Ca2+, and K+, in the environmental samples, KMS-1 was able to extract between 75–99% of the uranyl in solution when added at a phase ratio of 10–20 g L–1 over 12 h contact time. A saturation capacity of 380 mg g–1 was determined from a sorption isotherm obtained in deionized water with no pH adjustment or measurement. While these preliminary results are exciting and the materials merit further study, the phase ratios reported are more than 3 orders of magnitude beyond what is achievable in practical application.
elements.clean_text:
Layered Metal Sulfides or Polysulfide-Intercalated Layered Hydroxides

elements.content: A very recent report from the same group depicts use of polysulfide/layered double hydroxide composite materials for uranyl sequestration. When added at a reasonable phase ratio of 1 g L–1, the layered double hydroxide materials were able to extract 96–99% of uranium from deionized water, achieving a sorption capacity of 330 mg g–1. While significant variation in initial pH values for isotherm solutions adds uncertainty the accuracy of this number, the results are impressive nevertheless. Distribution coefficients (K d) as high as 3.4 × 106 were achieved, which are competitive with the best inorganic uranium sorbents reported in the literature. These results were decreased by 1–2 orders of magnitude upon addition of Ca2+ and Na+ but remain among the best literature results for uranyl extraction. The authors subsequently investigated these materials for extracting uranium from environmental seawater from near Tianjin City, China. The report that 78% of uranium was removed over 24 h would suggest rapid kinetics and great promise as an adsorbent material. However, a close reading reveals adsorbents were added at a phase ratio of 15 g L–1 for this experiment. Furthermore, control experiments reveal the concentration of uranium in this seawater exceeded 9 ppb, more than 2.5× the concentration of uranium typically anticipated under open ocean conditions. External validation of the performance for this material is essential, in particular when deployed at a reasonable phase ratio and in environmentally relevant uranium concentrations.

elements.content: A Mg–Co layered double hydroxide (LDH) possessing hierarchical structuring was synthesized from a sacrificial zeolite-imidizole framework (ZIF) template, which doubled as the Co source. Mg­(NO3)2 was added to the ZIF-67 template in an aqueous/ethanolic system, promoting growth of nanosheets on the facets of the template and ultimately affording hollow rhombic dodecahedron structures (). These adsorbents were contacted with a brine screening solution at a phase ratio of 0.5 g L–1 for 3 h contact time. Isothermal investigations revealed pH 5 is optimal for uranium recovery, with saturation greater than 850 mg of uranium g–1 achievable at high uranium concentrations. When contacted with a brine solution containing an environmentally appropriate 3 ppb uranium concentration, an uptake of 0.006 mg of uranium g–1 was achieved. This uptake increased up to 0.4 mg of uranium g–1 when contacted with a brine solution possessing 200 ppb uranium concentration.

elements.content: A series of chalcogel sorbents were investigated for capture of 99Tc, 238U, and gaseous I2, as sorbents for environmental remediation of radionuclides. These interesting materials contained compositions of Co0.7Bi0.3MoS4, Co0.7Cr0.3MoS4, Co0.5Ni0.5MoS4, PtGe2S5, and Sn2S3 and are prepared by chemically reacting chalcogenide clusters with interlinking metal ions in solvent and then allowing gelation to occur over several weeks. Following gelation, the materials were aged 1–3 days in ethanolic solutions, before washing with supercritical CO2 and mild heating.
elements.clean_text:
Chalcogel Sorbents

A series of chalcogel sorbents were investigated for capture of 99Tc, 238U, and gaseous I2, as sorbents for environmental remediation of radionuclides. These interesting materials contained compositions of Co0.7Bi0.3MoS4, Co0.7Cr0.3MoS4, Co0.5Ni0.5MoS4, PtGe2S5, and Sn2S3 and are prepared by chemically reacting chalcogenide clusters with interlinking metal ions in solvent and then allowing gelation to occur over several weeks. Following gelation, the materials were aged 1-3 days in ethanolic solutions, before washing with supercritical CO2 and mild heating.

elements.content: The sorbents were investigated for 99Tc and 238U sorption at a phase ratio of 50–100 g L–1 in deionized water for 1 week, with radionuclide removal ranging from 57–98% for 99Tc and 68–99% for 238U. Sorption of iodine was measured by flowing gaseous I2 over a sorbent bed at 125 °C. All chalcogel materials bound >99% of all iodine, as determined by ICP-MS of a 0.1 M NaOH solution through which chalcogel-filtered gas was bubbled. The ability to process these chalcogels into monolithic materials makes them a potentially useful technology for uranyl extraction from seawater; however, the use of expensive, rare, and toxic metals limits their applicability in current form. Furthermore, external validation must be performed, as the current report only discusses performance when deployed at phase ratios which are untenable for environmental conditions and large-scale deployment.

elements.content: Gamma-Al2O3 nanosheets were prepared by hydrothermal synthesis in the presence of supercritical CO2 and tested for their performance in extracting uranium from aqueous solutions. Al­(NO3)3 and urea were dissolved in deioinized water and subsequently pressurized with CO2 to 9 MPa, beyond the CO2 critical pressure of 7.38 MPa. This system was heated at 160 °C for 24 h and the resulting precipitate further calcined at 500 °C for 4 h after thorough washing. The material forms irregular nanosheets, similar in morphology to the boehmite precursor. Detailed time-dependent microscopy studies were performed to investigate the formation process, with the authors proposing a mechanism including quick nucleation resulting from Al3+ hydrolysis followed by gradual crystallization and agglomeration. The supercritical CO2 promoted exfoliation of the disordered sheets, while the calcination removed residual H2O and CO3 2– to form the hierarchically porous alumina. The synthetic process is summarized in .

Metal Oxides and Phosphates

Detailed time-dependent microscopy studies were performed to investigate the formation process, with the authors proposing a mechanism including quick nucleation resulting from Al3+ hydrolysis followed by gradual crystallization and agglomeration. The supercritical CO2 promoted exfoliation of the disordered sheets, while the calcination removed residual H2O and CO3 2- to form the hierarchically porous alumina. The synthetic process is summarized in .

elements.content: Uranium uptake studies reveal optimal performance is achieved at pH 5 in a 25 ppm uranium solution, while approximately 90% of the uranium is recovered at pH 8, affording an uptake of 4.5 mg of uranium g–1. The material saturation capacity was investigated through an isotherm, but a modest maximum uptake of approximately 10 mg g–1 was observed. Comparatively poor performance at acidic pH was ascribed to competition of the uranium with the proton in solution, suggesting an ion exchange mechanism and anticipation of poor performance in solutions with high ionic strength, such as seawater.
elements.clean_text: Uranium uptake studies reveal optimal performance is achieved at pH 5 in a 25 ppm uranium solution, while approximately 90% of the uranium is recovered at pH 8, affording an uptake of 4.5 mg of uranium g-1. The material saturation capacity was investigated through an isotherm, but a modest maximum uptake of approximately 10 mg g-1 was observed. Comparatively poor performance at acidic pH was ascribed to competition of the uranium with the proton in solution, suggesting an ion exchange mechanism and anticipation of poor performance in solutions with high ionic strength, such as seawater.

elements.content: An inorganic/organic composite, zirconyl-molybdopyrophosphate-tributyl phosphate (ZMPP-TBP), was prepared by coprecipitation of sodium molybdate and potassium pyrophosphate with zirconyl oxychloride. While a maximum uptake was observed at pH 6, there was minimal performance variation across a wide pH range, and >99% of the uranium was recovered from a 5 ppm aqueous solution when contacted at a 1 g L–1 phase ratio. Inclusion of various mono- or divalent cations (Zn2+, Na+, Ca2+, and Mg2+) or carbonate effected a < 5% decrease in uranium uptake, suggesting promising performance in complex matrixes. The saturation isotherm was also obtained, yielding a maximum capacity of 196 mg of uranium g–1 and achieving equilibrium in 80 min. In contrast to most adsorbents, variable temperature investigations with ZMPP-TBP reveal uranium uptake is inversely related to temperature. A negative Gibbs free energy for uranyl complexation was experimentally determined, demonstrating adsorption to be a spontaneous reaction, while the inverse relationship with temperature attests to a enthalpically driven process. Finally, the uranium could be easily eluted with dilute HCl and the material recycled up to four-times with negligible loss of performance. Although not investigated directly for recovery of uranium from seawater or an appropriate brine, the performance is promising and may merit further investigation.
