elements.content: Several magnetic inorganic adsorbents have also been reported of recent for uranium recovery from seawater. A magnetic cobalt ferrite/multiwalled carbon nanotube (CoFe2O4/MWCNT) system was investigated for uranium extraction from several aqueous solutions. When contacted at a phase ratio of 0.4 g L–1 in a 50 ppm uranium solution, a strong pH dependence was observed, with a maximum uptake of 212.7 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent reported at pH 6. When the pH increased to 8, a 33% decrease in performance was reported. Experiments performed in solutions containing alkaline and alkali earth cations reveal preferential uptake of uranium.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Adsorbents

Several magnetic inorganic adsorbents have also been reported of recent for uranium recovery from seawater. A magnetic cobalt ferrite/multiwalled carbon nanotube (CoFe2O4/MWCNT) system was investigated for uranium extraction from several aqueous solutions. When contacted at a phase ratio of 0.4 g L-1 in a 50 ppm uranium solution, a strong pH dependence was observed, with a maximum uptake of 212.7 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent reported at pH 6. When the pH increased to 8, a 33% decrease in performance was reported. Experiments performed in solutions containing alkaline and alkali earth cations reveal preferential uptake of uranium.

elements.content: Later work articulated the use of zerovalent iron nanocomposites, surface functionalized with AN and subsequently converted to amidoxime. When used to recover uranium from aqueous solutions, a maximum uptake was achieved at pH 5. Increasing ionic strength up to 0.5 M NaCl results in a decrease of adsorption at lower pH, but no decrease from pure aqueous solutions were observed at pH 6 or 7. Investigation of the uranium-contacted material by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) reveals a shoulder in the uranium 4f spectrum, indicative of partial reduction from U­(VI) to U­(IV), an oxidation state of uranium known to be much less soluble in water and part of the driving force for uranium binding. A saturation capacity of 206 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved at pH 5 by application of an adsorption isotherm.
elements.clean_text: Later work articulated the use of zerovalent iron nanocomposites, surface functionalized with AN and subsequently converted to amidoxime. When used to recover uranium from aqueous solutions, a maximum uptake was achieved at pH 5. Increasing ionic strength up to 0.5 M NaCl results in a decrease of adsorption at lower pH, but no decrease from pure aqueous solutions were observed at pH 6 or 7. Investigation of the uranium-contacted material by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) reveals a shoulder in the uranium 4f spectrum, indicative of partial reduction from U(VI) to U(IV), an oxidation state of uranium known to be much less soluble in water and part of the driving force for uranium binding. A saturation capacity of 206 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved at pH 5 by application of an adsorption isotherm.

elements.content: Nevertheless, while promising performance has been observed for magnetic adsorbent materials, from the perspective of practical uranium recovery from seawater they can be little more than an academic curiosity. Uncontrolled deployment at scales necessary for significant uranium recovery could not be accommodated biologically, or with regards to subsequent collection from the open ocean, while integration in some form of support or monolith defeats the purpose of being magnetic. These materials are not anticipated to be of significant practical use for the recovery of uranium from seawater.

elements.content: Renewed interest in development of inorganic adsorbents for extraction of uranium from seawater has resulted in several new materials which display promising uptake under idealized conditions, with a summary of material performance provided in . Unfortunately, deployment concentrations for some of these materials range from 10–100 g L–1, which are unacceptably high phase ratios to achieve suitable performance in environmental matrixes. In contrast, advanced polymer adsorbents, vide infra, are can achieve comparable performance when deployed at only 0.015 g L–1, a phase ratio approximately 3 orders of magnitude smaller than the best inorganic adsorbent discussed previously.
elements.clean_text:
Summary and Perspectives

Renewed interest in development of inorganic adsorbents for extraction of uranium from seawater has resulted in several new materials which display promising uptake under idealized conditions, with a summary of material performance provided in . Unfortunately, deployment concentrations for some of these materials range from 10-100 g L-1, which are unacceptably high phase ratios to achieve suitable performance in environmental matrixes. In contrast, advanced polymer adsorbents, vide infra, are can achieve comparable performance when deployed at only 0.015 g L-1, a phase ratio approximately 3 orders of magnitude smaller than the best inorganic adsorbent discussed previously.

Deployment issues also present a challenge for the aforementioned inorganic materials. While unbound powders are suitable for lab-scale investigation, the processing necessary to enable deployment often undermines the very properties that engender favorable uptake. While chalcogels mitigate this problem by forming comparatively large monoliths, the necessity of toxic, expensive, and rare metals makes them prohibitive from safety and cost perspectives. It is worth recalling that inorganic materials, including metal sulfides, were extensively investigated and subsequently abandoned after two decades of research. Although the work discussed above reveal some interesting materials, extensive continued effort in this direction is not anticipated to afford materials suitable for practical implementation.

elements.content: Polymeric adsorbents comprise the category of material which is closest to feasible large-scale deployment, due in large part to pioneering work from Japan and Turkey in the 1980s and 1990s. As discussed previously, several in-field deployment investigations of advanced polymer-based adsorbents have been performed by research programs of various nations, further demonstrating proof of concept for such materials and affording them the highest technology readiness level of all proposed seawater uranium adsorbents. Traditional materials have been prepared by graft polymerization from a polyolefin support, such as polyethylene fibers or a polypropylene unwoven fiber mat. Advantages afforded by this approach include scalability, economical material costs, versatility in graft chain functionalities, and the diversity of form factors available for a support. However, fundamental challenges remain regarding the direct investigation of graft chain molecular structure and positive identification of the uranyl binding environment. Moreover, hydrophilicity and salinity influence graft chain structure, putatively resulting in interesting morphological phenomena which remain largely uninvestigated.
elements.clean_text:
Synthetic Polymers

Polymeric adsorbents comprise the category of material which is closest to feasible large-scale deployment, due in large part to pioneering work from Japan and Turkey in the 1980s and 1990s. As discussed previously, several in-field deployment investigations of advanced polymer-based adsorbents have been performed by research programs of various nations, further demonstrating proof of concept for such materials and affording them the highest technology readiness level of all proposed seawater uranium adsorbents. Traditional materials have been prepared by graft polymerization from a polyolefin support, such as polyethylene fibers or a polypropylene unwoven fiber mat. Advantages afforded by this approach include scalability, economical material costs, versatility in graft chain functionalities, and the diversity of form factors available for a support. However, fundamental challenges remain regarding the direct investigation of graft chain molecular structure and positive identification of the uranyl binding environment. Moreover, hydrophilicity and salinity influence graft chain structure, putatively resulting in interesting morphological phenomena which remain largely uninvestigated.

elements.content: This section begins by discussing the synthesis of amidoxime, amidoxime-containing polymers, and derivatives of amidoxime, including recent investigations on how amidoxime binds uranyl. While other ligands have been proposed and investigated for uranium recovery, amidoxime-derived adsorbents nevertheless overwhelmingly predominate. Next, we discuss the polymerization techniques and resulting materials that have been investigated for seawater uranium recovery. A section discussing the rational design and synthesis of uranyl chelating ligands follows, including alternative methods for incorporating these well-designed chelators onto polymer-based adsorbents. Finally, this section concludes with a brief summary and outlook regarding polymer based adsorbents.

elements.content: The amidoxime functionality shows favorable binding for the uranyl ion, thus making it the preferred choice for the development of uranium adsorbent materials. However, to produce these materials on a scale capable of economical extraction, this uranium binding moiety must be synthesized through fast, efficient, and high yielding techniques. While there are a number of synthetic methods for the production of amidoximes (see reviews in refs and references therein for broader synthetic scope), the approach most commonly utilized involves conversion of a nitrile into the desired amidoxime product by treatment with hydroxylamine. This method is generally performed at moderate temperatures (60–80 °C) and in common solvents, such as water and alcohols, for times ranging from a few hours to a few days. This approach to amidoxime formation is largely unchanged from the pioneering work performed by Egawa and colleagues around 1980.
elements.clean_text:
Poly(amidoxime) and Derivatives

Traditional Preparation of Poly(Amidoxime)

The amidoxime functionality shows favorable binding for the uranyl ion, thus making it the preferred choice for the development of uranium adsorbent materials. However, to produce these materials on a scale capable of economical extraction, this uranium binding moiety must be synthesized through fast, efficient, and high yielding techniques. While there are a number of synthetic methods for the production of amidoximes (see reviews in refs  and references therein for broader synthetic scope), the approach most commonly utilized involves conversion of a nitrile into the desired amidoxime product by treatment with hydroxylamine. This method is generally performed at moderate temperatures (60-80 °C) and in common solvents, such as water and alcohols, for times ranging from a few hours to a few days. This approach to amidoxime formation is largely unchanged from the pioneering work performed by Egawa and colleagues around 1980.

elements.content: Nucleophilic attack by the nitrogen lone pair of hydroxylamine results in formation of an imino hydroxylamine tautomer which exists in dynamic equilibrium with the desired amidoxime (). While in the imino tautomer, free rotation of the hydroxylamine about the σ-bond will result in preferential adoption of either E- or Z-conformer upon formation of the amidoxime as a function of the electronic structure and relative steric bulk of the R-group.

elements.content: Witte and colleagues were the first to report small molecule uranyl-amidoxime complexes, as investigated through X-ray crystallography. To prepare uranyl acetamidoxime, uranyl nitrate was dissolved in an ethanolic solution at 50 °C, to which 10 equiv of acetamidoxime were added. Yellow crystals were precipitated by the addition of diethyl ether. Similarly, uranyl benzamidoxime was prepared by addition of 4 equiv of benzamidoxime to an ethanolic solution of uranyl nitrate at 50 °C. Orange-yellow crystals were obtained by recrystallization from hot nitromethane. Both complexes revealed monodentate coordination by four ligands through the oxime oxygen (, top), influencing the proposed motif for uranyl coordination for the next two decades.
elements.clean_text:
Identification of How Amidoxime Binds Uranyl

Witte and colleagues were the first to report small molecule uranyl-amidoxime complexes, as investigated through X-ray crystallography. To prepare uranyl acetamidoxime, uranyl nitrate was dissolved in an ethanolic solution at 50 °C, to which 10 equiv of acetamidoxime were added. Yellow crystals were precipitated by the addition of diethyl ether. Similarly, uranyl benzamidoxime was prepared by addition of 4 equiv of benzamidoxime to an ethanolic solution of uranyl nitrate at 50 °C. Orange-yellow crystals were obtained by recrystallization from hot nitromethane. Both complexes revealed monodentate coordination by four ligands through the oxime oxygen (, top), influencing the proposed motif for uranyl coordination for the next two decades.

elements.content: While the crystal structures were solved, slight disorder of acetamidoxime and benzamidoxime residues did not accommodate location of H atoms. Though short bond lengths suggested an anionic ligand with resonance contributions, it was not definitive whether the oxime had been deprotonated or whether tautomerization via H atom transfer to the oxime nitrogen had occurred. Subsequent potentiometric studies with both acetamidoxime and benzamidoxime revealed deprotonation of the oxime did occur prior to uranyl chelation, forming charge-neutral bis-amidoximato uranyl complexes. Presumably influenced by the early crystallographic data, researchers proposed binding motifs involving four amidoxime ligands coordinating in a monodentate fashion through the oxime oxygen, with charge balance achieved through deprotonation of two ligands. Others have promoted a chelating interaction between oxime oxygen and amide nitrogen. These motifs are summarized in .

Presumably influenced by the early crystallographic data, researchers proposed binding motifs involving four amidoxime ligands coordinating in a monodentate fashion through the oxime oxygen, with charge balance achieved through deprotonation of two ligands. Others have promoted a chelating interaction between oxime oxygen and amide nitrogen. These motifs are summarized in .

elements.content: In an effort to conclusively identify the binding motif for uranyl-amidoximate complexes, Vukovic and colleagues utilized a complementary approach combining DFT calculations with small molecule crystallographic studies and investigation of the Cambridge Structural Database. In this seminal work, DFT calculations were performed to evaluate the geometries and relative stabilities of proposed bonding motifs for a series of uranyl acetamidoxime (AO) complexes (). The authors report DFT calculations in structures I, II, and III achieved local minima, though attempts to optimize IV were unsuccessful, instead yielding III. The relative stabilities were compared for 1, 2, and 3 coordinating ligands, with the remainder of the equatorial coordination sphere filled by individual aqua ligands. Representative geometries are displayed in . For calculations performed both for solvent and gas phase formalisms, the η2 motif, III, was observed to be the most stable, albeit frequently by less than 3 kcal mol–1.

elements.content: More recently, high level coupled-cluster CCSD­(T)/aug-cc-pVDZ calculations were used to investigate the potential binding motifs of uranyl complexes with formamidoxime ligands, as this molecule is small enough that high-level ab initio calculations can be readily performed. Relative energies obtained from CCSD­(T) calculations were used as benchmarks against DFT and MP2 predicted energies. The most stable five- and six-coordinate B3LYP geometries of the uranyl complexes with 1–3 ligands involving η2-binding with the N–O bond and chelation through the oxime oxygen and amine nitrogen donor atoms are shown in . Consistent with previous DFT calculations and X-ray diffraction data, the η2-binding motif is the most stable at the B3LYP and MP2 levels for all amidoxime complexes; however, analysis of the relative stabilities of uranyl complexes with amidoxime reveals that the difference in the stability of the η2 and chelate binding motifs is smaller than previously thought. After application of higher order correlations estimated at the coupled-cluster theory, differences of 0–2 kcal mol–1 were observed between motifs II and III, suggesting both forms would coexist in thermodynamic equilibrium in aqueous solution. Moreover, a five-coordinate 1:2 uranyl complex with mixed coordination of the two ligands is slightly more stable than that with pure η2-coordination at the CCSD­(T) level (). These two motifs are effectively isoenergetic, suggesting the structure of the adsorbent and orientation of functions upon uranyl binding are likely to be the dominant factors in determining how uranyl is bound on an adsorbent polymer.

elements.content: Crystal structures obtained for UO2(acetamidoxime)2(MeOH)2 and the related UO2(benzamidoxime)2(MeOH)2 display the η2-coordination proposed in the preliminary study, while investigation of the Cambridge Structural Database reveals all known uranyl-oximate complexes adopt an identical coordination motif. Reported almost simultaneously, a uranyl bound by an amidoxime-functionalized imidizolidine also displayed an η2-coordination motif. Recently, studies on related 2-pyridyl ketoximes have also been pursued in an effort to better understand the fundamentals of uranyl binding. Similar to the aforementioned studies on acetamidoxime and benzamidoxime, methyl pyridyl ketoxime binds in an η2-configuration as determined through crystallographic studies. However, a dinuclear molecule displaying a κ2-binding mode and a peroxo bridge, [(UO2)2(O2)­(OAc)2(L)2] (where L = methyl 2-pyridyl ketoxime), is obtained when crystallized from methanol in direct sunlight and layered with diethyl ether and n-hexane (). The authors propose formation of the peroxide through a photochemical process whereby UO2 2+ is excited, reduced to UVO2 +, and subsequently re-oxidized to UO2 2+ forming H2O2 in the process. Similar multinuclear uranyl complexes were observed during crystallization of glutardiamidoxime with UO2(NO3)2, where the metal nitrate induced in situ cyclization of the ligand to form a bridged dinuclear species (). While DFT and small molecule results are consistent with each other, it is worth noting they are performed under idealized conditions and may not be representative of a complex and dynamic system, as is the case for a polymer adsorbent deployed in seawater.

elements.content: To further understand the amidoxime ligand, other simple amidoxime species were also studied computationally. Theoretical calculations were performed to elucidate the structure and relative stability of uranyl complexes with acetamidoxime and benzamidoxime. The most stable geometries of the uranyl complexes with one and two ligands obtained at the M06/SSC/6-311++G­(d,p) level of theory are shown in . Consistent with previous calculations and X-ray diffraction data, the η2 binding with the N–O oximate bond to uranyl is the energetically preferred coordination mode for all amidoxime complexes. As was observed previously, the most stable structural configuration for 1:1 uranyl complexes with mono and bidentate donor ligands was solely five-coordinate. In contrast, the solid-state configurations of 1:2 uranyl complexes with acetamidoxime and benzamidoxime attained the coordination number six by having two solvent molecules (CH3OH) in the equatorial plane. Theoretical calculations (M06 and SMD) were used to determine the most stable coordination environment in aqueous solution, with comparison of relative stabilities between one and two solvent molecules being ≤1 kcal mol–1 and indicating both forms likely coexist in thermodynamic equilibrium in solution.

elements.content: Due to the strong nucleophilic nature of hydroxylamine, several side reactions may occur. Aldehydes and ketones can be converted to oximes, and carboxylic acids can react to form hydroxamic acid. Although the original carbonyl compound can be restored upon treatment with acid, functional group stability must nevertheless be considered in adsorbent design. In addition to reacting with non-nitrile functional groups, important side reactions involving the amidoxime can also occur, most notably, cyclization of adjacent amidoximes to form a cyclic imidedioxime.
elements.clean_text:
Cyclic Imidedioxime Functionality

Due to the strong nucleophilic nature of hydroxylamine, several side reactions may occur. Aldehydes and ketones can be converted to oximes, and carboxylic acids can react to form hydroxamic acid. Although the original carbonyl compound can be restored upon treatment with acid, functional group stability must nevertheless be considered in adsorbent design. In addition to reacting with non-nitrile functional groups, important side reactions involving the amidoxime can also occur, most notably, cyclization of adjacent amidoximes to form a cyclic imidedioxime.

elements.content: Astheimer and colleagues were the first to report the generation of the cyclic imidedioxime functionality, determining “uptake of uranium from natural seawater is closely related to the presence of cyclic imidoxime [sic] configurations” from their investigation of cross-linked poly­(amidoxime) resins. Importantly, they indicate adsorbent elution as being a critical component of seawater uranium recovery and identify the acid-instability of the cyclic imidedioxime functionality as responsible for the degradation of performance following multiple recycles. Nevertheless, while providing this definitive statement, close inspection of the reported data reveal significant ambiguity and the following conclusion: “The comparative investigation of amidoxime and imide dioxime [sic] resins identified the cyclic imidoxime [sic] structures as being responsible for the observed instability of poly­(acrylamidoximes) in dilute acids, but allowed no discrimination to be made between open-chain amidoxime and cyclic imidedoxime [sic] groups with respect to uranium uptake from natural seawater”.
elements.clean_text: Astheimer and colleagues were the first to report the generation of the cyclic imidedioxime functionality, determining "uptake of uranium from natural seawater is closely related to the presence of cyclic imidoxime [sic] configurations" from their investigation of cross-linked poly(amidoxime) resins. Importantly, they indicate adsorbent elution as being a critical component of seawater uranium recovery and identify the acid-instability of the cyclic imidedioxime functionality as responsible for the degradation of performance following multiple recycles. Nevertheless, while providing this definitive statement, close inspection of the reported data reveal significant ambiguity and the following conclusion: "The comparative investigation of amidoxime and imide dioxime [sic] resins identified the cyclic imidoxime [sic] structures as being responsible for the observed instability of poly(acrylamidoximes) in dilute acids, but allowed no discrimination to be made between open-chain amidoxime and cyclic imidedoxime [sic] groups with respect to uranium uptake from natural seawater".

elements.content: Rao and colleagues performed thermochemical titrations of uranium binding to small molecule analogues of the open-chain and cyclic imidedioxime binding sites, proposed by Astheimer. Glutaronitrile was contacted with hydroxylamine at different temperatures and for different times to afford the cyclic analogue, glutarimidedioxime (H2A), and the open-chain analogue, glutardiamidoxime (H2B), as displayed in . Following a thorough investigation of uranyl binding by H2A, including computational studies, crystallography, as well as both spectrophotometric and potentiometric titrations, they determined not only was binding strongly favored but that the H2A ligand when present at concentrations roughly analogous to seawater-deployed polymers was competitive with carbonate for uranium binding. While binding by the open-chain H2B molecule was also determined to be thermodynamically favored, they concluded it was not capable of competing with environmental carbonate for uranium recovery, nor was a partial hydrolysis product of H2A, glutarimidoxioxime.

elements.content: Work by Hay and colleagues provided further insight into cyclic imidedioximes, resolving three fundamental characteristics involving (1) conditions that maximize conversion of adjacent nitriles to cyclic imidedioxime, (2) whether base-conditioning results in cyclic imidedioxime formation, and (3) conditions under which cyclic imidedioxime functionalities would hydrolyze. They noted that the relative synthetic yields of open-chain vs cyclic functionalities was a condition of reaction temperature, reporting that the complete transformation of glutaronitrile to H2A was achieved in just 3 h at 130 °C (). Accordingly, treatment of poly­(AN) with hydroxylamine at elevated temperatures is the most straightforward avenue for generating a maximum amount of cyclic imidedioxime sites. When glutarimidedioxime was investigated under basic conditions, glutarate was formed with no appreciable generation of H2A observed. Similarly, exposure of H2B to 1 M NaOD at various temperatures also afforded glutarate as the sole reaction product (). Finally, investigation of H2A and H2B under acidic conditions revealed that, while the open-chain H2B was stable in 1 M DCl for several months at room temperature, H2A degraded rapidly through a glutarimide intermediate in less than 20 h. An acid-resistant form could be produced by lowering the charge on the imino carbon, thereby slowing the nucleophilic attack of water and subsequent hydrolytic degradation. The addition of an aromatic backbone for the cyclic structure stabilized the resulting phthalimide dioxime molecule and imparted the requisite chemical stability. A general summary of cyclic imidedioxime formation and degradation is provided in .

The circled region in spectrum (b) suggests only trace formation of H2A under basic conditions. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2012, American Chemical Society.

elements.content: Recently these aforementioned studies were tested through development of adsorbents possessing maximized cyclic imidedioxime functionalities. An adsorbent polymer was formed by graft copolymerization of AN and itaconic acid from a polyethylene trunk fiber, followed by conversion of the nitrile into amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine in a water/methanol solution at 80 °C. Adsorbents were then heated at various temperatures (110–150 °C) in polar aprotic solvents to convert open-chain amidoxime groups into the desired cyclic imidedioxime functionalities. Chemical speciation was investigated by 13C cross-polarization magic angle spinning NMR spectroscopy (13C CP-MAS NMR), which suggests successful conversion of all adjacent amidoximes to the cyclic imidedioxime, consistent with the aforementioned work of Hay. An important point is that, assuming the 13C CP-MAS NMR peak characterizations are correct, treatment of poly­(AN) with hydroxylamine at comparatively mild temperatures and protic solvents results in formation of the cyclic imidedioxime functionality as the predominant species on the adsorbent, even prior to subsequent heat treatment in polar aprotic systems (). It is essential to note that previously reported 13C NMR analysis performed by Seko and colleagues identified the upfield shoulder as attributable to the cyclic imidedioxime, rather than the open-chain amidoxime (), with degradation observed upon treatment with HCl, consistent with work reported by Hay and colleagues. Such conflicting results continue to feed ongoing controversy regarding what amidoxime species is present on the adsorbent and how uranyl is actually bound.

elements.content: 13C CP-MAS NMR data of poly­(AN-co-itaconic acid) (a) before treatment with hydroxylamine, (b) after treatment with hydroxylamine in 50:50 methanol:water at 80 °C, and (c) after subsequent heating at 130 °C in DMSO. A slight shoulder is assigned to the 13C NMR signature of the open-chain amidoxime which largely disappears following heating in polar aprotic solvents, suggesting the near-complete formation of the cyclic imidedioxime functionality. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, Elsevier.

elements.content: The adsorbents were investigated for uranium uptake from an 8 ppm uranyl nitrate brine solution, also containing 193 ppm sodium bicarbonate and 25 600 ppm sodium chloride. The sample that was not heat-treated achieved an uptake of approximately 175 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while maximum uptake for samples receiving post-amidoximation heat-treatment in DMSO, DMF, and propylene carbonate achieved uptake of approximately 225, 220, and 185 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, respectively. Further investigations were performed using adsorbents heated in DMSO, which displayed more rapid uranyl-binding kinetics compared to the untreated material and improvement in recovery of uranium following 56-days of contact with seawater from Sequim Bay, WA in flow through columns. A seawater uranium recovery capacity of approximately 4.2 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved for the DMSO-treated sample, while 3.5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent were obtained for the untreated analogue. However, increases in uptake were also observed in the binding of numerous other metals present in seawater, in particular Ca, Mg, Fe, V, Mn, and Cr. Taken comprehensively, it is clear the cyclic imidedioxime plays a critical role in the performance of amidoxime-functionalized polymer adsorbents, though achieving the necessary selectivity and chemical stability for repeated use remains an elusive and highly desirable objective.

elements.content: Polymer-based materials comprise perhaps the most important category of material for uranium recovery from seawater, spanning a diverse range of compositions and forms, and the ensuing publications afford a wealth of knowledge to the disciplined reader. Nevertheless, identifying a coherent and logical format for the introduction and discussion of this volume of information is challenging, as many of the works discuss related concepts, while seemingly orthogonal synthetic techniques developed independently can dovetail with surprising ease and promising outcome. In an effort to systematically and coherently survey the pertinent literature that defines this research area, polymers are categorized and presented based on the polymerization technique used for their synthesis. Within each category, the report of new materials is arranged chronologically, but with complete development of each system presented before moving on to the next new material. Pertinent monomers are presented as figures at the beginning of each section.
elements.clean_text:
Polymerization Methods

Introduction

Polymer-based materials comprise perhaps the most important category of material for uranium recovery from seawater, spanning a diverse range of compositions and forms, and the ensuing publications afford a wealth of knowledge to the disciplined reader. Nevertheless, identifying a coherent and logical format for the introduction and discussion of this volume of information is challenging, as many of the works discuss related concepts, while seemingly orthogonal synthetic techniques developed independently can dovetail with surprising ease and promising outcome. In an effort to systematically and coherently survey the pertinent literature that defines this research area, polymers are categorized and presented based on the polymerization technique used for their synthesis. Within each category, the report of new materials is arranged chronologically, but with complete development of each system presented before moving on to the next new material. Pertinent monomers are presented as figures at the beginning of each section.

elements.content: Many different polymerization approaches have been used for the preparation of uranium adsorbents; however, RIGP has afforded the majority of materials and is the most technologically mature, while ATRP is much more recent and has provided the best-performing synthetic polymer in the literature. Materials prepared by these two techniques are covered in their own individual sections. There are also numerous adsorbents prepared by neither RIGP nor ATRP which constitute significant advances in the field and change the way polymer adsorbents are prepared or understood. Such materials are discussed in a third category, “Polymer Adsorbents Prepared by Neither RIGP Nor ATRP”, as they do not possess a common polymerization technique. While it is customary that such a category would follow sections on RIGP and ATRP, it is also where the report of the first amidoxime-functionalized polymers is categorized, and so it is the section in which this portion of the review begins.

While it is customary that such a category would follow sections on RIGP and ATRP, it is also where the report of the first amidoxime-functionalized polymers is categorized, and so it is the section in which this portion of the review begins.

elements.content: The first amidoxime-functionalized polymer-based adsorbents were prepared by thermally initiated suspension polymerization of (AN) and divinylbenzene (DVB) dissolved in toluene and dispersed in water (). As discussed above, subsequent treatment of the poly­(AN-co-DVB) with hydroxylamine generates the amidoxime (AO) functionality and the final poly­(AO-co-DVB) adsorbent. An identical polymerization approach was implemented by Hirotsu, who investigated the role of the hydrophilicity of the cross-linking comonomer on adsorbent performance. Substituting tetraethylene glycol dimethacrylate (4EGDM) for divinylbenzene resulted in an adsorbent with superior kinetics compared to poly­(AO-co-DVB). A 40-day test of the best performing poly­(AO-co-DVB) afforded an uptake of approximately 0.2 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while the poly­(AO-co-4EGDM) achieved 0.4 mg of uranium/g in only 28 days. Follow up work with poly­(AO) adsorbents cross-linked with different ratios of DVB/4EGDM revealed by X-ray microanalysis that uranium was more homogeneously distributed throughout the adsorbent as more 4EGDM was incorporated, whereas binding in the poly­(AO-co-DVB) was localized to the surface. While the DVB cross-linked adsorbent displayed the lowest capacity and slowest kinetics, the 100% 4EGDM adsorbent was only marginally better. The materials with the best kinetics were composed of different ratios of DVB/4EGDM, indicating hydrophilicity of the adsorbent is not the only consideration for effective uranium uptake. The poly­(AO-co-4EGDM) nevertheless displayed an impressive 4.5 mg of uranium/g uptake when deployed in a glass column and contacted with seawater for 180 days at 25 °C and 250 mL min–1.
elements.clean_text:
Polymer Adsorbents Prepared by Neither RIGP Nor ATRP

Suspension/Emulsion Polymerization

The first amidoxime-functionalized polymer-based adsorbents were prepared by thermally initiated suspension polymerization of (AN) and divinylbenzene (DVB) dissolved in toluene and dispersed in water (). As discussed above, subsequent treatment of the poly(AN-co-DVB) with hydroxylamine generates the amidoxime (AO) functionality and the final poly(AO-co-DVB) adsorbent. An identical polymerization approach was implemented by Hirotsu, who investigated the role of the hydrophilicity of the cross-linking comonomer on adsorbent performance. Substituting tetraethylene glycol dimethacrylate (4EGDM) for divinylbenzene resulted in an adsorbent with superior kinetics compared to poly(AO-co-DVB). A 40-day test of the best performing poly(AO-co-DVB) afforded an uptake of approximately 0.2 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while the poly(AO-co-4EGDM) achieved 0.4 mg of uranium/g in only 28 days. Follow up work with poly(AO) adsorbents cross-linked with different ratios of DVB/4EGDM revealed by X-ray microanalysis that uranium was more homogeneously distributed throughout the adsorbent as more 4EGDM was incorporated, whereas binding in the poly(AO-co-DVB) was localized to the surface. While the DVB cross-linked adsorbent displayed the lowest capacity and slowest kinetics, the 100% 4EGDM adsorbent was only marginally better. The materials with the best kinetics were composed of different ratios of DVB/4EGDM, indicating hydrophilicity of the adsorbent is not the only consideration for effective uranium uptake. The poly(AO-co-4EGDM) nevertheless displayed an impressive 4.5 mg of uranium/g uptake when deployed in a glass column and contacted with seawater for 180 days at 25 °C and 250 mL min-1.

elements.content: Morcellet and co-workers also used suspension polymerization to generate a series of porous polymers containing vinylamine units through suspension copolymerization of N-vinyl t-butyl carbamate, styrene (St), and ethylene glycol dimethacrylate, followed by postsynthetic hydrolysis of the carbamate functionality. These amines could then be chemically reacted to afford specific chelating ligands, such as iminodiacetic acid, aminophosphoric acid, thiourea, and dithiocarbamate. While capacities were not reported, X-ray microanalysis revealed uranium was bound exclusively at the surface of the beads, rather than homogeneously throughout.

These amines could then be chemically reacted to afford specific chelating ligands, such as iminodiacetic acid, aminophosphoric acid, thiourea, and dithiocarbamate. While capacities were not reported, X-ray microanalysis revealed uranium was bound exclusively at the surface of the beads, rather than homogeneously throughout.

elements.content: A St/AN copolymer was prepared by emulsion polymerization with potassium persulfate radical initiator and a sodium lauryl sulfate emulsifier. Following polymerization, the nitriles were converted to amidoxime groups. Different St:AN ratios were used to prepare materials (40:60, 30:70, 20:80), which were subsequently screened for uranium uptake from a 45 ppm solution at pH 2.2, achieving capacities as high as 0.85 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Introduction of competing metals, increasing ionic strength, or pre-exposure of the adsorbent to solutions containing 1.4 ppm chlorine reduced the performance. Nevertheless, when 35.8 L of filtered environmental seawater was passed through 2 g of adsorbent, an uptake of 0.0145 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was realized, equating to 25% the total quantity of uranium dissolved in the seawater.

Introduction of competing metals, increasing ionic strength, or pre-exposure of the adsorbent to solutions containing 1.4 ppm chlorine reduced the performance. Nevertheless, when 35.8 L of filtered environmental seawater was passed through 2 g of adsorbent, an uptake of 0.0145 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was realized, equating to 25% the total quantity of uranium dissolved in the seawater.

elements.content: Kabay reported the application of anionic polymerization to adsorbent development in the mid-90s, where methacrylonitrile was polymerized with the anionic initiators BuLi or Et2Mg. The resulting polymers possessed high molecular weight, ranging from 105 to 106 g mol–1. Upon conversion of the nitrile group to AO, pretreatment with 1 M NaOH, and subsequent neutralization, the best performing material achieved an uptake of 0.176 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent/day deployment in 5 L of natural seawater.
elements.clean_text:
Anionic Polymerization

Kabay reported the application of anionic polymerization to adsorbent development in the mid-90s, where methacrylonitrile was polymerized with the anionic initiators BuLi or Et2Mg. The resulting polymers possessed high molecular weight, ranging from 105 to 106 g mol-1. Upon conversion of the nitrile group to AO, pretreatment with 1 M NaOH, and subsequent neutralization, the best performing material achieved an uptake of 0.176 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent/day deployment in 5 L of natural seawater.

elements.content: Adsorbents composed of poly­(acrylamide-co-methylenebis­(acrylamide)) (poly­(AcA-co-MBA)) were synthesized using benzoyl peroxide as a radical initiator to generate fully water insoluble polymers (). The amides were then converted to hydroxamic acid through treatment with hydroxylamine. Different ratios of AcA:MBA were investigated, including 95:5, 85:15, and 75:25. Uranyl binding was investigated from pH 1–11, with maximum performance observed at pH 5 and 50–60% maximum performance at pH 8. The best performing material contained the smallest quantity of MBA, and higher moisture uptake was observed to correlate with higher metal uptake. A modest uranium uptake of 0.018 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent is likely attributable to the intense hydrophobicity of the adsorbent. Similar performance was reported by an insoluble cross-linked resin formed from poly­(N-(3- dimethylamino)­propylmethacrylamide), formed by radical polymerization. While the aforementioned adsorbents are unlikely to be directly applicable for seawater uranium recovery, the work does provide a good negative result corroborating the need for both hydrophilicity and appropriate uranyl-binding receptors.
elements.clean_text:
Chemically-Initiated Polymerization

Adsorbents composed of poly(acrylamide-co-methylenebis(acrylamide)) (poly(AcA-co-MBA)) were synthesized using benzoyl peroxide as a radical initiator to generate fully water insoluble polymers (). The amides were then converted to hydroxamic acid through treatment with hydroxylamine. Different ratios of AcA:MBA were investigated, including 95:5, 85:15, and 75:25. Uranyl binding was investigated from pH 1-11, with maximum performance observed at pH 5 and 50-60% maximum performance at pH 8. The best performing material contained the smallest quantity of MBA, and higher moisture uptake was observed to correlate with higher metal uptake. A modest uranium uptake of 0.018 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent is likely attributable to the intense hydrophobicity of the adsorbent. Similar performance was reported by an insoluble cross-linked resin formed from poly(N-(3- dimethylamino)propylmethacrylamide), formed by radical polymerization. While the aforementioned adsorbents are unlikely to be directly applicable for seawater uranium recovery, the work does provide a good negative result corroborating the need for both hydrophilicity and appropriate uranyl-binding receptors.

elements.content: Dipropionitrile acrylamide was polymerized through free radical polymerization by application of the chemical initiator 2,2′-azobis­(2-methylpropionitrile), more commonly known as AIBN (). Following postsynthetic conversion to the amidoxime form, the adsorbent displayed a high capacity for uranium and V over Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ competing ions. Calculation of the K d for each metal, i.e., the ratio of metal ions in the solution to the metal ions bound in the adsorbent, reveal strong selectivity for U. The K d value for uranium of nearly 2 × 105 mL g–1 was more than three times greater than that for V and more than 150× greater than the other competing ions. This selectivity was rationalized by the authors as attributable to intramolecular H-bonding promoting formation of the syn-hydroxyamino form, where metal-assisted hydroxyl deprotonation would occur prior to bonding and be governed by hard/soft acid/base theory.

elements.content: This adsorbent was investigated in seawater collected from the coast of Mutsu Sekine-Hama in the Aomori Prefecture in a recirculated column configuration at a flow rate of 6 mL min–1. After 1 h, 1 day, and 1 week of contact, the adsorbents were eluted with HCl and the uranium uptake determined, affording values of 13.1, 28.1, and 27.1 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. While these results are remarkably good, it is perplexing that such technology has not been successfully commercialized. It is suggested that the results be externally validated to confirm the performance and ensure the results are not a typographical error. In comparison to other adsorbents contacted under similar conditions, results in the μg of uranium g–1 adsorbent are more commonplace.

elements.content: Compolymers of AA, AcA, and trimethylolpropane triacrylate (TMPTA) were formed with an ammonium persulfate initiator, with the resulting nonamidoxime-functionalized adsorbents used to extract uranyl from a 5% NaCl solution. Performance was tested as a function of time, temperature, pH and ionic strength. Saponification of the polymer with NaOH afforded carboxylate groups, which are the putative uranyl-binding species in the adsorbent and also increase adsorbent hydrophilicity. The swelling of the hydrogel increased upon formation of carboxylic functionalities, though both swelling and adsorbent performance decreased when contacted with electrolytes possessing high ionic strength, such as seawater. Swelling also decreased with increasing cross-linking, afforded by a greater molar quantity of TMPTA. A maximum uranium uptake of 250 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved from contact of 0.15 g of material with 50 mL of a 502 ppm uranyl solution at pH 7.
elements.clean_text: Compolymers of AA, AcA, and trimethylolpropane triacrylate (TMPTA) were formed with an ammonium persulfate initiator, with the resulting nonamidoxime-functionalized adsorbents used to extract uranyl from a 5% NaCl solution. Performance was tested as a function of time, temperature, pH and ionic strength. Saponification of the polymer with NaOH afforded carboxylate groups, which are the putative uranyl-binding species in the adsorbent and also increase adsorbent hydrophilicity. The swelling of the hydrogel increased upon formation of carboxylic functionalities, though both swelling and adsorbent performance decreased when contacted with electrolytes possessing high ionic strength, such as seawater. Swelling also decreased with increasing cross-linking, afforded by a greater molar quantity of TMPTA. A maximum uranium uptake of 250 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved from contact of 0.15 g of material with 50 mL of a 502 ppm uranyl solution at pH 7.

elements.content: Ion-imprinted polymers (IIPs) have also been prepared through chemical polymerization. This type of material is prepared by first coordinating uranyl with chelating monomers and then polymerizing the complex followed by elution of the bound uranium (). For example, Rao and co-workers dissolved stoichiometric quantities of uranyl nitrate with select chelating ligands, including salicylaldoxime, catechol, succinic acid, 5,7-dichloroquinoline-8-ol (DCQ), and 4-vinylpyridine (VP), in 2-methoxy ethanol, followed by polymerization in the presence of 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA) and ethylene glycol-dimethacrylate (EGDMA) with an AIBN initiator (). Following elution of the bound uranium, adsorbents prepared with succinic acid, DCQ, and VP afforded enrichment of uranium recovery in seawater simulant when contacted at 0.02 g of resin per 1 L of seawater. While capacities of up to 33 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent were achieved during screening in uranyl-spiked DI water, the nonimprinted controls also achieved up to 80% of this capacity. Good selectivity was reported for these materials, achieving >99% extraction of uranium in the presence of Th­(IV), Fe­(III), Co­(II), Ni­(II), Mn­(II), Cu­(II), and Zn­(II), while adjustment of pH had no effect on performance. When Na2CO3 was added to the screening solution, recovery for the succinic acid/VP adsorbent was only 25%, while 99% recovery was still achieved by the DCQ/VP material. The DCQ/VP IIP was tested for uranium extraction from Arabian Seawater, recovering 1.59 μg of uranium/L of seawater and an uptake value of 0.08 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent.

elements.content: Later work by Shen et al. reported formation of an IIP from the uranyl complex with 2,4-dioxypentan-3-yl methacrylate, copolymerized with EGDMA in 1,4-dioxane with AIBN. 2,4-Dioxypentan-3-yl methacrylate was synthesized to afford both a β-diketone structure and a methacrolyl group, incorporating the ability for cross-linking with a uranyl receptor possessing a pK a close to seawater pH. An uptake of approximately 24 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved from an aqueous solution of UO2(NO3)2, while 15.3 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was recovered from an aqueous 200 ppm uranyl solution containing carbonate and at pH 9. The IIP was studied for the selective adsorption of uranium from an aqueous solution with numerous monovalent cations of varying ionic radii, affording 87–140× selectivity for uranium.

elements.content: Shamsipur and colleagues later reported preparation of IIPs grafted on the surface of a silica gel adsorbent, with the IIPs polymerized from surface-bound azo groups. Polymerization was performed in the presence of a MA-uranyl complex with EGDMA, followed by elution of the uranium. Adsorption studies were performed by adding 100 mg of adsorbent to 10 mL of an aqueous 5 ppm uranyl solution over pH 1.5–4. The best uptake was achieved at pH 3, where 100% of the uranium was extracted affording an uptake in excess of 0.5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Significant selectivity was displayed for uranyl over a wide range of di- and trivalent cations, including Cu­(II), Ni­(II), Fe­(III), and Mn­(II), among others. The adsorbent also achieved efficient recovery of uranium from spiked environmental samples, though recovery of uranium from tap water and Caspian Sea water were below limits of quantification for their analytical method.

elements.content: Pandey and co-workers prepared AO-functionalized polymeric adsorbents through both UV-activated and electron-beam radiation induced graft polymerization (RIGP, discussed in the subsequent section) of AN on polypropylene (PP) fibers and microporous sheets (). The UV initiator 2,2-dimethoxy-2-phenylacetophenone (DMPA) was dissolved in the polymerizing solution containing the PP support, MBA cross-linker, and AN, with the resulting mixture exposed to 365 nm UV light for 20 min. Only 120–130 wt % Dg could be achieved by either UV-initiated polymerization or RIGP, and adsorbents prepared by both routes displayed similar wt % water uptake for a common support and comparable Dg. While a uranium uptake was not provided for the UV-prepared adsorbents, the RIGP-prepared adsorbents with similar Dg and water uptake achieved a capacity of 380 mg of uranium g–1 when contacted with a 10 ppm solution of 233U in seawater.

UV-Activated Polymerization

Pandey and co-workers prepared AO-functionalized polymeric adsorbents through both UV-activated and electron-beam radiation induced graft polymerization (RIGP, discussed in the subsequent section) of AN on polypropylene (PP) fibers and microporous sheets (). The UV initiator 2,2-dimethoxy-2-phenylacetophenone (DMPA) was dissolved in the polymerizing solution containing the PP support, MBA cross-linker, and AN, with the resulting mixture exposed to 365 nm UV light for 20 min. Only 120-130 wt % Dg could be achieved by either UV-initiated polymerization or RIGP, and adsorbents prepared by both routes displayed similar wt % water uptake for a common support and comparable Dg. While a uranium uptake was not provided for the UV-prepared adsorbents, the RIGP-prepared adsorbents with similar Dg and water uptake achieved a capacity of 380 mg of uranium g-1 when contacted with a 10 ppm solution of 233U in seawater.

elements.content: Biofouling-resistant polymer adsorbents were also prepared by UV-initiated photopolymerization, where poly­(ethylene glycol methacrylate phosphate) was polymerized in solution with Ag nanoparticles and subsequently reinforced with a thermally bonded nonwoven PP fibrous sheet. As mentioned earlier, a uniform distribution of Ag nanoparticles in the adsorbent was observed, and when incubated with E. coli, no growth was observed on the adsorbent. This suggests inclusion of Ag nanoparticles imparts some significant resistance to biofouling. When contacted with a 1788 ppm uranyl solution in seawater, a capacity of 550 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained, though large quantities of other cationic metals were also extracted.

elements.content: Suh and colleagues functionalized Sephadex G-25 resin with a metal-binding ligand composed of 2,2′-dihydroxyazobenzene (DHAB) attached to poly­(ethylenimine) (PEI; ). This work followed previous studies by the same group where DHAB was attached to a chloromethylated cross-linked poly­(St) support, chloromethylated poly­(St-co-DVB), and pure PEI. In the former references, the chloromethyl group could also be converted to a quaternary ammonium function by treating with various tertiary amines. In this work, spectrophotometric titration experiments revealed 1:1 complexes of various metals, including uranium, with PEI-bound DHAB (). After grafting to the Sephadex resin with cyanuric chloride as a coupling reagent, the adsorbent was investigated for recovery of metals from seawater. Following exposure to flowing seawater for 20 h, 0.018 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent were extracted, compared to 1.3 mg of Fe/g of adsorbent and 0.47 μg of Zn/g of adsorbent. As noted by the authors, the low uranium uptake and high affinity for competing ions indicates the Sephadex-supported DHAB-PEI does not meet the criterion for economically feasible recovery of seawater uranium.

elements.content: Ramkumar reported the chemical oxidation of aniline to generate polyaniline, followed by its application in recovery of uranium from seawater. Due to incorporation of anions, such as Cl– or SO4 2–, in the polymer during synthesis, it was expected anionic exchange with anionic uranyl complexes could be achieved. Using ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) as a metal complexant to form an anionic uranyl species, a modest affinity for uranium was reported (40% in solution), which was further suppressed by the presence of other competing metals. In contrast, substitution of EDTA for SCN– or CO3 2– resulted in a marked improvement in performance. For SCN–, 85% of the uranium was extracted from solution (albeit, at pH 1), while 95% of uranium was extracted in a carbonate solution. Furthermore, at pH 5.5 uranium could be selectively separated from solutions containing up to 100× excess of competing metal ions. When investigated for recovery of uranium from seawater, 200 mL of seawater was contacted with 100 mg of adsorbent for 4 h, with 0.42 μg of uranium recovered. This amounts to a 72% uranium recovery efficiency and an uptake of 0.0042 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Nevertheless, the extremely high phase ratio of 500 mg L–1 is unreasonable for realistic seawater deployment conditions.

elements.content: Sellin and Alexandratos reported the application of a series of polymer-supported primary amines for uranium extraction (). Poly­(VBC-co-DVB) (VBC = vinylbenzyl chloride) gel beads were synthesized as a support, followed by postsynthetic functionalization with an array of amines possessing different lengths, structures, and substituents. HCl titrations revealed comparable quantities of amine sites with capability for uranyl binding, while uranium uptake was analyzed from a synthetic seawater spiked to 50 ppm with uranyl. On a mass- uranium per mass-adsorbent basis, the short-chain primary amine (pA) afforded the maximum uptake of 14.8 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. However, as noted by the authors a mmol of uranium per mol of ligand affords a more appropriate comparison in light of the added mass from more expansive amine functionalities. By this metric, the adsorbent functionalized with pTEPA achieved the best uptake of 17.7 mmol of uranium mol–1, followed closely by pTAEA (16.0 mmol mol–1) and then by pDETA and pEDA (13.3 and 13.2 mmol mol–1, respectively). These uptake values also correlate reasonably well with the number of amine sites in the adsorbent, with values of 8.51, 8.43, 7.10, and 6.61 mmol of N/g of polymer for pTEPA, pDETA, pTAEA, and pEDA, respectively. A poly­(DVB-co-VBC) functionalized with diamidoxime was also synthesized and investigated under the same conditions as a control. A comparatively modest uranyl capacity of 2.34 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved, while the adsorbent has 10.4 mmol g–1 protonation sites, converting to 3.79 mmol of uranium/mol of binding site.

elements.content: A particularly interesting follow-up work from the same group involved formation and performance of bifunctional amidoxime fibers synthesized by functionalization of commercially available poly­(AN) fibers (). A series of adsorbents were prepared by first attaching various derivatives of diethylenetriamine (DETA) to the poly­(AN) by simple amination chemistry. To prepare bifunctional versions, the residual nitrile species were converted to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine. To provide an assessment of relative performance, uranium was loaded onto the fibers by 1-week contact with a synthetic seawater spiked with uranyl at concentrations ranging from 0.9 to 50 ppm, followed by a second 1-week contact with a fresh uranyl-spiked synthetic seawater solution of the same concentration. Samples were also investigated following 21-days contact with filtered environmental seawater in a flow-through column at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL).

Samples were also investigated following 21-days contact with filtered environmental seawater in a flow-through column at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL).

elements.content: DETA and derivatives used to functionalize poly­(AN) adsorbents for recovery of seawater uranium. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society.
elements.clean_text: 33  DETA and derivatives used to functionalize poly(AN) adsorbents for recovery of seawater uranium. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society.

elements.content: While DETA- and DETA-derivative-functionalized poly­(AN) adsorbents displayed some affinity to uranium, inclusion of amidoxime functionalities dramatically improved the uptake. Uranium was completely removed from 0.9 ppm uranyl solutions, 97–99% removed from 6 ppm solutions, and approximately 95% removed from the 50 ppm solution. In comparison, a pure poly­(amidoxime) adsorbent prepared from the same poly­(AN) precursor achieved similar performance at 0.9 and 6 ppm, but only extracted 82.5% of the uranium from the 50 ppm solution. Seawater-contacted results also reveal superior performance for the bifunctional adsorbents, with AO–DETA extracting 0.54 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent and AO-phon-DETA recovering 0.79 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Pure poly­(amidoxime) recovered 0.12 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while the nonamidoximated phon-DETA extracted a comparable 0.14 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. This work demonstrates that affinity of amidoxime-functionalized adsorbents for uranyl can be enhanced by incorporation of auxiliary DETA ligands. While detailed FTIR investigations by the authors support activation of the amidoxime by the amine, they assert additional experiments are needed to determine whether the enhanced performance is attributable to true activation of the amidoxime group or is primarily the sum of individual binding from multiple functionalities.

elements.content: Chitin, a biopolymer, was also used as a chemically modified polymer support for the recovery of uranium. Rogers and co-workers started with shrimp shell waste, extracting chitin into an ionic liquid composed of 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium acetate. The chitin was wet-jet spun into fibers which were subsequently deacetylated with NaOH to form primary amine groups on the surface. Treatment with hydroxylamine appended hydroxamic acid functionalities for seawater uranium recovery. Approximately 2.5 mg of wet fibers were contacted for 144 h with 1 mL of DI water spiked with a 233U radiotracer, affording a final uptake of approximately 0.28 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Although the performance is underwhelming, and poor fiber integrity is noted by the authors of the publication, this work constitutes a particularly innovative approach to the preparation of novel uranium adsorbents, as well as the effective utilization of a biological waste stream. Assuming adequate performance can be achieved, additional benefits from this class of polymer include the expectation of mild environmental impact, as well as access to a hydrophilic trunk material capable of facilitating transport of water through the adsorbent.

elements.content: More recently, block copolymer adsorbent precursors of poly­(AN)-block-poly­(St) have been prepared by reversible addition–fragmentation transfer (RAFT) polymerization (). The poly­(AN) block can then be converted to poly­(AO) with hydroxylamine, and the resulting poly­(AO)-block-poly­(St) can then be further polymerized into microspheres via emulsion polymerization of the poly­(St) block with additional St or DVB (). This approach affords fine-tunability of the AO chain length through controlling the poly­(AN) and poly­(St) blocks, while the AO concentration can be modulated through varying the concentration of the poly­(AO)-block-poly­(St) in the emulsion polymerization step.
elements.clean_text:
RAFT Polymerization

More recently, block copolymer adsorbent precursors of poly(AN)-block-poly(St) have been prepared by reversible addition-fragmentation transfer (RAFT) polymerization (). The poly(AN) block can then be converted to poly(AO) with hydroxylamine, and the resulting poly(AO)-block-poly(St) can then be further polymerized into microspheres via emulsion polymerization of the poly(St) block with additional St or DVB (). This approach affords fine-tunability of the AO chain length through controlling the poly(AN) and poly(St) blocks, while the AO concentration can be modulated through varying the concentration of the poly(AO)-block-poly(St) in the emulsion polymerization step.

elements.content: Performance of the poly­(AO)-block-poly­(St)-co-poly­(St/DVB) was analyzed by deploying 15 mg particles in a dialysis bag, immersed in 200 mL of uranyl solution. A maximum capacity of 85 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained in a 6 ppm uranyl solution at pH 6.5, while the analogous uptake at the more seawater-relevant pH 8 was approximately 60 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. A saturation capacity of 247 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained via an isotherm at pH 6.5. Introduction of competing cations (Na+, Mg2+, Zn2+, Co2+, Fe3+, Pb3+, and Ni2+) reduced adsorption efficiency from 4–30% at pH 6, and a modest decrease in performance was observed over five recycles.

Introduction of competing cations (Na+, Mg2+, Zn2+, Co2+, Fe3+, Pb3+, and Ni2+) reduced adsorption efficiency from 4-30% at pH 6, and a modest decrease in performance was observed over five recycles.

elements.content: Related work by the same group reported preparation of bifunctional poly­(ionic liquid) microspheres by applying a similar process. Block copolymers of poly­(N-vinylimidazole)-block-poly­(St) were prepared by RAFT. The poly­(N-vinylimidazole) could be transformed into a quaternary amine bromine by treatment with bromoalkylnitrile, thus forming the poly­(ionic liquid), and the nitrile subsequently transformed into AO by treatment with hydroxylamine. Adsorbent microspheres were then prepared by emulsion polymerization of St/DVB with the block copolymer. Varying the bromoalkylnitrile species changes the number of carbons between the amidoxime and the quaternary amine, with adsorbents prepared with n = 1, 3, and 6 carbons. Poly­(AO) and poly­(St) blocks could also be finely controlled during RAFT polymerization, affording poly­(AO) blocks ranging from 40–82 units and poly­(St) blocks ranging from 9–11 units. A synthetic scheme is displayed in .
elements.clean_text: Related work by the same group reported preparation of bifunctional poly(ionic liquid) microspheres by applying a similar process. Block copolymers of poly(N-vinylimidazole)-block-poly(St) were prepared by RAFT. The poly(N-vinylimidazole) could be transformed into a quaternary amine bromine by treatment with bromoalkylnitrile, thus forming the poly(ionic liquid), and the nitrile subsequently transformed into AO by treatment with hydroxylamine. Adsorbent microspheres were then prepared by emulsion polymerization of St/DVB with the block copolymer. Varying the bromoalkylnitrile species changes the number of carbons between the amidoxime and the quaternary amine, with adsorbents prepared with n = 1, 3, and 6 carbons. Poly(AO) and poly(St) blocks could also be finely controlled during RAFT polymerization, affording poly(AO) blocks ranging from 40-82 units and poly(St) blocks ranging from 9-11 units. A synthetic scheme is displayed in .

elements.content: Synthesis of poly­(ionic liquid)-functionalized microspheres. St and DVB are as defined in the text. Reprinted in part with permission from ref . Copyright 2015, Royal Society of Chemistry.
elements.clean_text: 36  Synthesis of poly(ionic liquid)-functionalized microspheres. St and DVB are as defined in the text. Reprinted in part with permission from ref . Copyright 2015, Royal Society of Chemistry.

elements.content: To investigate uranium uptake performance, 18 mg adsorbents were deployed in 200 mL of 12 ppm aqueous uranyl solution. For the adsorbent prepared from poly­(AO)40-block-poly­(St)9 with a propyl spacer, an adsorption optimum of approximately 65 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained a pH 7, but a statistically insignificant decrease was observed for pH 8. As the poly­(AO) block was increased, leaving the carbon bridge between the zwitterion and AO function unchanged, an uptake maximum of 170 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained when n = 82. Additionally, while performance was comparable for the carbon bridge of 1 and 3 atoms, distancing the AO functionality from the quaternary ammonium bromide by 6 carbons resulted in a significant decrease in performance.
elements.clean_text: To investigate uranium uptake performance, 18 mg adsorbents were deployed in 200 mL of 12 ppm aqueous uranyl solution. For the adsorbent prepared from poly(AO)40-block-poly(St)9 with a propyl spacer, an adsorption optimum of approximately 65 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained a pH 7, but a statistically insignificant decrease was observed for pH 8. As the poly(AO) block was increased, leaving the carbon bridge between the zwitterion and AO function unchanged, an uptake maximum of 170 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained when n = 82. Additionally, while performance was comparable for the carbon bridge of 1 and 3 atoms, distancing the AO functionality from the quaternary ammonium bromide by 6 carbons resulted in a significant decrease in performance.

elements.content: The effect of including the quaternary amine was also investigated by preparing a control sample without the AO functionality, as well as one without the cationic species. In contrast to an uptake of 60 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent for the comparable poly­(ionic liquid) microsphere with both AO and quaternary amine, the charged adsorbent without the AO achieved only 22 mg of uranium/g uptake, suggesting up to 36% of the uranium uptake could be attributed to Coulombic interactions. Additionally, while the microsphere without the quaternary amine displayed almost identical uptake performance (54 mg of uranium/g for the neutral adsorbent and 59 mg of uranium/g for the cationic adsorbent), slower adsorption kinetics were observed. This interesting adsorbent system may show promise, especially if it can be efficiently translated to a platform more amenable to large scale, open ocean deployment. Moreover, the inherent tunability of the adsorbent is particularly noteworthy for fundamental investigations of the influence of soft matter properties on metal binding, as this work reports the ability to finely control both intermediate and atomistic length scales by varying the size of the copolymer blocks as well as the distance between AO and cation.
elements.clean_text: The effect of including the quaternary amine was also investigated by preparing a control sample without the AO functionality, as well as one without the cationic species. In contrast to an uptake of 60 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent for the comparable poly(ionic liquid) microsphere with both AO and quaternary amine, the charged adsorbent without the AO achieved only 22 mg of uranium/g uptake, suggesting up to 36% of the uranium uptake could be attributed to Coulombic interactions. Additionally, while the microsphere without the quaternary amine displayed almost identical uptake performance (54 mg of uranium/g for the neutral adsorbent and 59 mg of uranium/g for the cationic adsorbent), slower adsorption kinetics were observed. This interesting adsorbent system may show promise, especially if it can be efficiently translated to a platform more amenable to large scale, open ocean deployment. Moreover, the inherent tunability of the adsorbent is particularly noteworthy for fundamental investigations of the influence of soft matter properties on metal binding, as this work reports the ability to finely control both intermediate and atomistic length scales by varying the size of the copolymer blocks as well as the distance between AO and cation.

elements.content:
A summary of material performance for all polymer-derived adsorbents prepared by neither RIGP nor ATRP is provided as .

Radiation-Induced Graft Polymerization

A truly seminal contribution to the development of polymer-supported adsorbents for seawater uranium recovery was the introduction of RIGP by Omichi and colleagues in 1985, surpassed in importance perhaps only by the introduction of the amidoxime functionality. The publication reports the preparation and performance of a fibrous polymer adsorbent functionalized by RIGP with poly­(AN) followed by amidoximation with hydroxylamine (). The work was motivated by the poor mechanical stability of other fibrous adsorbents where the nitrile precursor is homogeneously distributed through the adsorbent, such as poly­(AN). Polymeric substrates, such as poly­(ethylene) (PE) or poly­(propylene) (PP) (), can be irradiated with 60Co γ-rays or with an electron beam, forming 1019 radicals per gram of polymer. These radicals induce uncontrolled graft polymerization upon immersion of the irradiated support in a solution containing appropriate monomers (). In the work by Omichi, RIGP was used to graft AN onto fibrous poly­(tetrafluoroethylene-co-ethylene), followed by conversion to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine. A second batch of material first involved grafting of acrylic acid (AA) by RIGP to the polymeric trunk, prior to a second RIGP of AN and subsequent amidoximation.

The work was motivated by the poor mechanical stability of other fibrous adsorbents where the nitrile precursor is homogeneously distributed through the adsorbent, such as poly(AN). Polymeric substrates, such as poly(ethylene) (PE) or poly(propylene) (PP) (), can be irradiated with 60Co γ-rays or with an electron beam, forming 1019 radicals per gram of polymer. These radicals induce uncontrolled graft polymerization upon immersion of the irradiated support in a solution containing appropriate monomers (). In the work by Omichi, RIGP was used to graft AN onto fibrous poly(tetrafluoroethylene-co-ethylene), followed by conversion to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine. A second batch of material first involved grafting of acrylic acid (AA) by RIGP to the polymeric trunk, prior to a second RIGP of AN and subsequent amidoximation.

elements.content: Common trunk materials used for preparation of adsorbents by RIGP.

elements.content: When applied to recovering uranium from seawater, several important observations were reported. First, uranium uptake was observed to be linearly correlated with the amount of amidoxime grafted to the trunk. Second, the molar ratio of uranium to amidoxime groups was approximately 1:10–4, revealing poor overall efficiency. Finally, inclusion of the AA comonomer was observed to appreciably increase uranium uptake over the pure amidoxime graft polymer by approximately 20% following 7 d of batch contact with environmental seawater. A maximum uranium uptake of slightly more than 0.5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained over 50 d of contact with 2 L of environmental seawater, which was replenished every 2 d.
elements.clean_text: When applied to recovering uranium from seawater, several important observations were reported. First, uranium uptake was observed to be linearly correlated with the amount of amidoxime grafted to the trunk. Second, the molar ratio of uranium to amidoxime groups was approximately 1:10-4, revealing poor overall efficiency. Finally, inclusion of the AA comonomer was observed to appreciably increase uranium uptake over the pure amidoxime graft polymer by approximately 20% following 7 d of batch contact with environmental seawater. A maximum uranium uptake of slightly more than 0.5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained over 50 d of contact with 2 L of environmental seawater, which was replenished every 2 d.

elements.content: The authors noted in a subsequent work that when hydrophilic monomers, such as N,N-dimethyl acrylamide (DMAAm) or AA were copolymerized with poly­(AN), significant increases in water uptake were observed. Nevertheless, while water uptake by the adsorbents was poly­(AO-co-DMAAm) > poly­(AO-co-AA) > poly­(AO), uranium uptake differed slightly: poly­(AO-co-AA) > poly­(AO-co-DMAAm) > poly­(AO). This work firmly established the precedent for including hydrophilic comonomers to improve adsorbent performance, also demonstrating poly­(AA) has no appreciable affinity for uranyl and is coordinatively innocent. However, consideration of the difference between water uptake and uranium uptake reveal that hydrophilicity is not the only consideration for achieving performance improvements, as also observed by Hirotsu and colleagues in their studies on the influence of hydrophilic vs hydrophobic cross-linkers on uranium uptake.
elements.clean_text: The authors noted in a subsequent work that when hydrophilic monomers, such as N,N-dimethyl acrylamide (DMAAm) or AA were copolymerized with poly(AN), significant increases in water uptake were observed. Nevertheless, while water uptake by the adsorbents was poly(AO-co-DMAAm) > poly(AO-co-AA) > poly(AO), uranium uptake differed slightly: poly(AO-co-AA) > poly(AO-co-DMAAm) > poly(AO). This work firmly established the precedent for including hydrophilic comonomers to improve adsorbent performance, also demonstrating poly(AA) has no appreciable affinity for uranyl and is coordinatively innocent. However, consideration of the difference between water uptake and uranium uptake reveal that hydrophilicity is not the only consideration for achieving performance improvements, as also observed by Hirotsu and colleagues in their studies on the influence of hydrophilic vs hydrophobic cross-linkers on uranium uptake.

elements.content: The final foundational work reported by Omichi and colleagues articulates the first foray into the role of the shape of the polyolefin support on adsorbent performance. AN was polymerized via RIGP from PP fibrous supports possessing either round or cross-shaped cross sections. When uranium recovery performance was compared directly, the adsorbents with cross-shaped supports afforded faster uranium binding kinetics and superior uranium uptake. This result was attributed to the increase in surface area afforded by the different trunk material. Similarly, using small radius round fiber supports, a uranium uptake of 5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent could be achieved following 140 d contact with natural seawater, in contrast to 0.5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent for the larger round fiber support following 100 d contact. Careful observation of these results led the researchers to propose a logarithmic relationship between uranium recovery and trunk surface area, as displayed in .

This result was attributed to the increase in surface area afforded by the different trunk material. Similarly, using small radius round fiber supports, a uranium uptake of 5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent could be achieved following 140 d contact with natural seawater, in contrast to 0.5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent for the larger round fiber support following 100 d contact. Careful observation of these results led the researchers to propose a logarithmic relationship between uranium recovery and trunk surface area, as displayed in .
