elements.content: Although these foundational works established the fundamentals of developing polymer adsorbents by RIGP for uranium recovery, research continues to elucidate and optimize the complex relationships that govern soft matter adsorbents. In 2000, Seko and colleagues reported the preparation of methacrylic acid (MA) copolymerized with AN onto PP fibers to improve uranium adsorption kinetics by inclusion of a different hydrophilic comonomer. In contrast to the aforementioned adsorbents, MA and AN were copolymerized from the same solution following one irradiation, rather than by two distinct RIGP processes performed in series. Optimized performance was achieved for a AN/MA ratio of 80:20. Although similar to the work reported by Omichi, water content was maximized for a 60:40 ratio, suggesting competing factors in uranium adsorption performance, such as hydrophilicity vs binding site density. Inclusion of the hydrophilic MA resulted in a 4-fold enhancement in uranium binding kinetics, compared to conventional fibers prepared exclusively from RIGP of AN, and achieved a seawater uptake of 0.2 mg of uranium/g following 1 d of contact with 20 L of natural seawater in a flow-through column.
elements.clean_text:
Modern Developments in RIGP

Although these foundational works established the fundamentals of developing polymer adsorbents by RIGP for uranium recovery, research continues to elucidate and optimize the complex relationships that govern soft matter adsorbents. In 2000, Seko and colleagues reported the preparation of methacrylic acid (MA) copolymerized with AN onto PP fibers to improve uranium adsorption kinetics by inclusion of a different hydrophilic comonomer. In contrast to the aforementioned adsorbents, MA and AN were copolymerized from the same solution following one irradiation, rather than by two distinct RIGP processes performed in series. Optimized performance was achieved for a AN/MA ratio of 80:20. Although similar to the work reported by Omichi, water content was maximized for a 60:40 ratio, suggesting competing factors in uranium adsorption performance, such as hydrophilicity vs binding site density. Inclusion of the hydrophilic MA resulted in a 4-fold enhancement in uranium binding kinetics, compared to conventional fibers prepared exclusively from RIGP of AN, and achieved a seawater uptake of 0.2 mg of uranium/g following 1 d of contact with 20 L of natural seawater in a flow-through column.

elements.content: A report from the same group compared the performance of adsorbents prepared by RIGP of AN with different hydrophilic comonomers from a PE trunk fiber, followed by amidoximation with hydroxylamine. As in their prior work, MA was used as one comonomer, while HEMA was the other. As expected, modulating the weight ratios of the comonomers afforded adsorbents with differing hydrophilicities, and it was noted that the amidoxime density and water content needed to be balanced to achieve optimal uranium uptake. Water uptake by the adsorbents (postconversion with hydroxylamine treatment) was maximized when AN was not included in the initial copolymer. For the MA copolymer, water uptake decreased linearly with increasing amidoxime, while the HEMA copolymer did not display an appreciable decrease in water uptake until amidoxime exceeded 60 wt %. Seawater uranium recovery by the adsorbent materials was investigated both in lab-based flow-through experiments, where 20 L of natural seawater was circulated through a column for 24 h, as well as in open-ocean deployments off the coast of Japan, where the materials were submerged at 15 m below the surface. Submersion experiments subsequently validated by column studies revealed ratios of 60:40 for amidoxime:MA and 70:30 amidoxime:HEMA were optimal (). Uranium uptake, measured at 10, 20, and 40 d, revealed superior kinetics for the MAA-containing adsorbent, outperforming the HEMA-containing adsorbent by 1.7× and the pure poly­(amidoxime) material by 3×. The best performing material, a 60:40 amidoxime:MA copolymer on a fibrous PE trunk, achieved an uptake of 0.9 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent following 20 d deployment in the open ocean.

As expected, modulating the weight ratios of the comonomers afforded adsorbents with differing hydrophilicities, and it was noted that the amidoxime density and water content needed to be balanced to achieve optimal uranium uptake. Water uptake by the adsorbents (postconversion with hydroxylamine treatment) was maximized when AN was not included in the initial copolymer. For the MA copolymer, water uptake decreased linearly with increasing amidoxime, while the HEMA copolymer did not display an appreciable decrease in water uptake until amidoxime exceeded 60 wt %. Seawater uranium recovery by the adsorbent materials was investigated both in lab-based flow-through experiments, where 20 L of natural seawater was circulated through a column for 24 h, as well as in open-ocean deployments off the coast of Japan, where the materials were submerged at 15 m below the surface. Submersion experiments subsequently validated by column studies revealed ratios of 60:40 for amidoxime:MA and 70:30 amidoxime:HEMA were optimal (). Uranium uptake, measured at 10, 20, and 40 d, revealed superior kinetics for the MAA-containing adsorbent, outperforming the HEMA-containing adsorbent by 1.7× and the pure poly(amidoxime) material by 3×. Circles correspond to poly­(acrylamidoxime-co-MA)-graft-PE, triangles correspond to poly­(acrylamidoxime-co-HEMA)-graft-PE, diamonds denote the poly­(amidoxime)-graft-PE adsorbent devoid of hydrophilic comonomer. Circles correspond to poly(acrylamidoxime-co-MA)-graft-PE, triangles correspond to poly(acrylamidoxime-co-HEMA)-graft-PE, diamonds denote the poly(amidoxime)-graft-PE adsorbent devoid of hydrophilic comonomer. elements.content: More recently, work from Oyola and colleagues built off the work of Omichi and investigated a series of RIGP-prepared adsorbents composed of PE-graft-poly­(amidoxime-co-MA), where various high surface area PE trunk fibers were used instead of the traditional round fibers presented in previous work. These PE supports were prepared by bicomponent melt-spinning technology prior to RIGP, reducing the fiber diameter, changing the cross-sectional shape, or by combinations of both. Fibers as small as 0.25 μm in diameter were prepared through an approach known as “islands-in-the-sea,” where nanofibers are embedded in a dissolvable polymer matrix, such as poly­(lactic acid) (PLA), resulting in a coaxial-like fiber. Dissolution of the PLA results in a fiber containing as many as 156 000 nanofiber “islands.” High surface area PE fibers possessing round morphologies of varying diameter () were grafted with 70:30 AN:MA by RIGP, followed by amidoximation and performance screening in an 8 ppm uranium brine solution. The best performing adsorbent also had the smallest diameter, 0.24 mm, and in general adsorbents with smaller diameters outperformed those with larger diameters. Uranium uptake ranged from 30 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent (d = 20 mm) to 140 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent (d = 0.24 mm).

These PE supports were prepared by bicomponent melt-spinning technology prior to RIGP, reducing the fiber diameter, changing the cross-sectional shape, or by combinations of both. Fibers as small as 0.25 μm in diameter were prepared through an approach known as "islands-in-the-sea," where nanofibers are embedded in a dissolvable polymer matrix, such as poly(lactic acid) (PLA), resulting in a coaxial-like fiber. Dissolution of the PLA results in a fiber containing as many as 156000 nanofiber "islands." High surface area PE fibers possessing round morphologies of varying diameter () were grafted with 70:30 AN:MA by RIGP, followed by amidoximation and performance screening in an 8 ppm uranium brine solution. The best performing adsorbent also had the smallest diameter, 0.24 mm, and in general adsorbents with smaller diameters outperformed those with larger diameters. Uranium uptake ranged from 30 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent (d = 20 mm) to 140 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent (d = 0.24 mm).

elements.content: Summary of round PE fibrous supports investigated for seawater uranium recovery. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society.
elements.clean_text: 42  Summary of round PE fibrous supports investigated for seawater uranium recovery. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society.

elements.content: The performance of nonround fibers as PE trunks was also investigated in the same work. Using bicomponent melt-spinning technology, new shapes including solid or hollow flowers, gears, trilobal shapes, and others were investigated as supports for RIGP-prepared adsorbents (). Similar to the round PE supports, increasing the surface area with shaped fibers resulted in an increase surface area and uranium uptake, but without the loss of mechanical strength. Unlike the round fibers of varying diameter, uranium uptake by the majority of the shaped fibers displayed little variation, achieving uptake of 120–140 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. The quasi-trilobal material displayed poor performance, achieving uptake of only 20 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while the hollow gear support achieved an uptake of 160 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Screening capacities for all adsorbents are displayed in .

Unlike the round fibers of varying diameter, uranium uptake by the majority of the shaped fibers displayed little variation, achieving uptake of 120-140 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. The quasi-trilobal material displayed poor performance, achieving uptake of only 20 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while the hollow gear support achieved an uptake of 160 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Screening capacities for all adsorbents are displayed in .

elements.content: Several adsorbents on nonround PE supports were investigated for recovery of uranium from filtered environmental seawater at PNNL, compared against an adsorbent sample obtained from the JAEA. Following 11–12 weeks of contact in column-based flow through systems, the JAEA fiber achieved an uptake of 1.1 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while uptakes ranging from 2.3 to 3.1 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent were obtained for the high surface area materials. As suggested by lab-based screening, the hollow gear fiber was the best performing. However, simultaneous investigation of six batches of adsorbent prepared on the same hollow-gear trunk revealed variability in performance, with uranium uptake ranging from 2.7 to 3.5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 8 weeks of exposure. A JAEA sample investigated as a control achieved the same uptake as in the other column study, 1.1 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Similar to the pioneering work by Omichi, these results demonstrate the potential for dramatic enhancement of uranium uptake by modulation of trunk surface area.

elements.content: Another study investigated functionalizing a PE support by RIGP with AN and AA, followed by treatment with hydroxylamine. Similar to aforementioned work involving MA, water uptake and Dg increased with AA content, with a maximum uptake afforded from a 50:50 amidoxime:AA ratio. Uranium extraction was assessed from a 100 ppm solution over 1-d contact, with poly­(acrylamidoxime-co-AA) performing comparably to simple poly­(amidoxime) and achieving uptake of 25 mg of uranium/g. This similarity in performance is almost certainly attributable to the excessive uranium concentration in the screening solution. A resin-based adsorbent was also prepared by RIGP of AN and AA. In this particular example, an 80:20 amidoxime:AA ratio was optimal, affording an uptake of 924 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent from a 100 ppm UO2(NO3)2 solution. AN and MA grafted on PP by RIGP was also investigated, then analyzed for uranium uptake as a function of pH. In contrast to aforementioned studies, water uptake increased with additional amidoxime content. An uptake of 45 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained from a 95 ppm uranyl solution at pH 8 and 0.1 M ionic strength.

elements.content: Seko and colleagues reported the preparation of an adsorbent prepared on PE coated PP nonwoven fibers by RIGP of AN and MA followed by amidoximation through treatment with hydroxylamine. Following irradiation in an inert environment, the PE-coated PP fibers were immersed in a comonomer mixture in degassed DMSO, the composition of which was tuned to afford AN:MA ratios ranging from 60:40 to 80:20. Performance was investigated at pH 8 in natural seawater, contacted with a lab-based column flow-through system at a velocity of 3 L min–1. A total of 2 days of contact afforded 0.141, 0.145, and 0.135 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent for 60, 70, and 80 wt % amidoxime-containing materials, respectively. Notably, the 70:30 material displayed the best performance, in contrast to the 60:40 ratio determined for purely a fibrous PE support. Increasing seawater contact time for the optimized adsorbent to 7 days afforded a maximum uptake of 0.300 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. This nonwoven adsorbent was subsequently used for a large scale open-ocean deployment. A total of 52 000 sheets totaling 350 kg were packaged in 3 × 16 m2 adsorption cages, then deployed for 240 days at 20 m deep, 7 km off the coast of Japan. 1 kg of uranium (yellowcake) was obtained, affording an uptake of 2.8 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent per 240 days.

elements.content: A significant decrease in performance was observed for the adsorbents over five recycles, with uranium eluted with HCl. Treating the recycled adsorbent with an alkaline solution afforded 75% retention in original capacity, while no capacity was achieved if the alkaline treatment was not performed. In contrast, when tartaric acid, a weaker organic acid, was substituted for HCl, > 80% performance during adsorbent recycle was achieved. 13C NMR was used to investigate the degradation process. While peaks attributable to amidoxime and cyclic imidedioxime were visible following treatment with hydroxylamine, contact with HCl resulted in an increase in the peak assigned to a carbonyl carbon, indicative of a hydrolysis degradation pathway (). Upon treatment with an unspecified alkaline solution, a spectrum is obtained similar to the one following the initial treatment with hydroxylamine, prompting the suggestion from the authors that the uranium binding site is regenerated by this process.

elements.content: Critical consideration of this suggestion finds it unlikely, but contingent upon the identity of the base treatment. Alkaline pretreatment before seawater deployment is a common practice, known to increase uranium uptake, though the precise rational remains unresolved. Common bases used for this purpose include KOH, NaOH, and Na2CO3. In light of the acid stability reported for the open-chain amidoxime and the instability reported for the cyclic imidedioxime group, it is likely the decreasing peak upon HCl contact can be attributed to hydrolysis of cyclic imidedioxime groups. As reported by Hay and colleagues, glutarimidedioxime (H2A) degrades to glutarate upon contact with HCl, suggesting formation of adjacent carboxylate species when part of a polymer. Treatment of carboxylates with none of the aforementioned bases will result in regeneration of a cyclic imidedioxime, amidoxime, or any related functionalities. However, in the event the alkaline solution was composed of hydroxylamine, there is the possibility of further graft-chain chemistry occurring. Further work or additional information is necessary to understand and better interpret the changes in the 13C NMR spectra and the implications for adsorbent recycle.

elements.content: A PE-coated PP support was used to attach bis-amidoxime groups through a glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) intermediate, polymerized by RIGP. The PE@PP-graft-poly­(GMA) was then reacted with 3,3′-iminodipropionitrile, ring-opening the epoxide group on the GMA functionality and installing two nitriles. Subsequent treatment with hydroxylamine results in the desired bis-amidoxime-functionalized adsorbent (). Although this adsorbent was not tested for uranium uptake from natural seawater, adsorption performed in a 100 ppb uranyl solution at pH 5 revealed rapid uptake (>80% in 30 min). When contacted with a 1 ppm uranyl solution, an uptake of 1.6 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained, though competing ions V, Cu and Co all displayed significant adsorption, with values of 1.5, 0.9, and 0.9 mg/g, respectively. Although the performance of the GMA-grafted adsorbents are not remarkable, these works comprise a particularly important contribution because they establish the use of an intermediate ligand to afford the rational design and inclusion of precisely engineered uranyl binding sites.

elements.content: In 2008, Pandey and co-workers reported the application of RIGP to prepare PP membranes grafted with poly­(AN). Following irradiation in air to a 200 kGy dose, the PP membranes were immersed in a DMF/AN solution at 50 °C, affording a 125 wt % Dg. The poly­(AN) functionalities were converted to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine, and the adsorbent was pretreated in an aqueous KOH solution. Water uptake capacity for the adsorbent was 200 wt % in seawater, compared to 260 wt % in DI water, suggesting an influence of ionic strength on polymer hydrophilicity. Uranium uptake was determined by scintillation counting using a 233U radiotracer, though no explicit concentration values were provided. An uptake of 380 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was determined, affording a 1:4 uranium:amidoxime binding mode assuming exclusive formation of the open-chain amidoxime.
elements.clean_text: In 2008, Pandey and co-workers reported the application of RIGP to prepare PP membranes grafted with poly(AN). Following irradiation in air to a 200 kGy dose, the PP membranes were immersed in a DMF/AN solution at 50 °C, affording a 125 wt % Dg. The poly(AN) functionalities were converted to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine, and the adsorbent was pretreated in an aqueous KOH solution. Water uptake capacity for the adsorbent was 200 wt % in seawater, compared to 260 wt % in DI water, suggesting an influence of ionic strength on polymer hydrophilicity. Uranium uptake was determined by scintillation counting using a 233U radiotracer, though no explicit concentration values were provided. An uptake of 380 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was determined, affording a 1:4 uranium:amidoxime binding mode assuming exclusive formation of the open-chain amidoxime.

elements.content: Using the RIGP-prepared poly­(AN) adsorbent membranes discussed above, in-field demonstration experiments were performed, including deployment in intake/outfall canals of the Tarapur Atomic Power Station. Adsorbents were prepared by RIGP on PE, PP, and polyester supports, with fibrous forms of the latter two polyolefins favored during lab scale experiments and PP fibers in felt form used during oceanic deployment. During lab-based screenings, the authors investigated the effect of various synthetic parameters on the resulting material, including dose, duration, and solvent. As observed in earlier work, graft yield increases as a function of radiation dose with the most significant gains observed up to 200 kGy, and improvements were still noticed as high as 250 kGy. Selection of the appropriate solvent was also determined to be an important parameter, with DMF preventing phase separation and facilitating polymerization. It was determined 30% DMF in the AN monomer was ideal, as further dilution resulted in deleterious concentration effects. While polar protic solvents were investigated exclusively for treatment of the poly­(AN) with hydroxylamine, the authors noted that 1:1 mixtures of methanol or ethanol in water more than doubled the amount of amidoxime generated on the final adsorbent material.

elements.content: Initial studies performed in the Trombay Estuary () suggested 12 d deployment to be the optimal time frame, balancing uranium uptake against biofouling, which was determined to be detrimental to uranium uptake. Subsequent experiments performed at the power station intake/outfall canals supported this result. Approximately 30% improvement in uranium uptake was observed for the adsorbents deployed by the outfall canal over those deployed at the intake canal, putatively attributed to the elevated temperature and suggesting endothermic thermodynamics for uranium binding. The elution of 1.8 and 4.85 ppm uranium was reported for the outfall canal (following 330 and 570 h deployment, respectively), while the comparative results for the intake canal were 1.3 and 3.92 ppm. Insufficient data were provided to determine the uptake capacity of the adsorbent following seawater deployment.

elements.content: The same group reported a parametric study on RIGP of adsorbents for recovery of heavy metals, investigating the effect of cumulative dose, time exposed to air, atmosphere of radiation, and reaction temperature on final grafting yield. PP fiber sheets were irradiated and subsequently immersed in AN dissolved in DMF, followed by conversion of poly­(AN) to poly­(amidoxime) by treatment with hydroxylamine. When irradiated in air, the Dg increases with cumulative dose, reaching 80 wt % around 220 kGy. In contrast, when irradiated under an inert N2 environment, a plateau of 20 wt % is reached around 180 kGy. Exposure of the irradiated sample to air for 15 min prior to contact with the monomer solution improved the grafting to 90 wt % Dg, while heating the polymerization solution to 60 °C yielded further improvements and a Dg of 130 wt %. These data are summarized in . Performance was analyzed by oceanic deployment at the Trombay estuary submergence facility, with the optimized adsorbent achieving 0.6 × 10–3 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 13 d of contact at the pilot scale.

elements.content: Poly­(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) was investigated as a trunk material for preparation of PVA-graft-poly­(AO) adsorbents. Following preirradiation, the PVA trunk was immersed in the AN monomer solution, and a 43.5 wt % Dg was obtained. Following conversion with hydroxylamine to form amidoximes, the saturation capacity of the adsorbent was determined through production of an isothermal study. A theoretical saturation capacity of 69 mg of uranium/g of adsobent was obtained by linearization of the Langmuir isotherm, while the experimental maximum was 43 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. While the maximum adsorption in screening experiments was obtained at pH 8.5, pertinent to seawater, isotherms and all reported values were obtained at pH 4, making relevant comparisons difficult.

Following preirradiation, the PVA trunk was immersed in the AN monomer solution, and a 43.5 wt % Dg was obtained. Following conversion with hydroxylamine to form amidoximes, the saturation capacity of the adsorbent was determined through production of an isothermal study. A theoretical saturation capacity of 69 mg of uranium/g of adsobent was obtained by linearization of the Langmuir isotherm, while the experimental maximum was 43 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. While the maximum adsorption in screening experiments was obtained at pH 8.5, pertinent to seawater, isotherms and all reported values were obtained at pH 4, making relevant comparisons difficult.

elements.content: In an effort to address the poor mechanical properties exhibited by polymers following irradiation, as well as increase the Dg by promoting postirradiation radical stability, Wu and co-workers applied RIGP to graft ultrahigh molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE). When investigated by electron paramagnetic resonance, the radical lifetime on the UHMWPE was approximately 100× longer than on PE, suggesting superior potential for polymerization. Upon exposure to 50 kGy γ-radiation from a 60Co source, UHMWPE fibers were immersed in a solution of AN and AA which had been purged with N2. Ammonium iron­(II) sulfate, more commonly known as Mohr’s salt, was added to the polymerization solution to suppress homopolymerization and promote the growth of the poly­(AN-co-AA) graft chain. The study reveals that the tensile strength of the fiber decreases dramatically upon radiation, from 3 to 1.3 GPa. While surface grafting improved tensile strength, subsequent treatment with hydroxylamine mitigated any gains and a final tensile strength of 1.2 GPa was obtained. The UHMWPE-graft-poly­(amidoxime-co-AA) adsorbent was screened in a 3 ppb solution for 11 d at 30 °C, affording a respectable uptake of 1.3 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. When the uranyl concentration was increased to 5 ppm, the capacity improved to 21 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent at 30 °C and 28 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent at 40 °C, again indicative of an endothermic uranium binding process. Lastly, the adsorbent was investigated for recovery of uranium from natural seawater, performed by PNNL. The adsorbent was suspended in a column packed with glass beads which was then contacted with filtered seawater from Sequim Bay, Washington, U.S.A. Following 42 d of contact, an uptake of 2.3 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained. Subsequent studies on the same adsorbent deployed in a 331 ppb uranium screening solution contacted by batch and flow through techniques afforded uranium uptake of 4.54 and 2.97 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, respectively. When exposed to filtered seawater at PNNL, a capacity of 0.48 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained over 42 d. Finally, when deployed directly in the East China Sea of Xiamen Island for 60 d, 0.25 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was reported.

elements.content: UHMWPE was subsequently used by the same group as the fibrous polymer support for grafting of GMA and MA by RIGP, again using a 60Co source to afford γ-irradiation. The Dg was analyzed in the material as a function of monomer concentration and dose. The max Dg obtained was 553 wt %, but a slow increase in Dg with dose in excess of 20 kGy suggests a high amount of homopolymerization at higher dose and monomer concentration. 10 kGy and 10% monomer concentration in the graft solution were deemed ideal. Following polymerization, the GMA was ring-opened by reaction with EDA, with subsequent addition of AN to pendant amino groups, yielding nitrile functionalities which were subsequently converted to amidoxime (). Although affording the traditional amidoxime functionality on the adsorbent, this approach also separates the chelating functions from the graft chain, while adding amino groups to promote hydrophilicity. Furthermore, this physical separation should dramatically reduce the extent of cyclic imidedioxime formation, as adjacent amidoximes are necessary to accommodate the generation of the 6-member ring, affording exclusively the open-chain amidoxime on the adsorbent. For these reasons, the synthetic avenue pursued in the development of this adsorbent shows significant promise for the rational design of model systems which would afford insight into identification of adsorbent functional groups and metal binding environments. The adsorbent was tested in a seawater simulant under continuous flow conditions, affording an adsorbent uptake of 1.97 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. The adsorbent also displayed much better uptake of uranium over vanadium, a metal which traditionally is highly competitive for binding sites. The uptake of metals by the adsorbent was as follows: U > Cu > Fe > Ca > Mg > Ni > Zn > Pb > V > Co.

The uptake of metals by the adsorbent was as follows: U > Cu > Fe > Ca > Mg > Ni > Zn > Pb > V > Co.

elements.content: Preparation of UHMWPE-graft-poly­(GMA) and subsequent transformations to form amidoxime-functionalized adsorbent via addition of AN and treatment with hydroxylamine. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, Elsevier.
elements.clean_text: 48  Preparation of UHMWPE-graft-poly(GMA) and subsequent transformations to form amidoxime-functionalized adsorbent via addition of AN and treatment with hydroxylamine. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, Elsevier.

elements.content: A later work reported the tuning of AN/AA feed ratios during the RIGP preparation of UHMWPE adsorbents. The series of materials possessed AN:AA ratios of 4:1, 1.3:1, 0.92:1, and 0.3:1, and were screened with a 300 ppb uranium solution in seawater simulant, as well as deployment off the coast of Xiamen Island at 3 m deep for 60 d. Tensile tests revealed a 50% reduction in strength upon irradiation, with further reduction upon grafting and deployment in seawater. Furthermore, the authors noted higher ratios of AN:AA were not favorable for uranium extraction, consistent with previously reported work, and proposed a potential synergism between the carboxylic acid and amidoxime functionalities in achieving uranium binding. Uranium recovery from simulant was 5.49, 8.10, 7.01, and 3.62 mg-uranium/g-adsorbent, respectively. Similarly, adsorption upon oceanic deployment afforded uptake of 0.29, 0.50, 0.77, and 0.33 mg-uranium/g-adsorbent. From this work, the authors concluded that the 0.92:1 ratio of AN:AA afforded the best adsorbent, but also that there was no definitive correlation between the quantity of amidoxime groups and the adsorption capacity.

Similarly, adsorption upon oceanic deployment afforded uptake of 0.29, 0.50, 0.77, and 0.33 mg-uranium/g-adsorbent. elements.content: As can be readily gleaned from the aforementioned publications, AA and MA constitute the two archetypical comonomers used in the preparation of amidoxime-functionalized polymeric adsorbents (). Other hydrophilic comonomers have also been used, with DMAAm reported in some of the earliest literature applying RIGP to the extraction of uranium from seawater. HEMA was also investigated. In both instances, they were observed to afford less uranyl uptake than similar adsorbents prepared with AA or MA. Nevertheless, while hydrophilic comonomers are known to be essential for adsorbent performance, the totality of their role in influencing uranium uptake remains unresolved, and many adsorbents have been prepared with more exotic comonomers in an effort to improve seawater uranium recovery.
elements.clean_text:
Amidoxime-Functionalized Adsorbents with Different Comonomers

As can be readily gleaned from the aforementioned publications, AA and MA constitute the two archetypical comonomers used in the preparation of amidoxime-functionalized polymeric adsorbents (). Other hydrophilic comonomers have also been used, with DMAAm reported in some of the earliest literature applying RIGP to the extraction of uranium from seawater. HEMA was also investigated. In both instances, they were observed to afford less uranyl uptake than similar adsorbents prepared with AA or MA. Nevertheless, while hydrophilic comonomers are known to be essential for adsorbent performance, the totality of their role in influencing uranium uptake remains unresolved, and many adsorbents have been prepared with more exotic comonomers in an effort to improve seawater uranium recovery.

elements.content: Comonomers investigated as part of RIGP-prepared adsorbents for extraction of uranium from seawater.
elements.clean_text: 49  Comonomers investigated as part of RIGP-prepared adsorbents for extraction of uranium from seawater.

elements.content: Based on early work where water uptake and uranium binding were both investigated, one can conclude that improvement in adsorbent hydrophilicity is one role the comonomer does definitively play. Both AN and MA contain carboxylic acids which will deprotonate at seawater pH, encouraging the adsorbent to swell due to Coulombic repulsion, while pK a values for both amidoxime small molecules and polymers reveal it will be neutral. However, as uranium exists in seawater as the UO2(CO3)4– complex, a tetra-anion, a negatively charged polymer is not expected to facilitate concentration of the desired complex near the uranium binding amidoxime moieties. Moreover, such a material would presumably repel the alkali and alkaline earth cations, ubiquitous in seawater. Hua and co-workers developed an adsorbent prepared with a cationic copolymer by grafting poly­(1- vinylimidazole) onto PP via RIGP. Reaction with 4-bromobutyronitrile afforded a quaternary amine as well as the necessary nitrile group for subsequent conversion to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine (). Zeta-potential measurements revealed the cationic polymer had a surface charge of 145 mV, whereas poly­(amidoxime) had a surface charge of –9.51 mV.

Reaction with 4-bromobutyronitrile afforded a quaternary amine as well as the necessary nitrile group for subsequent conversion to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine (). elements.content: Schematic for synthesis of cationic amidoxime adsorbent. Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society.
elements.clean_text: 50  Schematic for synthesis of cationic amidoxime adsorbent. Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society.

elements.content: Uranium uptake experiments were performed in a brine solution of seawater-relevant salinity and carbonate, with pH adjusted to 8. When contacted with brine spiked with 7.2 ppm uranium, capacities were correlated with polymer Dg. Inclusion of the cationic species appeared to improve performance, as isothermal studies afforded a saturation capacity of 100 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, compared to 20 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent for the neutral poly­(amidoxime). While clearly displaying a solid trend, significant differences in polymer degree of grafting prevent an ideal comparison. When the cationic adsorbent was immersed in a 1.7 ppb solution, a capacity of 0.04 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved following 8 days contact.

When the cationic adsorbent was immersed in a 1.7 ppb solution, a capacity of 0.04 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved following 8 days contact.

elements.content: Oyola and Dai reported the systematic investigation of uranium uptake as a function of different comonomers grafted by RIGP on a PE fiber. Using a brine solution for screening performance, they observed uranium uptake as a function of comonomer was as follows: AA < vinyl sulfonic acid < MA < itaconic acid (IA) < vinyl phosphonic acid (PA), which achieved an uptake of approximately 160 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. When exposed to environmental seawater, the performance changed: MA < AA (with Mohr’s salt) < vinyl sulfonic acid < IA (with Mohr’s salt) < IA (without Mohr’s salt) < PA. Several different formulations of the adsorbents were investigated, affording seawater uranium uptake as high as 5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbnet over 11 weeks or 4.4 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 8 weeks. CHN analysis revealed a low cografting of hydrophilic monomers (e.g., <10 wt % IA and <3 wt % PA). An important observation made by the authors was that the increase in uranium adsorption capacity was correlated with grafting of AN, suggesting that one potential role of the comonomer is simply to promote AN polymerization.

Several different formulations of the adsorbents were investigated, affording seawater uranium uptake as high as 5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbnet over 11 weeks or 4.4 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 8 weeks. elements.content: Building off this work, Das and colleagues reported the optimization of two promising adsorbents identified during the previous investigation: PE-graft-poly­(amidoxime-co-IA) and PE-graft-poly­(amidoxime-co-PA), denoted as the “AF” and “AI” series, respectively. The ensuing parametric studies optimized Dg by varying the ratio of AN:comonomer, as well as by testing the effect of 1 h vs 3 h KOH predeployment treatment. For both series, material performance was first assessed by 24-h contact with a brine screening solution, possessing appropriate salinity, pH, and carbonate for environmental seawater, but with an 8 ppm uranium concentration. Samples were subsequently analyzed at PNNL suspended in columns supported by glass beads and contacted with filtered natural seawater over a period of 56 d.

The ensuing parametric studies optimized Dg by varying the ratio of AN:comonomer, as well as by testing the effect of 1 h vs 3 h KOH predeployment treatment. For both series, material performance was first assessed by 24-h contact with a brine screening solution, possessing appropriate salinity, pH, and carbonate for environmental seawater, but with an 8 ppm uranium concentration. Samples were subsequently analyzed at PNNL suspended in columns supported by glass beads and contacted with filtered natural seawater over a period of 56 d.

elements.content: For the AF materials, varying the AN:IA ratio in the grafting solution from 3.76:1 to 23.36:1 afforded Dg values of 154–354 wt %. For the AI series, AN:PA ratios varied from 1.91:1 to 7.39:1, resulting in Dgs of 110–300 wt %. When screened for uranium uptake in the brine solution, the AF series showed consistent performance of approximately 170–190 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, regardless of Dg. A maximum uptake of 200 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent obtained for the material with a 7.57:1 AN:IA ratio, conditioned in KOH for 3 h prior to contact. In contrast, the AI series displayed a dramatic change in performance in the brine solution as a function of comonomer ratio. While a PE-graft-poly­(amidoxime) adsorbent yielded an uptake of 165 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, progressive inclusion of PA afforded increasing uptake, maximized at a ratio of approximately 3.2–3.5:1 (). The maximum uptake was approximately 187 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, following 3 h of KOH conditioning.

elements.clean_text: 51  Uptake by AI-series adsorbents from 8 ppm uranium brine solution, following 3 h of KOH conditioning and 24-h contact. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society.

elements.content: For both AF and AI materials, trends observed during brine screening loosely predicted performance upon deployment in seawater (). For AF, the best material performance was achieved by a 10.14:1 AN:IA ratio contacted for 1 h with KOH, affording 3.9 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. This is a slightly higher monomer ratio than determined ideal by the screening study, underscoring the importance of actual seawater tests in providing meaningful adsorption data and for analyzing the effect of synthetic modifications to adsorbents. For AI materials, the same AN:PA ratios as identified in screening afforded the optimal performance, though the material composed of 3.52:1 AN:PA out-performed the material with a 3.21:1 ratio. In contrast to the screening studies, the differences in uranium uptake were much less distinct, with most materials, including PE-graft-poly­(amidoxime), achieving capacities ranging from 2.8–3.2 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. The best uptake of 3.4 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved following 3 h of KOH conditioning of the material with a 3.52:1 AN:PA ratio.

elements.content: Similar to previous work with AN and AA, these reports confirm the importance of the hydrophilic comonomer in achieving improved adsorbent performance, though they also demonstrate these two new comonomers require less monomer composition to achieve optimal performance. Although the precise rationale for this has not been investigated directly, subsequent work has suggested at the innocence of the comonomer in binding uranium directly, suggesting improvements may be attributable to increased steric bulk and the influence on graft chain morphology.

Although the precise rationale for this has not been investigated directly, subsequent work has suggested at the innocence of the comonomer in binding uranium directly, suggesting improvements may be attributable to increased steric bulk and the influence on graft chain morphology.

elements.content: Emulsion polymerization affords an interesting variation on traditional RIGP processes. Instead of immersing a preirradiated polymer support in a homogeneous monomer solution, a surfactant is used to create microemulsions possessing high monomer concentrations. Polymerization proceeds rapidly once initiated, while formation of uniform microemulsions ensures similar quantities of monomer are polymerized at each initiated site, theoretically reducing the polydispersity of the resulting graft chain.
elements.clean_text:
Emulsion Graft Polymerization

Emulsion polymerization affords an interesting variation on traditional RIGP processes. Instead of immersing a preirradiated polymer support in a homogeneous monomer solution, a surfactant is used to create microemulsions possessing high monomer concentrations. Polymerization proceeds rapidly once initiated, while formation of uniform microemulsions ensures similar quantities of monomer are polymerized at each initiated site, theoretically reducing the polydispersity of the resulting graft chain.

elements.content: Following the initial report of GMA as an intermediate functionality for preparing uranium adsorbents, GMA was used to achieve the first adsorbent prepared by emulsion polymerization for the recovery of uranium from seawater. GMA was grafted to a PE fiber adsorbent through RIGP with Tween-20 as the surfactant. Improvements in Dg were observed to be dependent upon radiation dose, up to 40 kGy, where the rate of polymerization exceeds the rate of monomer diffusion to the trunk polymer. The highest Dg values were obtained at 40 kGy, 50 °C, and with 0.5% Tween-20 in the monomer solution. The GMA-grafted fibers were then reacted with DETA, triethylenetetramine (TETA), and ethylenediamine (EDA), again by ring-opening of the GMA epoxide (). Uranium uptake was assessed by contacting with a 100 ppb aqueous solution for 1 d at pH 5. While a precise uptake cannot be calculated from the data provided, a minimum value of 0.25 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent can be calculated based on the reported value for the K d.
elements.clean_text: Following the initial report of GMA as an intermediate functionality for preparing uranium adsorbents, GMA was used to achieve the first adsorbent prepared by emulsion polymerization for the recovery of uranium from seawater. Improvements in Dg were observed to be dependent upon radiation dose, up to 40 kGy, where the rate of polymerization exceeds the rate of monomer diffusion to the trunk polymer. The highest Dg values were obtained at 40 kGy, 50 °C, and with 0.5% Tween-20 in the monomer solution. The GMA-grafted fibers were then reacted with DETA, triethylenetetramine (TETA), and ethylenediamine (EDA), again by ring-opening of the GMA epoxide (). Uranium uptake was assessed by contacting with a 100 ppb aqueous solution for 1 d at pH 5. elements.content: Comonomers and amines applied for epoxide ring opening of GMA and 4-HAGE to generate uranyl adsorbent polymers.
elements.clean_text: 53  Comonomers and amines applied for epoxide ring opening of GMA and 4-HAGE to generate uranyl adsorbent polymers.

elements.content: Wang and colleagues performed a closely related work, using preirradiation to graft emulsified GMA (with Tween-20 surfactant) onto PE nonwoven fabric. In addition to TETA, DETA, and EDA, tetraethylenepentamine was also used to functionalize the poly­(GMA)-graft-PE material. While Dg of up to 325 wt % could be obtained with a dose of 30 kGy and 60 min polymerization at 75 °C, the high Dg materials were observed to embrittle, and an optimal Dg of 195 wt % was selected. Uranium uptake was determined from various screening solutions with the best performing material containing the simple EDA chelator which afforded the highest molar density (). When contacted with a 1 ppm uranyl solution in water, a capacity of 1.6 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved. Inclusion of carbonate reduced the uptake to 1.3 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Reducing the uranium concentration to that of natural seawater afforded uptake of 0.006 and 0.003 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, for DI water and carbonate solutions, respectively.

elements.content: Related work was recently published articulating the preparation of PE@PP-graft-poly­(4-hydroxybutyl acrylate glycidyl ether) (4-HAGE) by RIGP and emulsion polymerization in a 5% graft ligand and 0.5% Tween-20 solution. Similar to GMA, 4-HAGE possesses an epoxide group which can be opened through nucleophilic attack by sterically unencumbered amines, as well as an acryl functionality which is amenable to RIGP. The primary difference is the length of the alkyl chain between the acryl and epoxide groups, with 4-HAGE an additional six atoms farther away and putatively affording faster adsorption and improved performance. As reported previously, following polymerization on a nonwoven PE coated PP fabric, the epoxide group was opened with EDA, DETA, TETA, and diethylamine (DEA) affording chelator densities ranging from 1.6 to 3 mmol g–1. Uranium adsorption studies were performed revealing DETA to achieve fastest adsorption kinetics, followed by DEA, TETA, and EDA, and a maximum uranium uptake of 64.3 mg of uranium/g. While pH had a negligible effect on the uranium uptake over the range of 4–8.5, deploying the adsorbents in uranyl solutions with 3.5% salinity, appropriate for a seawater simulant, resulted in a 55% loss of capacity. Furthermore, adsorption was optimal when performed at 25 °C, outperforming studies performed at 35 °C and far superior to performance at lower temperature. These results not only prevent determination of binding enthalpy, but also suggest factors in addition to those occurring at the atomistic scale influence the energetics of uranium binding in this system.

elements.content: Wang, Li and colleagues reported the first instance of emulsion polymerization of AN for development of adsorbents for the recovery of uranium from seawater. PE nonwoven fabric was preirradiated and contacted with AN emulsified with Tween-20, followed by treatment with hydroxylamine to generate PE-graft-poly­(amidoxime), as reported in a previous work. Characterization of uranium uptake was performed at different concentrations and temperatures in 3.5 L of uranyl solutions. At the environmentally relevant concentration of 3 ppb and pH 7.5, the adsorbent achieved 0.024–0.036 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent following 10 days contact at 10–30 °C. Application of the Arrhenius equation afforded an activation energy of 65.8 kJ mol–1, and the increase in uranium uptake as a function of temperature is indicative of an endothermic binding process.
elements.clean_text: Wang, Li and colleagues reported the first instance of emulsion polymerization of AN for development of adsorbents for the recovery of uranium from seawater. PE nonwoven fabric was preirradiated and contacted with AN emulsified with Tween-20, followed by treatment with hydroxylamine to generate PE-graft-poly(amidoxime), as reported in a previous work. Characterization of uranium uptake was performed at different concentrations and temperatures in 3.5 L of uranyl solutions. At the environmentally relevant concentration of 3 ppb and pH 7.5, the adsorbent achieved 0.024-0.036 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent following 10 days contact at 10-30 °C. Application of the Arrhenius equation afforded an activation energy of 65.8 kJ mol-1, and the increase in uranium uptake as a function of temperature is indicative of an endothermic binding process.

elements.content: The majority of work pertaining to adsorbent development by RIGP involves the propagation of a graft chain from a polyolefin trunk, as discussed above. The trunk is irradiated and subsequently immersed in a monomer-containing solution. However, direct irradiation of the monomer solution, without inclusion of any trunk or support, results in the formation of a hydrogel which can also be used for the recovery of uranium from seawater.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrogels Prepared through Radiation Induced Polymerization

The majority of work pertaining to adsorbent development by RIGP involves the propagation of a graft chain from a polyolefin trunk, as discussed above. The trunk is irradiated and subsequently immersed in a monomer-containing solution. However, direct irradiation of the monomer solution, without inclusion of any trunk or support, results in the formation of a hydrogel which can also be used for the recovery of uranium from seawater.

elements.content: Pekel, Güven, and colleagues have been protagonists of this field of material development, with early work reporting the use of poly­(AN-co-N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) (VP) hydrogels for uranium recovery (). The respective monomers were irradiated by a γ-radiation from a 60Co source, with AN:VP ratios of 0.67:1, 1:1, 1.5:1, and 2:1. Hydrogel performance was assessed by contacting with aqueous solutions 1000–1850 ppm in uranium, affording uptakes as high as 540 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent for the best materials, albeit at pH 4. Similar to work on supported graft polymers, a mixture of AN with the hydrophilic comonomer VP afforded the best performance, with 1:1 and 1.5:1 achieving the best uptake due to the improved hydrophilicity and accessibility of uranium binding sites. Concurrent work revealed higher quantities of VP afforded greater water uptake and swelling (). Based on the stoichiometry of amidoxime:uranyl, the authors proposed a 1:4 UO2 2+:amidoxime binding mode.

elements.content: Later work from the same group reported the preparation of poly­(AN-co-VP) interpenetrating polymer networks (IPNs), synthesized by γ-irradiation of solutions of AN in VP. Nitriles were converted to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine, which was monitored by FTIR and correlated well with uranyl uptake. While the poly­(AN-co-VP) IPN afforded a uranium uptake of 540 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent prior to treatment with hydroxylamine, performance improved to 750 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent after formation of the amidoxime groups. While the importance of forming the amidoxime species cannot be overstated, these uptake experiments were performed at a concentration of 1400 ppm uranium, without any carbonate or consideration for ionic strength. Accordingly, a high uptake is observed for even the nonamidoximated material, and little insight is afforded regarding the materials potential for seawater uranium recovery.
elements.clean_text: Later work from the same group reported the preparation of poly(AN-co-VP) interpenetrating polymer networks (IPNs), synthesized by γ-irradiation of solutions of AN in VP. Nitriles were converted to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine, which was monitored by FTIR and correlated well with uranyl uptake. While the poly(AN-co-VP) IPN afforded a uranium uptake of 540 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent prior to treatment with hydroxylamine, performance improved to 750 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent after formation of the amidoxime groups. While the importance of forming the amidoxime species cannot be overstated, these uptake experiments were performed at a concentration of 1400 ppm uranium, without any carbonate or consideration for ionic strength. Accordingly, a high uptake is observed for even the nonamidoximated material, and little insight is afforded regarding the materials potential for seawater uranium recovery.

elements.content: Synthesis of terpolymeric hydrogel adsorbents was achieved by polymerization in water initiated by a 60Co source. Aqueous solutions containing acrylamide (AA), 2-hydroxy propylmethyl acrylate (HPMA), and maleic acid (MaA) were irradiated in air and at ambient temperature at 0.45 kGy h–1 to total doses of 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 kGy. Hydrogels composed of AA, AA/HPMA, and AA/HPMA/MaA were synthesized, characterized, and investigated for uranyl uptake. Adsorbent swelling upon contact with water was greatest for the poly­(AA) system, followed by poly­(AA-co-HPMA-co-MaA), then poly­(AA-co-HPMA). Importantly, the poly­(AA) system did not adsorb any uranium, while the others displayed a distinct color change following contact with an aqueous uranyl solution for 48 h at pH 5–6. The negligible uptake by the AA hydrogel was rationalized by it being devoid of any ionizable groups, preventing interaction with uranyl. ΔG values of <20 kJ mol–1 were calculated, indicative of physisorption of uranium onto the material, rather than chemical binding. Information on the quantity of uranium adsorbed was not provided, but the aforementioned thermodynamic information reveals the hydrogel would not perform favorably for seawater uranium recovery.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of terpolymeric hydrogel adsorbents was achieved by polymerization in water initiated by a 60Co source. Aqueous solutions containing acrylamide (AA), 2-hydroxy propylmethyl acrylate (HPMA), and maleic acid (MaA) were irradiated in air and at ambient temperature at 0.45 kGy h-1 to total doses of 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 kGy. Hydrogels composed of AA, AA/HPMA, and AA/HPMA/MaA were synthesized, characterized, and investigated for uranyl uptake. Adsorbent swelling upon contact with water was greatest for the poly(AA) system, followed by poly(AA-co-HPMA-co-MaA), then poly(AA-co-HPMA). Importantly, the poly(AA) system did not adsorb any uranium, while the others displayed a distinct color change following contact with an aqueous uranyl solution for 48 h at pH 5-6. The negligible uptake by the AA hydrogel was rationalized by it being devoid of any ionizable groups, preventing interaction with uranyl. ΔG values of <20 kJ mol-1 were calculated, indicative of physisorption of uranium onto the material, rather than chemical binding. Information on the quantity of uranium adsorbed was not provided, but the aforementioned thermodynamic information reveals the hydrogel would not perform favorably for seawater uranium recovery.

elements.content: AA and acrylic acid (AcA) were copolymerized at molar ratios of 15:85, 20:80, and 30:70, with the resulting hydrogels investigated for uranium recovery. Swelling behavior was related to the quantity of AA, and with maximum swelling for the hydrogel with the 15:85 molar ratio at pH 8. In contrast, swelling with UO2(NO3)2 or UO2(OAc)2 resulted in significantly lower swelling percentages, attributed to metal binding resulting in the exclusion of water from the hydrogel. Uranium uptake ranged from 70–400 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, though the yellow coloration and facile desorption of uranyl ions upon contact with DI water supports physisorption as the mode of action.
elements.clean_text: AA and acrylic acid (AcA) were copolymerized at molar ratios of 15:85, 20:80, and 30:70, with the resulting hydrogels investigated for uranium recovery. Swelling behavior was related to the quantity of AA, and with maximum swelling for the hydrogel with the 15:85 molar ratio at pH 8. In contrast, swelling with UO2(NO3)2 or UO2(OAc)2 resulted in significantly lower swelling percentages, attributed to metal binding resulting in the exclusion of water from the hydrogel. Uranium uptake ranged from 70-400 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, though the yellow coloration and facile desorption of uranyl ions upon contact with DI water supports physisorption as the mode of action.

elements.content:
Performance for uranium uptake for adsorbents prepared by RIGP are summarized in .

Atom-Transfer Radical Polymerization

Since the initial discovery in the 1950s, controlled or “living” polymerization has contributed tremendously to the advancement of polymer science. In contrast to conventional free radical polymerization, such as RIGP, living polymerization affords precise control over the graft chain synthesis, permitting modulation of various important polymer parameters. For example, graft chain molecular weight, composition, and morphologies can be tuned, including installation of various block copolymer architectures. Furthermore, precise control over the chain length can be achieved, allowing determination of the precise Dg to achieve optimal performance. Recent developments in controlled radical polymerization have also greatly expanded its applicability to a wide range of monomers, allowing the incorporation of monomers which are not suitable for RIGP due to radical quenching and making controlled radical polymerization an exciting avenue for the rational development of new adsorbents for the recovery of uranium from seawater. ATRP is especially well-suited for controlling AN polymerization, particularly in light of other techniques, such as anionic polymerization, which are not as well controlled. In addition to the intensely studied polymerization mechanism of AN via ATRP, the functionalization of trunk fibers to possess uniformly distributed ATRP initiation sites is feasible, with some commercially available trunk polymers amenable to direct functionalization by ATRP. Thus, several recent studies investigated the use of ATRP for a graft polymerization on fibers and other substrates, as are summarized in the following section.

Saito and colleagues reported the first use of ATRP for the preparation of adsorbents for uranium recovery from seawater. A high surface area PE trunk was first grafted by RIGP with poly­(vinylbenzyl chloride, VBC) () to install ATRP initiation sites. AN and tert-butyl acrylate (tBA) were then copolymerzied by ATRP from the PE-graft-poly­(VBC) trunk material, creating a “brush-on-brush” structure (). This material was then converted to the amidoxime form by reaction with hydroxylamine. Implementation of ATRP afforded a much higher Dg than RIGP alone, with values ranging from 585–2818 wt % being achieved. Polymer composition was varied by tuning the ratio of AN:tBA, observing that both amidoxime density and hydrophilicity were essential for optimal adsorbent performance.
elements.clean_text: Saito and colleagues reported the first use of ATRP for the preparation of adsorbents for uranium recovery from seawater. A high surface area PE trunk was first grafted by RIGP with poly(vinylbenzyl chloride, VBC) () to install ATRP initiation sites. AN and tert-butyl acrylate (tBA) were then copolymerzied by ATRP from the PE-graft-poly(VBC) trunk material, creating a "brush-on-brush" structure (). This material was then converted to the amidoxime form by reaction with hydroxylamine. Implementation of ATRP afforded a much higher Dg than RIGP alone, with values ranging from 585-2818 wt % being achieved. Polymer composition was varied by tuning the ratio of AN:tBA, observing that both amidoxime density and hydrophilicity were essential for optimal adsorbent performance.

elements.content: Trunk materials and comonomers used in preparation of polymeric adsorbents by ATRP.
elements.clean_text: 57  Trunk materials and comonomers used in preparation of polymeric adsorbents by ATRP.

elements.content: Preparation of the PE-graft-poly­(VBC)-graft-poly­(amidoxime-co-tBA) adsorbent by combination RIGP and ATRP, affording a brush-on-brush structure. Installation of a highly hydrophilic block at the end of the graft chain afforded improved uranium uptake, also demonstrating the importance of polymer morphology and hydrophilicity in adsorbent performance. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2014, Royal Society of Chemistry.
elements.clean_text: 58  Preparation of the PE-graft-poly(VBC)-graft-poly(amidoxime-co-tBA) adsorbent by combination RIGP and ATRP, affording a brush-on-brush structure. Installation of a highly hydrophilic block at the end of the graft chain afforded improved uranium uptake, also demonstrating the importance of polymer morphology and hydrophilicity in adsorbent performance. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2014, Royal Society of Chemistry.

elements.content: This first generation of ATRP adsorbents were screened in a 6 ppm uranium brine solution under laboratory conditions, achieving uptake of 141–179 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. However, when deployed in filtered natural seawater in a flow-through column setup, uptake was lower than that of other high-surface-area adsorbents, attributed to slower adsorption kinetics resulting from suppressed mass transfer. The next iteration on the adsorbent included the installation of a hydrophilic block of poly­(tBA) on the end of the graft chain terminus, resulting in the doubling of the seawater adsorption capacity from 1.56 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent to over 3 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent following 56 d of exposure. This investigation revealed the importance of polymer chain conformation and optimization of hydrophilic comonomers in the development of advanced adsorbents for uranium recovery from seawater.
elements.clean_text: This first generation of ATRP adsorbents were screened in a 6 ppm uranium brine solution under laboratory conditions, achieving uptake of 141-179 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. However, when deployed in filtered natural seawater in a flow-through column setup, uptake was lower than that of other high-surface-area adsorbents, attributed to slower adsorption kinetics resulting from suppressed mass transfer. The next iteration on the adsorbent included the installation of a hydrophilic block of poly(tBA) on the end of the graft chain terminus, resulting in the doubling of the seawater adsorption capacity from 1.56 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent to over 3 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent following 56 d of exposure. This investigation revealed the importance of polymer chain conformation and optimization of hydrophilic comonomers in the development of advanced adsorbents for uranium recovery from seawater.

elements.content: Brown and colleagues recently reported the complete elimination of the RIGP step to further advance the preparation of adsorbents via ATRP. In order to afford ATRP initiation sites, a new class of trunk materials were prepared by chlorination of PP round fibers, a hollow-gear-shaped PP fiber, and a hollow-gear-shaped PE fiber (shaped fibers, including representative pictures, are discussed above in section 4.2.2). ATRP of AN and tBA from the halide-functionalized trunk fibers was successfully achieved, with Dg as high as 2570 wt % obtained. Amidoximation was achieved by the usual approach. An overview of the synthesis of this new adsorbent is provided in . The maximum adsorption capacity from a 6 ppm uranium screening brine solution was 146.6 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, approximately doubling an adsorbent provided by the JAEA as a control (75.1 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent).
elements.clean_text: Brown and colleagues recently reported the complete elimination of the RIGP step to further advance the preparation of adsorbents via ATRP. In order to afford ATRP initiation sites, a new class of trunk materials were prepared by chlorination of PP round fibers, a hollow-gear-shaped PP fiber, and a hollow-gear-shaped PE fiber (shaped fibers, including representative pictures, are discussed above in section 4.2.2). ATRP of AN and tBA from the halide-functionalized trunk fibers was successfully achieved, with Dg as high as 2570 wt % obtained. Amidoximation was achieved by the usual approach. An overview of the synthesis of this new adsorbent is provided in . The maximum adsorption capacity from a 6 ppm uranium screening brine solution was 146.6 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, approximately doubling an adsorbent provided by the JAEA as a control (75.1 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent).

elements.content: Chlorination of shaped polyolefin trunks and subsequent graft-chain polymerization by ATRP to afford adsorbents for seawater uranium recovery. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society.
elements.clean_text: 59  Chlorination of shaped polyolefin trunks and subsequent graft-chain polymerization by ATRP to afford adsorbents for seawater uranium recovery. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society.

elements.content: The same group simultaneously reported graft-polymerizing from a commercially available poly­(vinyl chloride)-co-chlorinated poly­(vinyl chloride) (PVC-co-CPVC) fiber through application of ATRP (). This direct approach eliminates any modification of the trunk material, simplifying the process and reducing the adsorbent cost. The ratio of AN to tBA was systematically varied to identify the optimal ratio of hydrophilicity and uranyl binding amidoxime functionalities, derived from the AN by treatment with hydroxylamine. The best performing adsorbent possessed a tBA:AN ratio of 0.356 and a Dg of 1390 wt %. When deployed in flow-through column studies and contacted with filtered natural seawater, remarkable uptake was obtained. Following 42 days exposure, the material uptake ranged from 2.42–3.24 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while 5.22 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was recovered following 49 d of exposure. To date, this remains the highest uranium uptake reported in the open literature.

elements.content: Synthesis of PVC-co-CPVC-graft-poly­(AO-co-tBA) for recovery of uranium from seawater. This material currently displays the best performance for extraction of uranium from natural seawater, surpassing 5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 49 d of deployment. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society.
elements.clean_text: 60  Synthesis of PVC-co-CPVC-graft-poly(AO-co-tBA) for recovery of uranium from seawater. This material currently displays the best performance for extraction of uranium from natural seawater, surpassing 5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 49 d of deployment. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society.

elements.content: While displaying remarkable promise, questions remain unresolved regarding interbatch reproducibility for the PVC-co-CPVC-graft-poly­(AO-co-tBA) material. As reported in the publication, three different batches of adsorbent were analyzed for recovery of uranium from filtered natural seawater, each affording different uptake kinetics and calculated saturation capacities. While the best performing batch reached a half-saturation around 14 days contact, the worst performing batch required nearly twice as long (). Accompanying calculated saturation uptake ranged from 3.94 to 6.91 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Comparison against JAEA reference fibers deployed and measured simultaneously also displayed significant fluctuations, though the changes in uptake did not correlate with those observed for the ATRP-prepared material. The authors attributed slight compositional differences to be the driving force in the dramatic changes in performance. Further investigation is necessary to achieve sufficiently precise control over the polymer composition and validate the influence on adsorbent performance. If this hypothesis is correct, it implies extreme sensitivity of the adsorbent to subtle changes in synthetic approach, and causes one to question whether such control is achievable at industrial scale.

elements.content: ATRP has also been applied to the synthesis of mesoporous polymer adsorbents, functionalized with poly­(amidoxime). As first reported by Yue and co-workers, a copolymer monolith support was synthesized by conventional free radical polymerization of VBC and DVB in the presence of AIBN. A surface area of 572 m2 g–1 was achieved by optimizing the ratio of the two comonomers. Subsequent ATRP of AN was initiated from the chloride in the poly­(VBC-co-DVB), which was subsequently converted to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine. displays a representative schematic of the synthesis process.

elements.content: When screened for uranium adsorption in a 6.8 ppm uranyl brine solution at pH 8, the material achieved an uptake of 80 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, outperforming several commercially available adsorbent materials. Furthermore, when deployed in 5 gallons (18.92 L) of environmental seawater for 27 d, an uptake of 2.0 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved.
elements.clean_text: When screened for uranium adsorption in a 6.8 ppm uranyl brine solution at pH 8, the material achieved an uptake of 80 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, outperforming several commercially available adsorbent materials. Furthermore, when deployed in 5 gallons (18.92 L) of environmental seawater for 27 d, an uptake of 2.0 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved.

elements.content: The same group applied ATRP to the functionalization of a porous aromatic framework (PAF) with poly­(AN), followed by conversion to PAF-graft-poly­(AO) with hydroxylamine. Uranium uptake was assessed in laboratory screening tests using a 6 ppm uranium brine solution, where the adsorbent outperformed several commercially available adsorbents as well as a reference fiber obtained from the JAEA. Uptakes of 64.1 and 65.2 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent were obtained for the “as prepared” sample, as well as following a KOH-conditioning step. The statistically insignificant difference in uranium uptake indicates the alkaline preconditioning normally required for polymer adsorbents is not necessary for this particular material. While easy to overlook this important detail, the identity of the trunk is the primary difference that differentiates this polymer adsorbent from the many different adsorbent materials discussed above, and further research is warranted to elucidate the relationship between trunk material and need for KOH conditioning prior to achieving promising performance.

elements.content: The adsorbent was also tested via batch-contact in filtered environmental seawater spiked to an 80 ppb uranium concentration. Following 42 d of contact, an adsorption capacity of 4.81 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved. Furthermore, kinetics analysis revealed approximately 80% of all uranium was adsorbed after 2 weeks of contact, suggesting a reduced deployment time would be plausible. Nevertheless, no appreciable uranium uptake was detected by the authors when the material was deployed in unspiked seawater, though the low concentration of uranium was near the limits of their analytical quantification.

elements.content: Chi and co-workers further developed the above work, varying the ratio of DVB:VBC and polymerizing AN by ATRP. As in the work by Yue and colleagues, the surface area and pore architectures of the poly­(DVB:VBC) could be tuned as a function of the DVB:VBC ratio. Furthermore, the authors noted that poly­(AN) length varied as the structure of the poly­(DVB-co-VBC) support changed. While the highest Dg was obtained for the material formed on the 1:1 DVB:VBC support, the best performing adsorbent was prepared on 2:1 DVB:VBC, suggesting the structure of the support may supersede Dg in determining adsorbent performance. When contacted with a 100 ppm aqueous uranyl solution at pH 8.3, a uranium uptake of 75 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved. When the concentration was reduced to 10 ppb, an uptake of 2 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was reported.

elements.content:
The uranium uptake performance of adsorbents prepared by ATRP are summarized in .

Rational Design and Synthesis of Uranyl-Chelating LigandsIntroduction

While promising development has been reported through preparation of polymer adsorbents, a second school of thought involves the rational design and synthesis of engineered uranyl receptors. For example, Rebek and colleagues reported an ion exchange polymer where a ligand derived from Kemp’s triacid oriented three carboxylates to bind uranyl in the equatorial plane, while an N–H bond is oriented toward the axial oxygen (). This receptor could be immobilized on PEG and subsequently supported on a minimally cross-linked poly­(St) substrate at 0.22 mmol g–1. Uranium recovery from seawater spiked to 400 ppb with uranium at pH 8.4 afforded recovery of 332 ng of U and was able to be recycled over 15 times with negligible degradation in performance.

Rational Design and Synthesis of Uranyl-Chelating Ligands

Introduction

While promising development has been reported through preparation of polymer adsorbents, a second school of thought involves the rational design and synthesis of engineered uranyl receptors. For example, Rebek and colleagues reported an ion exchange polymer where a ligand derived from Kemp's triacid oriented three carboxylates to bind uranyl in the equatorial plane, while an N-H bond is oriented toward the axial oxygen (). This receptor could be immobilized on PEG and subsequently supported on a minimally cross-linked poly(St) substrate at 0.22 mmol g-1. Uranium recovery from seawater spiked to 400 ppb with uranium at pH 8.4 afforded recovery of 332 ng of U and was able to be recycled over 15 times with negligible degradation in performance.

elements.content: Although the aforementioned work is not on a support capable of deployment in seawater, the general strategy provides an important point for consideration. Rather than forming long graft chains of poly­(amidoxime-co-hydrophilic monomer), better adsorbent performance may be achieved through application of supramolecular chemistry principles with rational design of highly selective chelators. Moreover, as receptors are necessarily well-defined, such an approach is inherently amenable to application of high-performance computational design. This section summarizes recent work on the design of such engineered uranyl receptors, with particular emphasis on application of computation to the design and improvement of uranyl-binding species.

Rather than forming long graft chains of poly(amidoxime-co-hydrophilic monomer), better adsorbent performance may be achieved through application of supramolecular chemistry principles with rational design of highly selective chelators. Moreover, as receptors are necessarily well-defined, such an approach is inherently amenable to application of high-performance computational design. This section summarizes recent work on the design of such engineered uranyl receptors, with particular emphasis on application of computation to the design and improvement of uranyl-binding species.

elements.content: Early improvements to the amidoxime functionality were proposed by Abney et al., who performed DFT calculations to identify critical orbitals participating in uranium-amidoxime bonding. Natural bond orbital (NBO) analysis of [UO2(AO)­(H2O)3]+ revealed bonds between uranium and hybridized orbitals from O and N were more than 85% localized on the light elements, and the authors observed that varying the energy levels of the bonding orbitals would result in differing bond strength. By increasing electron donation, the energy level of the bonding molecular orbitals should increase to afford greater contribution from uranyl and a more thermodynamically stable bond. When η2-bound to uranyl, a series of conjugated π-orbitals connect the oxime functionality with the adjacent amine, affording a convenient route for varying the electron density on the oxime and modulating the energy of the electronic orbitals.
elements.clean_text:
Computationally-Guided Amidoxime Development

Early improvements to the amidoxime functionality were proposed by Abney et al., who performed DFT calculations to identify critical orbitals participating in uranium-amidoxime bonding. Natural bond orbital (NBO) analysis of [UO2(AO)(H2O)3]+ revealed bonds between uranium and hybridized orbitals from O and N were more than 85% localized on the light elements, and the authors observed that varying the energy levels of the bonding orbitals would result in differing bond strength. By increasing electron donation, the energy level of the bonding molecular orbitals should increase to afford greater contribution from uranyl and a more thermodynamically stable bond. When η2-bound to uranyl, a series of conjugated π-orbitals connect the oxime functionality with the adjacent amine, affording a convenient route for varying the electron density on the oxime and modulating the energy of the electronic orbitals.

elements.content: To investigate this hypothesis, the authors performed DFT calculations on a series of oximate-derived ligands, coordinated in an η2-fashion to uranyl. Substituents adjacent to the oxime were selected on the basis of their electron donating character via resonance, with Gibbs Free Energies (ΔG) for uranyl binding calculated by DFT and used to determine the equilibrium constant K, assuming a temperature of 298 K. The unfunctionalized acetoxime ligand, with hydrogen in the adjacent position, was used as a reference and the resulting K value defined as K 0. The log of K/K 0 for each ligand was plotted against the corresponding Hammett σpara value, as obtained from the literature. The Hammett σ value is a measure of a substituent’s ability to influence the rate of a reaction due to electron donation or withdrawing.
elements.clean_text: To investigate this hypothesis, the authors performed DFT calculations on a series of oximate-derived ligands, coordinated in an η2-fashion to uranyl. Substituents adjacent to the oxime were selected on the basis of their electron donating character via resonance, with Gibbs Free Energies (ΔG) for uranyl binding calculated by DFT and used to determine the equilibrium constant K, assuming a temperature of 298 K. The unfunctionalized acetoxime ligand, with hydrogen in the adjacent position, was used as a reference and the resulting K value defined as K 0. The log of K/K 0 for each ligand was plotted against the corresponding Hammett σpara value, as obtained from the literature. The Hammett σ value is a measure of a substituent's ability to influence the rate of a reaction due to electron donation or withdrawing.

elements.content: The plot of log­(K/K 0) revealed a direct correlation between uranyl binding strength and the electron donating properties of the adjacent substituent (). Functionalized with a nitro group, a strongly electron withdrawing substituent with σpara value of 0.78, nitrooxime bound uranyl with a ΔG of −27.34 kcal mol–1. In contrast, when functionalized with one methyl group and possessing a σpara value of −0.75, monomethylamidoxime bound uranyl with a ΔG of −56.45 kcal mol–1. The noteworthy exception to this trend was dimethylamidoxime, which possessed the strongest σpara value of −0.83, yet bound uranyl with a ΔG of −54.63 kcal mol–1. The authors rationalized this discrepancy by observing steric interactions from the one methyl group resulted in disruption of the conjugated π-orbitals, reducing the effective electron donation.

The point corresponding to the dimethyl amine substituent (N­(Me)2) was not included due to sterically induced distortion in orbital conjugation. Inset: the scope of oximate-derived ligands. elements.content: Continuing this line of reasoning, the authors suggested an imidazole-derived oxime would display enhanced bond strength with uranyl. Computationally this was observed, as an [UO2(imidazole oxime)­(H2O)3]+ complex achieved a bond strength of −60.92 kcal mol–1. However, the authors noted instability of this complex was reported in previous literature, and subsequently suggested a reduced imidazolidine-oximate ligand which would display enhanced stability and bond strength of −58.06 kcal mol–1.
