However, the authors noted instability of this complex was reported in previous literature, and subsequently suggested a reduced imidazolidine-oximate ligand which would display enhanced stability and bond strength of -58.06 kcal mol-1.

elements.content: Design of host structures capable of selective guest binding is a central area of research in the subdiscipline of supramolecular chemistry. Such chemical recognition is achieved when three criteria are met. First, the host structure must contain at least two binding sites that interact favorably with the intended guest. Second, the host must provide a “complementary array” of these binding sites for interacting with the guest. That is, the binding species must be oriented in such a fashion as to simultaneously bind the guest. Finally, preorganization of the complementary array is necessary or at least a minimal number of stable conformations should be achievable for the host, with the ideal conformation low in energy relative to the alternatives. The application of such structure-based approaches can compensate for modest affinity, achieving strong uranium binding through cooperative interactions. This was clearly demonstrated through development of engineered proteins, where weakly coordinating atoms were oriented to form a uranyl binding pocket, achieving femtomolar affinity for uranium.
elements.clean_text:
De Novo Design and Synthesis of Uranyl Chelating Ligands

Design of host structures capable of selective guest binding is a central area of research in the subdiscipline of supramolecular chemistry. Such chemical recognition is achieved when three criteria are met. First, the host structure must contain at least two binding sites that interact favorably with the intended guest. Second, the host must provide a "complementary array" of these binding sites for interacting with the guest. That is, the binding species must be oriented in such a fashion as to simultaneously bind the guest. Finally, preorganization of the complementary array is necessary or at least a minimal number of stable conformations should be achievable for the host, with the ideal conformation low in energy relative to the alternatives. The application of such structure-based approaches can compensate for modest affinity, achieving strong uranium binding through cooperative interactions. This was clearly demonstrated through development of engineered proteins, where weakly coordinating atoms were oriented to form a uranyl binding pocket, achieving femtomolar affinity for uranium.

elements.content: Upon identification of the η2-motif as a valid configuration for uranyl binding, rational design of a selective chelating ligand could be pursued. Binding sites with uranyl were identified as the equatorial plane, and 2–3 AO ligands could readily constitute the complementary array of binding moieties. However, identification of the host architecture necessary to preorganize the AO functionalities remained a challenge. The software HostDesigner was initially developed by Hay and colleagues and subsequently adapted for the design of anionic hosts and the design of high-symmetry molecular polyhedra. Starting from an appropriate array of binding sites located at optimized positions around the intended guest, the software identifies host architectures by assembling structures from user-defined input fragments to achieve the appropriate preorganized arrangement for optimally binding host molecule. Once HostDesigner had identified the best candidates from a geometrical perspective, subsequent molecular mechanics analyses refined the top contenders.
elements.clean_text: Upon identification of the η2-motif as a valid configuration for uranyl binding, rational design of a selective chelating ligand could be pursued. Binding sites with uranyl were identified as the equatorial plane, and 2-3 AO ligands could readily constitute the complementary array of binding moieties. However, identification of the host architecture necessary to preorganize the AO functionalities remained a challenge. The software HostDesigner was initially developed by Hay and colleagues and subsequently adapted for the design of anionic hosts and the design of high-symmetry molecular polyhedra. Starting from an appropriate array of binding sites located at optimized positions around the intended guest, the software identifies host architectures by assembling structures from user-defined input fragments to achieve the appropriate preorganized arrangement for optimally binding host molecule. Once HostDesigner had identified the best candidates from a geometrical perspective, subsequent molecular mechanics analyses refined the top contenders.

elements.content: HostDesigner was used to identify promising uranyl receptors by the aforementioned approach. Assuming uranyl forms a tris-carbonate [UO2(CO3)3]4– in seawater, displacement of two carbonates by AO ligands was determined to afford a good model for designing a complementary host. Geometries of [UO2(AO)2(CO3)]2– were optimized by quantum mechanical calculations, affording three potential configurations. While not isoenergetic, the most thermodynamically stable complex was achieved when the AO C–H groups are facing carbonate, requiring an unreasonably long linking molecule. By rotating the AO so the C–H groups face each other, reasonable configurations were able to be obtained, but at a mild energy penalty of 1.56 kcal mol–1. This identification process is depicted graphically in . Structural degrees of freedom were also applied to accommodate some flexibility within the proposed complexes, consisting of ±20° for in-plane angle variation of the AO groups, ±20° for the twist of the AO group, and ±15° for rotation about the N–O bond.
elements.clean_text: HostDesigner was used to identify promising uranyl receptors by the aforementioned approach. Assuming uranyl forms a tris-carbonate [UO2(CO3)3]4- in seawater, displacement of two carbonates by AO ligands was determined to afford a good model for designing a complementary host. Geometries of [UO2(AO)2(CO3)]2- were optimized by quantum mechanical calculations, affording three potential configurations. While not isoenergetic, the most thermodynamically stable complex was achieved when the AO C-H groups are facing carbonate, requiring an unreasonably long linking molecule. By rotating the AO so the C-H groups face each other, reasonable configurations were able to be obtained, but at a mild energy penalty of 1.56 kcal mol-1. This identification process is depicted graphically in . Structural degrees of freedom were also applied to accommodate some flexibility within the proposed complexes, consisting of ±20° for in-plane angle variation of the AO groups, ±20° for the twist of the AO group, and ±15° for rotation about the N-O bond.

elements.content: HostDesigner constructed and scored 180 million geometries in under 20 min to achieve the initial ranking. Subsequent molecular mechanics calculations determined ligand strain upon metal complexation for the top 1000 candidates, reordering as appropriate. Conformational searches performed on the top 200 candidates, resulted in 87 candidates with ΔG rel ≤ 10 kcal mol–1. The top 10 candidates all exhibit ΔG rel ≤ 5 kcal mol–1, with the top scoring candidate 2.7 kcal mol–1. These fragments are displayed in .

elements.content: Qualitative comparison of the top ranked candidates reveals four sp3 or four to five sp2 bridging carbon atoms are necessary to minimize reorganization energy and create a high-scoring host. However, a lack of synthesizability hinders this computer-guided approach. Inclusion of chiral centers demand the costly and laborious preparation of enatiopure precursors. Alkene or diene-comprised hosts are chemically reactive. Further filtering of the results based on synthetic conditions resulted in a series of three candidates for preparation and experimental testing, displayed in . However, these ligands have not been successfully synthesized or grafted onto polymers for subsequent testing as of the time of publication.

elements.content: Understanding the speciation of uranium ions in aqueous solution is the basis for predicting and controlling the behavior of uranium binding and extraction process. This understanding also provides the essential foundation for the rational design of ligands with enhanced uranium ion affinity and selectivity in seawater. Central to this endeavor, an important and fundamental characterization of ligand reactivity involves the determination of equilibrium constants for the formation of simple 1:1 metal:ligand complexes with a series of metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Determination of Binding Constants for Uranium with Amidoxime and Derivatives

Understanding the speciation of uranium ions in aqueous solution is the basis for predicting and controlling the behavior of uranium binding and extraction process. This understanding also provides the essential foundation for the rational design of ligands with enhanced uranium ion affinity and selectivity in seawater. Central to this endeavor, an important and fundamental characterization of ligand reactivity involves the determination of equilibrium constants for the formation of simple 1:1 metal:ligand complexes with a series of metal ions.

elements.content: Such values, which are referred to as stability constants or formation constants, are determined most frequently in aqueous solution. In practice, stability constants are normally defined as the ratio of concentrations rather than activities. In the case of 1:1 complexes, the aqueous stability constant is defined as the concentration of the metal complex, ML, divided by the concentrations of the metal ion, M, and the ligand, L, as shown by . Because they may span many orders of magnitude, stability constants are usually reported in logarithmic form, log K 1. Individual log K 1 values quantify the strength of the metal–ligand interaction and the difference between log K 1 values for two metal ions measures the degree of selectivity. M + L ⇌ ML ⁣ K 1 = [ ML ] [ M ] [ L ]

Individual log K 1 values quantify the strength of the metal-ligand interaction and the difference between log K 1 values for two metal ions measures the degree of selectivity. 1    M + L ⇌ ML ⁣  K 1  =   [ ML ]    [ M ]   [ L ]

elements.content: Applying necessary corrections for using pure H2O as a reference in thermochemical calculations, log K 1 values were calculated for a series of 18 donor ligands binding uranyl and compared with experimental data. These results were then plotted for 13 distinct complexes, spanning almost 17 orders of magnitude. Though calculated log K 1 values were systemically overestimated by up to 39 log units, a plot of experimental log K 1 values versus calculated log K 1 values afford linear correlations with R 2 ≥ 0.950. These results are displayed in .

elements.content: (Left) Plots of experimental log K 1 versus calculated log K 1, as obtained in aqueous solution. Darkened circles are for monoanions, while open circles are dianions. Linear correlations had R 2 values of 0.967 and 0.950 for mono- and dianions and were represented by the equations expt log K 1 = 0.309 × calc log K 1 – 2.047 and expt log K 1 = 0.473 × calc log K 1 – 8.108, respectively. (Right) Plot of experimental log K 1 versus calculated log K 1 for select dianionic uranyl chelating ligands. The linear correlation indicates computational screening can afford a powerful tool for predictive determination of experimental uranyl affinity. Figures reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2015, American Chemical Society.

elements.content: The computationally directed preparation of improved amidoxime functionalities and de novo designed uranyl chelators leverage a powerful tool for the preparation of adsorbents with great promise for enhanced selectivity and uranyl uptake. Furthermore, application of computational screening of uranyl binding provides a powerful tool for identifying small molecules with high affinity for uranyl chelation. Judicious application of these approaches holds great potential for high-throughput computational screening investigations, reducing waste and expediting discovery. Ongoing efforts should be devoted to completing the synthetic work necessary to synthesize N-methylamidoxime and N,N-dimethylamidoxime functionalized polymer adsorbents, as well adsorbents grafted with the uranyl receptors identified by HostDesigner. While exciting results have been obtained from the first round of HostDesigner-based investigation, it is peculiar that only two ligands were considered sufficient to form an array of binding sites. Recent reports indicate structurally based adsorbents can display high affinity for uranyl through cooperative adsorbent interactions, despite possessing individual log K 1 values far below those listed in . Using HostDesigner or similar software to design adsorbents with 3-D structure capable of fully occupying the equatorial coordination sphere should be pursued fervently.

elements.content: One major downside of computationally guided efforts is the challenge and cost of subsequent synthetic confirmation. The fact that, despite a list of 87 candidates, only three ligands were deemed synthetically plausible is a glaring condemnation. Though appropriate from a perspective of fundamental science and publication, identification of host molecules with facile synthetic avenues is vital for implementation of these results to real-world applications.

elements.content: Finally, it is worth commenting that all of the computationally guided efforts are underpinned by several critical assumptions, foremost of which is η2 binding mode between amidoxime and uranyl. As noted in , binding of formamidoxime to uranyl is effectively isoenergetic for η2 and chelating motifs, while acetamidoxime and benzamidoxime prefer η2 mode by only 3 kcal mol–1. This relatively small, computationally determined energy difference should be placed in context. An 11 kcal mol–1 barrier was deemed experimentally feasible for vanadium binding, and the ring flip of cyclohexane, which occurs readily at room temperature, proceeds through a 10 kcal mol–1 half-chair intermediate. Free rotation of ethylene around the σ bond, with the eclipsed conformer 2.9 kcal mol–1 higher in energy than staggered, is similar in energy to the calculated difference between η2 and chelating motifs.

elements.content: While crystal structures confirm η2-binding to be possible, molecular packing interactions can strongly dictate which crystal phases are obtained. Furthermore, while there is apparent agreement between computation and crystallography in terms of bonding motif, there is no consensus regarding the appropriate number of equatorially coordinating aqua ligands. Justification of computational work should not hold a double-standard, claiming the bonding motif is confirmed while ignoring diverging results in coordination number.

elements.content: Importantly, these results are all obtained under extensively controlled, highly idealized circumstances, which may not be representative of complex, dynamic conditions present for amorphous polymers deployed in environmental seawater. Indeed, recent work using X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy attempted to validate the use of small molecule standards to predict uranyl bonding on an amidoxime-functionalized polymer. However, as shown in , the extended XAFS (EXAFS) spectra reveal distinct differences between the uranium coordination environment for small molecule standards and adsorbent-bound uranyl.

Indeed, recent work using X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy attempted to validate the use of small molecule standards to predict uranyl bonding on an amidoxime-functionalized polymer. However, as shown in , the extended XAFS (EXAFS) spectra reveal distinct differences between the uranium coordination environment for small molecule standards and adsorbent-bound uranyl.

elements.content: Comparison of EXAFS spectra for seawater-contacted adsorbent, simulant-contacted adsorbent, UO2(glutarimidedioxime)2 small molecule standard, and UO2(benzamidoxime)2(MeOH)2 small molecule standard. Elution refers to a 1 h soak in dilute HCl, eluting weakly bound transition metals. These spectra show the uranium coordination environment on adsorbents to be distinctly different from both motifs displayed by small molecule standards. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, Royal Society of Chemistry.

Elution refers to a 1 h soak in dilute HCl, eluting weakly bound transition metals. These spectra show the uranium coordination environment on adsorbents to be distinctly different from both motifs displayed by small molecule standards. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016, Royal Society of Chemistry.

elements.content: While previous small molecule and computational research suggested cyclized amidoxime groups are responsible for uranyl binding, no contribution from this binding motif was observed by EXAFS. In contrast to research proposing single functionalities could bind uranyl, EXAFS fits revealed a coordination environment with at least two binding ligands. Importantly, the uranyl coordination environment is distinctly different depending on whether adsorbents were contacted with seawater simulant or environmental seawater, with environmental seawater spectra possessing features indicative of an adjacent metal forming an oxo-bridge with uranium. This work casts doubt on the assumption that small molecule and computationally guided investigations are representative of complex polymeric systems under environmental conditions.

This work casts doubt on the assumption that small molecule and computationally guided investigations are representative of complex polymeric systems under environmental conditions.

elements.content: Nanostructured materials represent a new category of adsorbents which were not available during initial development of materials for seawater uranium recovery. As such, they are technologically far less mature than the more established adsorbent materials discussed in preceding sections and frequently have not been tested under environmental conditions. With the development of advanced analytical and processing techniques, the ability to synthesize, modify, and functionalize materials on the nanoscale regime allows an unprecedented ability to engineer materials for specific applications. A much larger proportion of nanomaterials are surface-accessible than a comparable quantity of bulk material. This intrinsic characteristic engenders nanomaterials and nanostructured materials with several key properties, including high surface areas, high binding site densities, and rapid mass transport properties. These features are expected to facilitate uranyl extraction selectivity, kinetics, and capacity, perhaps even to the extent that one day they may replace polymer-based adsorbents as the benchmark technology for this application. Despite the vast promise afforded by accessing nanoscale regimes, such materials are not technologically mature and significant additional research emphasis is necessary prior to their meaningful application as uranium adsorbents.
elements.clean_text:
Nanostructured Materials

Nanostructured materials represent a new category of adsorbents which were not available during initial development of materials for seawater uranium recovery. As such, they are technologically far less mature than the more established adsorbent materials discussed in preceding sections and frequently have not been tested under environmental conditions. With the development of advanced analytical and processing techniques, the ability to synthesize, modify, and functionalize materials on the nanoscale regime allows an unprecedented ability to engineer materials for specific applications. A much larger proportion of nanomaterials are surface-accessible than a comparable quantity of bulk material. This intrinsic characteristic engenders nanomaterials and nanostructured materials with several key properties, including high surface areas, high binding site densities, and rapid mass transport properties. These features are expected to facilitate uranyl extraction selectivity, kinetics, and capacity, perhaps even to the extent that one day they may replace polymer-based adsorbents as the benchmark technology for this application. Despite the vast promise afforded by accessing nanoscale regimes, such materials are not technologically mature and significant additional research emphasis is necessary prior to their meaningful application as uranium adsorbents.

elements.content: Activated carbons provide an exciting platform for the development of new uranyl adsorbents. Prior to functionalization, they display minimal background sorption and are sufficiently stable for deployment in environmental seawater without risk of degradation. Due to preparation by a variety of routes, pore architectures can be tuned and systematically investigated. Often possessing surface areas from 250–3000 m2 g–1 and capable of processing into monolithic materials or sheets, they show significant promise as effective sorbents for extracting uranium from seawater.
elements.clean_text:
Porous Carbon

Activated carbons provide an exciting platform for the development of new uranyl adsorbents. Prior to functionalization, they display minimal background sorption and are sufficiently stable for deployment in environmental seawater without risk of degradation. Due to preparation by a variety of routes, pore architectures can be tuned and systematically investigated. Often possessing surface areas from 250-3000 m2 g-1 and capable of processing into monolithic materials or sheets, they show significant promise as effective sorbents for extracting uranium from seawater.

elements.content: The first instance of functionalized carbon for extraction of uranium was by Starvin et al. in 2004. An activated carbon compound was functionalized with diarylazobisphenol through treatment in an aqueous solution, similar to previously reported functionalization of single-wall carbon nanotubes through chemical modification with a diazonium compound. No information is provided regarding surface area coverage or even characterization of the carbon material. It was packed into a column and investigated for preconcentration of uranium in the pH range of 4–5, saturating at approximately 18 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent.
elements.clean_text: The first instance of functionalized carbon for extraction of uranium was by Starvin et al. in 2004. An activated carbon compound was functionalized with diarylazobisphenol through treatment in an aqueous solution, similar to previously reported functionalization of single-wall carbon nanotubes through chemical modification with a diazonium compound. No information is provided regarding surface area coverage or even characterization of the carbon material. It was packed into a column and investigated for preconcentration of uranium in the pH range of 4-5, saturating at approximately 18 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent.

elements.content: Unfunctionalized activated carbon was also investigated for batch adsorption. Varying contact time, pH, concentration of uranium, and temperature, a maximum uptake of 28 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained at pH 3 and 20 °C with 4 h contact time. Uranium sorption was observed to decrease significantly below pH 2 and above pH 6. It was suggested optimal saturation occurs at pH 3 because this is the acidity at which “free” uranium is maximized, meaning uranyl speciates to a penta–aqua complex and there is minimal formation of dimers or tetramers. Sorption data were not collected above pH 7, but this study reveals negligible sorption would be expected by unfunctionalized activated carbon under seawater conditions.
elements.clean_text: Unfunctionalized activated carbon was also investigated for batch adsorption. Varying contact time, pH, concentration of uranium, and temperature, a maximum uptake of 28 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained at pH 3 and 20 °C with 4 h contact time. Uranium sorption was observed to decrease significantly below pH 2 and above pH 6. It was suggested optimal saturation occurs at pH 3 because this is the acidity at which "free" uranium is maximized, meaning uranyl speciates to a penta-aqua complex and there is minimal formation of dimers or tetramers. Sorption data were not collected above pH 7, but this study reveals negligible sorption would be expected by unfunctionalized activated carbon under seawater conditions.

elements.content: Electrosorption using activated carbon slurries prepared with polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) has also been studied. This technique utilizes the conductivity of the carbon to extract ions through isolation within the electrical double layer formed when a bias potential is applied to the electrodes. Through optimizing the applied potential at +0.4 V (), uranyl can be selectively separated from seawater. A capacity after 300 min of applied potential was reported as 3.4 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, comparable to high surface area adsorbents recently developed at ORNL. The authors speculate that no cationic species is adsorbed; therefore, the triscarbonatouranyl­(VI) anion must be the electrosorbed species. However, the calcium and magnesium response, two cations reported to have strong binding affinity to the triscarbonatouranyl­(VI) anion, do not appear to increase with the uranium uptake. While this work is promising, more work is required due to the large decrease in surface area from the use of 50 wt % binder (PVDF) to stabilize the activated carbon electrode. Further work is required to understand the electrosorption process and further characterize the ion extraction as no high valent metals are discussed outside of uranium. The high oxidation state transition metals should be electrosorbed as well and will impact the reported economics of the process.

elements.clean_text: 70  Electrosorption of uranium from seawater as a function of applied potential (vs Ag/AgCl). Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2015, Elsevier.

elements.content: Very recently, Cui and co-workers reported the application of an amidoxime-functionalized conducting carbon electrode in a half-wave rectified alternating current electrochemical (HW-ACE) method for the extraction of seawater uranium. As noted by the authors, conventional physicochemical adsorption of uranyl is limited due to slow diffusion of uranyl ions due to low seawater uranium concentration, poor binding site accessibility due to Coulombinc repulsion from adjacent bound metals, and strong competition from other ubiquitous seawater cations, such as sodium and calcium (). In contrast to traditional electrosorptive approaches, HW-ACE uses an electric field to guide the migration of the uranyl ions, preconcentrating the solution surrounding the electrode. The amidoxime functionalities then readily bind the uranium, demonstrating enhancements in selectivity, kinetics, and uptake.
elements.clean_text: Very recently, Cui and co-workers reported the application of an amidoxime-functionalized conducting carbon electrode in a half-wave rectified alternating current electrochemical (HW-ACE) method for the extraction of seawater uranium. As noted by the authors, conventional physicochemical adsorption of uranyl is limited due to slow diffusion of uranyl ions due to low seawater uranium concentration, poor binding site accessibility due to Coulombinc repulsion from adjacent bound metals, and strong competition from other ubiquitous seawater cations, such as sodium and calcium (). In contrast to traditional electrosorptive approaches, HW-ACE uses an electric field to guide the migration of the uranyl ions, preconcentrating the solution surrounding the electrode. The amidoxime functionalities then readily bind the uranium, demonstrating enhancements in selectivity, kinetics, and uptake.

elements.content: Depiction of difficulties in traditional physicochemical adsorption of uranium by receptor-functionalized adsorbents, and mechanism of the HW-ACE extraction approach. Panel (a) displays uranyl repulsed by Coulombic forces of other bound ions, and panel (b) displays the competition between uranyl and other ubiquitous seawater cations. Panel (c) depicts the HW-ACE method, where a voltage applied to the amidoxime-functionalized carbon electrode alternates between a negative value and zero, resulting in concentration and selective binding of uranium. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2017, Nature Publishing Group.
elements.clean_text: 71  Depiction of difficulties in traditional physicochemical adsorption of uranium by receptor-functionalized adsorbents, and mechanism of the HW-ACE extraction approach. Panel (a) displays uranyl repulsed by Coulombic forces of other bound ions, and panel (b) displays the competition between uranyl and other ubiquitous seawater cations. Panel (c) depicts the HW-ACE method, where a voltage applied to the amidoxime-functionalized carbon electrode alternates between a negative value and zero, resulting in concentration and selective binding of uranium. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2017, Nature Publishing Group.

elements.content: As displayed in , adsorption by a HW-ACE method can be conceptualized as a sequence of five repeating steps, which correspond with the cycling of the bias on the electrode. Step I shows randomized ions in a seawater solution, prior to application of the bias, while step II depicts the application of a negative bias, inducing the migration of the ions and formation of an electrical double layer. Notably, application of a negative bias requires the adsorption of cations, UO2 2+, rather than the anionic UO2(CO3)3 4– reported in previous work. Step III reveals the binding and deposition of uranium on the surface of the electrode. Due to the presence of the amidoxime functionality on the surface of the carbon electrode, only uranium remains bound upon removal of the bias, while other ions redisperse in solution. Step V reveals further growth of uranyl as a function of more cycles.
elements.clean_text: As displayed in , adsorption by a HW-ACE method can be conceptualized as a sequence of five repeating steps, which correspond with the cycling of the bias on the electrode. Step I shows randomized ions in a seawater solution, prior to application of the bias, while step II depicts the application of a negative bias, inducing the migration of the ions and formation of an electrical double layer. Notably, application of a negative bias requires the adsorption of cations, UO2 2+, rather than the anionic UO2(CO3)3 4- reported in previous work. Step III reveals the binding and deposition of uranium on the surface of the electrode. Due to the presence of the amidoxime functionality on the surface of the carbon electrode, only uranium remains bound upon removal of the bias, while other ions redisperse in solution. Step V reveals further growth of uranyl as a function of more cycles.

elements.content: The authors first tested the amidoxime-functionalized carbon electrode and HW-ACE method in seawater spiked with uranium concentrations ranging from 150 ppb to 2000 ppm, revealing the formation of (UO2)­O2·2H2O crystals on the surface of the electrode. In a head-to-head comparison against pure physicochemical adsorption, performance improvements through application of the HW-ACE approach were obvious. Near 100% recovery of uranium was achieved by HW-ACE across all concentrations, while physicochemical adsorption varied from approximately 10% to 80%, as displayed in . The difference in performance was also observed by EDX using a poly­(amidoxime)-coated electrode patterned with parallel Pt lines on an insulating quartz substrate. After extraction of uranium, EDX mapping clearly revealed uranium binding to map directly on the conduction Pt pattern on the electrode (), confirming that the application of the bias and resulting uranium concentration resulted in the improved uranium uptake. When subsequently tested in filtered, unspiked, environmental seawater, the HW-ACE approach achieved a uranium uptake of 1.62 μg, compared to 0.55 μg for physicochemical adsorption.

After extraction of uranium, EDX mapping clearly revealed uranium binding to map directly on the conduction Pt pattern on the electrode (), confirming that the application of the bias and resulting uranium concentration resulted in the improved uranium uptake. When subsequently tested in filtered, unspiked, environmental seawater, the HW-ACE approach achieved a uranium uptake of 1.62 μg, compared to 0.55 μg for physicochemical adsorption.

elements.content: Uptake of uranium from spiked seawater using the HW-ACE method (orange) and traditional physicochemical adsorption (purple). Performance was analyzed for initial uranium concentrations of (a) 150 ppb, (b) 1.5 ppm, (c) 15 ppm, (d) 400 ppm, (e) 1000 ppm, and (f) 2000 ppm. The bottom right plot shows a schematic of the patterned electrode, with accompanying SEM image (top right) and EDX maps for Pt (bottom left) and uranium (bottom right) following uranium adsorption by the HW-ACE method. elements.content: Benzoylthiourea-functionalized activated carbons were prepared through in situ generation of diazonium cations. These materials were investigated for uranyl sorption from pH 1–5, with differing speciation of uranyl again providing the rationale for why sorption was not continued to environmental pH. A saturation capacity of 82 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained, which surpassed the unmodified activated carbon by three times. The binding motif for the benzoylthiourea-functionalized carbon was proposed to be chelation of one uranyl by two cooperating benzoylthiourea functionalities through the carboxylic oxygen and thiourea sulfur, while the imide and amine nitrogen were proposed to be Lewis bases donating electron pairs to other uranyl molecules.
elements.clean_text: Benzoylthiourea-functionalized activated carbons were prepared through in situ generation of diazonium cations. These materials were investigated for uranyl sorption from pH 1-5, with differing speciation of uranyl again providing the rationale for why sorption was not continued to environmental pH. A saturation capacity of 82 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained, which surpassed the unmodified activated carbon by three times. The binding motif for the benzoylthiourea-functionalized carbon was proposed to be chelation of one uranyl by two cooperating benzoylthiourea functionalities through the carboxylic oxygen and thiourea sulfur, while the imide and amine nitrogen were proposed to be Lewis bases donating electron pairs to other uranyl molecules.

elements.content: CMK-3, a nanoporous ordered carbon, was functionalized with a carboxymethylated polyethylenimine substrate. Upon functionalization, the surface area of the material decreased by approximately 50%, while degree of functionalization was estimated at 24% by total organic carbon analysis. Sorption isotherms displayed good sorption from pH 3–4, with saturation capacities of 119 and 222 mg g–1, respectively. It was proposed further deprotonation of the imine and carboxylic acids resulted in the improved sorption capacity at higher pH. CMK-3 was also functionalized by oxidation to generate a surface carboxylic acid. A maximum saturation capacity of 190 mg g–1 was observed at pH 5.5, decreasing to 160 mg g–1 at pH 7.5. Interestingly, the pristine CMK-3 also displayed a maximum sorption capacity of 120 mg g–1 at pH 6, decreasing to 90 mg g–1 at pH 7.5.

elements.content: A related activated carbon material, CMK-5, was functionalized with 4-acetophenone oxime by thermally induced diazonitization with isoamyl nitrite (). Batch sorption experiments were performed to investigate uranyl sorption from simulated effluent from nuclear processing. The simulant contained multiple competing di- and trivalent transition metals as well as several lanthanides. While poor sorption was observed below pH 3, a maximum sorption capacity around 65 mg g–1 was obtained at pH 4.5. This was rationalized by the extent to which the oxime could be deprotonated, forming a proposed uranyl complex of four equatorial monodentate-coordinating oxime ligands.

elements.content: A salicylaldeneimine-functionalized hydrothermal carbon was prepared by functionalizing an activated hydrothermal carbon with ethylenediamine. Condensation with salicylaldehyde resulted in the final material, which was investigated for extraction of uranyl over the pH range of <1–4.5. Uptake increased with increasing pH, with a maximum uptake of 261 mg g–1 obtained at pH 4.3, while kinetic studies revealed more than 80% of the total adsorption occurred in the first minute. Competitive adsorption of uranyl from simulated nuclear processing effluent revealed remarkable selectivity for uranyl, with a K d of approximately 9.5 × 104 mL g–1.

elements.content: In an effort to provide a more direct basis for comparison, Carboni et al. prepared a library of organic functional groups and grafted them to commercially available mesoporous carbon through formation of in situ diazonium cations (). Containing many functional groups investigated on MS materials by Vivero-Escoto, a similar result was obtained: a phosphylated mesoporous carbon material possessed the highest sorption capacity, at both pH 4 and 8.2. Saturation capacities of 85 and 50 mg g–1 were obtained under these conditions, respectively. Not surprisingly, sorption of uranyl was pH-dependent, with a dramatic increase observed above pH 3.5 attributed to the first deprotonation of the surface phosphoryl groups.

elements.content: Sonochemical grafting of AN into mesoporous carbon was also pursued for development of uranyl-extracting materials. The authors report an increase in degree of grafting through sonochemical approaches compared to efforts with free radical polymerization. They propose pore blockage occurs during free radical polymerization, but penetration of the monomer is encouraged through sonication. The authors reported that a high intensity ultrasonication, using an ultrasonic horn as the source, provided more conformal polymer coatings within the pores compared to the standard lab bath ultrasound. This was observed through the nitrogen sorption isotherms where a hysteresis of the lab bath ultrasound was extended instead of sharply closing, as in the case of the high intensity ultrasound, a phenomenon attributed to pore constrictions (). Homogeneous polymerization of poly­(AN) throughout the mesoporous material was coupled with nitric acid surface oxidation and CO2 pore activation to achieve enhanced sorbent performance. Modest sorption capacities of <1–4 mg g–1 were obtained, but these experiments were performed in a seawater simulant at pH 8.2 with carbonate sources, which typically reduces sorption dramatically.

elements.content: To overcome the low capacities observed by mesoporous carbons, a combination of templating techniques were utilized to generate hierarchical porosity. Hard templating with uniform silica spheres was used to generate large mesopores of 35 and 50 nm average diameters along with 85 nm average diameter macropores. This was coupled with soft templating to generate an average 10 nm mesopore. The carbons were then further activated with flowing carbon dioxide (CO2) at high temperature to induce microporosity. This stepwise synthesis allows for tailoring the porosity. Upon increasing the largest pore size from 10 to 35 nm, a significant increase in polymer grafting and subsequent uranium capacity was observed. Increasing the pore size to 50 nm enhanced the increase in capacity. When 85 nm pores were introduced with the 10 nm mesopore and microporosity, the polymer grafting percentage decreased with an increase in the uranium capacity. This is believed to be due to better accessibility resulting in greater utilization of the polymer graft allowed by the larger pores. The stepwise approach also facilitated the understanding of the pore regime, i.e., micro-, meso-, or macroporosity, on the uranium sorption capacity. It was observed () that the microporosity, while good at providing anchor points for the polymer within the nanostructure, did not contribute significantly to the overall capacity of the sorbent. This is most likely due to the size of the uranyl ion. The triscarbonatouranyl­(VI) anion has a diameter that is approximately 0.8 nm equatorially and 0.6 nm axially. This represents a bulky anion that can significantly block microporosity thereby negating the rest of the polymer in the micropores. It was also determined that the larger pores are required as the mesoporosity did not significantly contribute to the overall capacity.

Mayes and colleagues subsequently reported a systematic study investigating the impact of pore size on uranyl adsorption by mesoporous carbon materials. Applying the aforementioned sonochemical polymerization technique, poly­(AN) (later modified to form amidoxime sites) was polymerized from carbon supports which had been rationally modified to exclude mesoporosity, microporosity, or macroporosity. The authors observed N2-adsorption isotherm surface area measurements were not representative of uranium-binding performance nor was the polymer Dg. However, pore size and the accompanying curvature of the pore wall were directly correlated with uranium extraction. While affording large specific surface areas, microporosity was detrimental to uranium capacity, putatively due to pore-filling or the inability of uranyl to access buried amidoxime binding sites. In contrast, mesoporosity and macroporosity were both advantageous to achieving good performance.

elements.content: Carbon nanotubes have also been investigated for uranium sorption. First reports involve acid treatment for enhancing colloidal stability, with sorption capacities of approximately 45 mg g–1 achieved at pH 5. Similar results were obtained by oxidation of multiwalled carbon nanotubes, affording a sorption capacity of 36 mg g–1. Finally, carboxymethyl cellulose was also attached to the surface of multiwalled carbon nanotubes by plasma induced grafting. After exposure to an N2 plasma, the nanotubes were combined with carboxymethyl cellulose and heated to 80 °C for 1 week with stirring. Sorption isotherms obtained at pH 5 yield a sorption capacity of approximately 110 mg g–1.

elements.content: Very recently, a graphene oxide (GO)/amidoxime hydrogel adsorbent was developed for the removal of uranium from aqueous solution, including seawater simulant. Amino acids, polyamines, and metformin possess multiple nitrogen basic moieties which bind with carboxylic or alcohol groups on GO sheets, forming hydrogels. Iminodiacetonitirle (IDAN) was treated with hydroxylamine to form the amidoxime derivative, AO-IDAN, which was then used as a cross-linking agent in the GO dispersion. Uranium adsorption experiments reveal pH affects performance significantly, with maximum uptake achieved from pH 5–7. A slight decrease was observed at pH 8, followed by a precipitous drop at higher pH. When contacted with a 3.7 ppb uranium seawater simulant at a phase ratio of 0.5 mg L–1, the hydrogel adsorbed 88% of the uranium in solution, affording an uptake of 0.006 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 6 h. An isotherm performed at pH 6 yields a saturation capacity of 398 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent.

elements.content:
summarizes the uranium adsorption performance by nanostructured carbon-based adsorbents.

Mesoporous ATRP Initiators for Advanced Adsorbents

An exciting development in the preparation of nanostructured materials for uranyl extraction is the preparation of mesoporous heterogeneous supports from copolymerization of divinylbenzene and vinylbenzyl chloride. These materials previously had been developed for other separations processes and catalysis, and varying the ratio of comonomers is known to afford final materials with controllable porosity and high surface areas without the use of porogens. In addition to providing a desirable support, the readily accessible and homogeneously distributed chlorides were used as initiators for atom-transfer radical polymerization of poly­(AN). Treatment with hydroxylamine resulted in conversion to amidoxime functionalities for uranyl sequestration.

Applying this process yielded supports with degree of grafting ranging from 280–509 wt %, displaying a linear correlation with density of initiator sites. The authors do note extensive grafting may ultimately fill or block mesopores, a phenomenon discussed previously regarding functionalization of mesoporous carbon. Deployment of the mesoporous copolymer sorbents in simulated seawater at environmental pH resulted in adsorption capacities as high as 80 mg g–1, surpassing that of four commercially available adsorbent materials (12–50 mg g–1) and that of nonwoven amidoxime-functionalized polyethylene fabric (0.75 mg g–1). Batch experiments involving 5 gallons of seawater were performed using the ATRP-grafted mesoporous polymer. A uptake behavior of the mesoporous polymer sorbent, 0.33 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent/day, was observed with a moderate capacity of 1.99 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. This behavior is similar to that of an poly­(amidoxime-co-MA) sorbent produced by ORNL (0.30 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent/day).

elements.content: AN/AA comonomers were also copolymerized with DVB on a mesoporous carbon framework, initiated thermally with an AIBN activator. The ratio of AN:AA:DVB was maintained at 7:2:1 (w/w) while the carbon:monomer ratios were varied from 1:3 to 1:25. Screening of uranium uptake was performed following conversion of the nitrile groups to amidoximes via treatment with hydroxylamine. Approximately 15 mg of adsorbents were suspended in 250 mL of a 700 ppb uranium brine solution for 24 h. The highest screening capacity of 63 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved for a 1:12 carbon:monomer ratio, though performance by 1:15, 1:20, and 1:25 were similar. The material possessing a 1:12 carbon:monomer ratio was investigated for recovery of uranium from 5 gallons of filtered environmental seawater over 4 weeks via a batch contact, affording an uptake of 0.55 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent.

elements.content:
summarizes the performance of graft polymers generated on porous carbon supports by ATRP.

Metal–Organic Frameworks (MOFs)

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous materials formed by the reaction of organic ligand struts with metal cluster nodes to form infinite 1-, 2-, or 3-D networks. Often displaying extremely high surface areas (with some surpassing 6000 m2 g–1) and porosities (up to 90% free volume), this new class of materials has been of great interest in recent years. Unlike traditional coordination polymers, MOFs possess extensive long-range ordering and can be readily characterized by crystallography, facilitating the study of structure–activity relationships. The ability to extend the length of the organic struts while retaining the overall material topology, known as isoreticular synthesis, enables the tuning of pore and channel structure to target desired applications. Finally, orthogonal functionalities can be included through direct synthesis or postsynthetic modification (PSM) to engender desirable properties to MOFs which would otherwise be chemically inert.

Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs)

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous materials formed by the reaction of organic ligand struts with metal cluster nodes to form infinite 1-, 2-, or 3-D networks. Often displaying extremely high surface areas (with some surpassing 6000 m2 g-1) and porosities (up to 90% free volume), this new class of materials has been of great interest in recent years. Unlike traditional coordination polymers, MOFs possess extensive long-range ordering and can be readily characterized by crystallography, facilitating the study of structure-activity relationships. The ability to extend the length of the organic struts while retaining the overall material topology, known as isoreticular synthesis, enables the tuning of pore and channel structure to target desired applications. Finally, orthogonal functionalities can be included through direct synthesis or postsynthetic modification (PSM) to engender desirable properties to MOFs which would otherwise be chemically inert.

Composition of solution: 10123 ppm of Na+, 15529 ppm of Cl–, 140 ppm of HCO3 –, 250 mL of solution

While these three fundamental characteristics have made MOFs interesting for a wide range of potential applications, they also suffer from several significant drawbacks, limiting their application as solid-phase adsorbent materials. Most notably, the relatively weak and labile metal–ligand coordination bonds make chemical stability a routine challenge, and displacement of organic bridging ligands from MOF templates has even been harnessed as a way to prepare porous inorganic materials under mild conditions. While design of complex and intricate organic struts can be easily proposed, the synthetic challenge of their preparation must not be neglected, and thus far the industrial-scale synthesis of MOFs has only been pursued with simple, commercially available ligands. Moreover, incorporation of orthogonal functionalities capable of strongly chelating metals is extremely difficult, due to the solvothermal synthetic routes commonly implemented to prepare MOFs. Direct synthesis will result in the occupation of the metal-chelating site by the metal intended to form the MOF node (also referred to as the Secondary Building Unit, or SBU). Besides preventing the chelation of subsequent metals, this also reduces the efficiency of the MOF preparation, if not prohibiting it outright. Finally, MOFs are not generally amenable to environmental deployment due to small particle size. A method for synthesizing MOF monoliths has not been developed, requiring some additional form of large-scale support for deployment in seawater, which undermines the high surface areas enabled by using mesoscale nanostructured materials.

elements.content: Several publications have nevertheless reported the use of MOFs extraction of uranyl from aqueous solutions, with proposed applications either in separation of radionuclides or seawater mining. Two reports submitted and published almost simultaneously constitute the initial foray into this burgeoning new field of investigation: Lin et al. reported the use of a phosphate-functionalized UiO-68­(Zr) MOF, while Wang et al. articulated the use of unfunctionalized HKUST-1­(Cu). Despite nearly identical publication dates, these two papers delineate fundamentally different approaches to designing MOFs for uranium binding. While the former relies upon inclusion of a rationally designed organic strut, providing a specific binding site, the latter utilizes a pristine MOF with nonspecific binding presumably occurring at the SBU. These two strategies are discussed below, as are the publications in which they are utilized.

Despite nearly identical publication dates, these two papers delineate fundamentally different approaches to designing MOFs for uranium binding. These two strategies are discussed below, as are the publications in which they are utilized.

elements.content: Lin and colleagues are generally credited with the first report of a MOF used for extraction of uranium from seawater. A Zr-MOF, UiO-68, was synthesized containing an orthogonal diethoxyphosphoryl-urea moiety which orients into the framework tetrahedra to minimize steric interactions (1). Deprotection of the ethoxy groups to yield the phosphate analogue was accomplished by treating with Me3SiBr and subsequent hydrolysis in water (2). While NMR analysis of a decomposed MOF revealed only ∼66% deprotection was achievable, this approach was necessary due to the synthetic limitations of the MOF. Direct synthesis of Zr- MOFs with phosphate-functionalized ligands is untenable, due to the extremely strong binding of Zr with phosphates. The unfunctionalized UiO-68-NH2 (3) was also prepared and investigated as a control. A scheme depicting the preparation and structure of MOFs 1–3 is displayed as .
elements.clean_text:
Orthogonally-Functionalized MOFs

Lin and colleagues are generally credited with the first report of a MOF used for extraction of uranium from seawater. A Zr-MOF, UiO-68, was synthesized containing an orthogonal diethoxyphosphoryl-urea moiety which orients into the framework tetrahedra to minimize steric interactions (1). Deprotection of the ethoxy groups to yield the phosphate analogue was accomplished by treating with Me3SiBr and subsequent hydrolysis in water (2). While NMR analysis of a decomposed MOF revealed only ~66% deprotection was achievable, this approach was necessary due to the synthetic limitations of the MOF. Direct synthesis of Zr- MOFs with phosphate-functionalized ligands is untenable, due to the extremely strong binding of Zr with phosphates. The unfunctionalized UiO-68-NH2 (3) was also prepared and investigated as a control. A scheme depicting the preparation and structure of MOFs 1-3 is displayed as .

elements.content: (Top) Scheme depicting the synthesis of 1–3. (Bottom) Orthogonal functionalities incorporated in (left) 1 and (right) 2. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2013, Royal Society of Chemistry.

elements.content: All three MOFs were investigated for the extraction of uranium from several aqueous solutions. Measurements were made at pH 2.5 and 5 in DI water, with maximum saturation capacities of 217 and 109 mg of uranium/g of ads obtained at pH 2.5 for 1 and 2, respectively. When the pH was elevated to 5, saturation capacities decreased to 152 and 104 mg of uranium/g of ads accordingly. No uptake was observed for 3 under any conditions. MOFs 1 and 2 were also tested in a seawater simulant containing various sodium salts, carbonate, and both Mg and Ca cations. For both materials, a reduced uptake was observed, with 188 and 32 mg of uranium/g of ads obtained at pH 2.5 for 1 and 2. Isotherms are displayed in . Subsequent DFT calculations suggested the uranium was bound cooperatively by two adjacent ligands through monodentate coordination with the phosphoryl oxygen. This DFT-proposed 2:1 ligand to metal ratio (L:M) was supported by investigation of the uranyl uptake, as experimental L:M of 2:1 and 2.3:1 were obtained for MOF 1 in DI water and seawater simulant, respectively.

elements.content: The Cr MOF MIL-101 was subsequently functionalized and investigated for uranyl extraction. In contrast to the aforementioned work, PSM at several different sites afforded a series of four isoreticular MOFs which were investigated for adsorption of uranium. While MIL-101­(Cr) (4) was prepared by traditional routes, the analogue MIL-101-NH2 (4-NH2) was prepared by exposing 4 to strongly oxidizing acidic conditions and subsequently reducing the in situ generated orthogonal nitro group to a primary amine. MIL-101-ED (4-ED) and MIL-101-DETA (4-DETA) were prepared by the condensation of ethylenediamine (ED) or diethylenetriamine (DETA) with vacant metal sites in the MOF SBU, following removal of coordinating solvent molecules under high temperatures in vacuo. Functionalization of 4-ED and 4-DETA is summarized in . Unlike direct synthesis of a MOF with pre-functionalized ligands, as per Lin et al., PSM typically cannot completely functionalize all sites in the MOF precursor. While the PSM of the aforementioned materials was confirmed by FTIR, TGA, and CHN analysis, 4-NH2, 4-ED, and 4-DETA were only functionalized at 18%, 14%, and 8% of all possible sites, respectively.

elements.content: MOFs 4, 4-NH2, 4-ED, and 4-DETA were investigated for uranium sorption in DI water over the pH range of 3–6. Uptake was negligible for all materials at pH < 4, but rose dramatically up to pH 6, while kinetic studies performed at pH 5.5 revealed rapid saturation of all materials occurred in less than 1 h of contact time. Sorption isotherms, again at pH 5.5 in DI water, afforded saturation capacities of 20, 90, 200, and 350 mg of uranium/g of ads for 4, 4-NH2, 4-ED, and 4-DETA, respectively. These results are displayed in . The authors noted the trend in capacity was inversely correlated with coverage of the functional groups. Though correlation breaks down for 4, which was unfunctionalized, the implication is that sorption is related to the accessibility of the binding sites located in the center of the MOF, in conjunction with the enhanced Lewis basicity of an aliphatic amine (as on 4-ED and 4-DETA) as opposed to an aromatic amine (4-NH2). The flexibility of the binding moiety on the SBU-functionalized 4-ED and 4-DETA was also proposed to enhance uptake.

elements.content: Recycling investigations were performed which confirmed the stability of the adsorbent in aqueous conditions, as well as the potential for reuse after elution of bound uranium. PXRD analysis reveals no change in peak position between the pristine and U-loaded MOFs, while SEM images also attest to the stability of the MOF adsorbent. Despite no apparent physical changes, MOFs 4-ED and 4-DETA showed a decrease of approximately 30% following elution. However, 4-NH2 did not reveal any appreciable loss of uptake. While PXRD spectra of MOFs postelution were not provided, this process was performed by decreasing the pH and MIL-101­(Cr) is known for acid stability; MOF degradation from elution is not likely.

elements.content: Selectivity studies on a series of metals at pH 5.5 were also performed, with high K d values achieved for uranium (>6000 mL g–1) in contrast to relatively low values for competing ions (<100 mL g–1) when all are present at an 0.5 mM initial concentration (). While these results are interesting, the selection of metals contains six lanthanides which are not present in seawater at appreciable concentrations and three transition metals, none of which are known to strongly compete for uranyl-binding sites in previously reported adsorbents. Most conspicuously absent are V, Fe, and Cu from the list of competing metals.

elements.content: The EXAFS spectra of 4-NH2, 4-ED, and 4-DETA were fitted and compared with the spectra for uranyl hydroxide. Both qualitative and quantitative similarities were observed for the spectra of 4-ED and 4-DETA, indicative of a common uranyl bond motif to both materials. In contrast, for 4-NH2, the feature corresponding to the scattering elements in the uranyl equatorial plane was enhanced and attributed to steric hindrance from the aromatic rings in the framework. The bond lengths for U–N scattering decreased, however, which is neither consistent with a sterically hindered complex nor a less active aromatic amine. Moreover, as the fits were only performed on the first uranyl coordination sphere, they are lacking in rigor. This is exacerbated by an inappropriate selection of Rbkg during the data processing, which would diminish quadrature from the tightly bound axial oxygen, distorting the spectrum. Furthermore, EXAFS analysis is unable to discriminate between elements which are ±1 in Z-number, making O and N indistinguishable and the definite assignment of these scattering paths somewhat doubtful as a result. It is possible the chemical identities of these elements could be inferred by fitting the second shell of the uranyl spectra; however, this was not completed for this work.

elements.content: Similar work was reported shortly thereafter by Zhang et al., again using MIL-101­(Cr) and functionalizing at the metal SBU with ED. While much of this report duplicates previous work, the authors do perform sorption experiments up to pH 9, where a dramatic decrease in uptake is observed (). The pH of the sorption solution was adjusted with small amounts of HNO3 or Na2CO3, which suggests that at higher pH there would be an appreciable effect from formation of [UO2(CO3)3]4–. A capacity of approximately 200 mg of uranium/g of ads was obtained for 4-ED at pH 5, essentially identical to previously reported data. The capacity at pH 8 decreased to approximately 150 mg of uranium/g of ads, while at pH 9 the capacity was around 80 mg of uranium/g of ads. Interestingly, negative uptake was reported at pH 2.

elements.content: XAFS spectroscopy was performed at both the Cr K-edge and uranium LIII-edge. X-ray absorption near edge spectra (XANES) analysis revealed broadening of the white line as increasing quantities of ED was bound to the MOF SBU. The authors attribute this phenomenon to gradual occupation of vacant coordination sites around Cr by ED. However, they also note the pre-edge feature is unchanged, regardless of ED functionalization. Pre-edge features for first-row transition metals are attributable to transitions of electrons from the 1s orbital to the 3d orbital. This symmetry-forbidden transition can only occur when 3d and 4p orbitals are hybridized, which is present only for a tetrahedral coordination environment. Occupancy of vacant coordination sites should result in increasing symmetry, reducing the observed pre-edge feature as an octahedral coordination environment is approached. The EXAFS region was fitted for the uranium LIII-edge spectra, but again the second coordination shell was ignored. Dramatically different coordination environments are reported compared to the identical system discussed previously, with the number of scatterers in the equatorial plane fixed at 6 and all scatterers assigned as oxygen. As expected, a large mean squared relative displacement (σ2) value was obtained to accommodate this model. While good R-factors were reported in the publication, obvious mis-fit occurs in this second coordination sphere.

elements.content: The most recent MOF system reported for the extraction of uranium contains Zn atoms as SBUs with a mixture of two bridging ligands: 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), and N 4,N 4′-di­(pyridine-4-yl)­biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxamide (L2). As reported in previous literature, this MOF (5) crystallizes in a chiral hexagonal system composing a racemic bulk sample. The Zn atoms are bound in a tetrahedral geometry by two carboxylate oxygen and two nitrogen from the pyridyl groups on L2. These complexes form infinite 1-D chains with hairpin folds traversing the c axis, creating 1-D hexagonal channels with the inner wall functionalized by carboxylic acids and acylamide moieties, as shown in .

As reported in previous literature, this MOF (5) crystallizes in a chiral hexagonal system composing a racemic bulk sample. The Zn atoms are bound in a tetrahedral geometry by two carboxylate oxygen and two nitrogen from the pyridyl groups on L2. These complexes form infinite 1-D chains with hairpin folds traversing the c axis, creating 1-D hexagonal channels with the inner wall functionalized by carboxylic acids and acylamide moieties, as shown in .

elements.content: Uranium uptake was investigated in DI water at pH 1–5, with a maximum uptake of 92 mg of uranium/g of ads obtained at pH 2 and an uptake of approximately 75 mg of uranium/g of ads obtained at pH 5 (). The authors attribute this decrease to formation of colloidal or oligiomeric species of uranyl, such as (UO2)2(OH)2 2+ or (UO2)4(OH)7 +, inhibiting binding by the pendant functionalities. Though not specifically mentioned, the pore apertures of 7.0–9.4 Å would not accommodate diffusion of colloidal uranium into the MOF interior as the axial diameter of the uranyl tricarbonate anion is approximately 6 Å while the equatorial diameter is approximately 8–9 Å. Due to the optimal uptake obtained at pH 2, subsequent investigations were only performed at that pH.

elements.content: Rapid absorption uptake was observed in a kinetics investigation, with complete uptake achieved in less than 1 min. However, this experimental setup does not provide meaningful information, as the experiment was performed at a concentration where the adsorbent was not saturated. Similar kinetics would be observed for most materials where absorption kinetics are performed below saturation concentrations. Moreover, the instantaneous completion of adsorption casts doubt on the analytical rigor. The only data point which was not 90 ± 5 mg of uranium/g of ads was the data point at t = 0. Moreover, adsorbents were collected by centrifugation for 10 min, which makes the measurements at t < 10 questionable. Subsequent adsorption isotherms reveal a saturation capacity of 126 mg of uranium/g of ads at pH 2 in DI water, despite only having a contact time of 5 min. These results do support rapid uranyl sorption.

elements.content: Elution studies were performed with water, 0.1 M HCl, 0.1 M HNO3, and 0.1 M Na2CO3, which showed >3%, 54%, 82%, and 92% uranium recovered from the adsorbent for each of the eluents, respectively. However, the authors note the MOF was “digested” during the elution process, and no PXRD data were available after elution. The conspicuous absence of these important data suggests this MOF would not be reusable and, more importantly, would not be stable for long-term deployment in environmental seawater. Labile metal–ligand bonding is well established in Zn MOFs, and decomposition is generally to be expected.
elements.clean_text: Elution studies were performed with water, 0.1 M HCl, 0.1 M HNO3, and 0.1 M Na2CO3, which showed >3%, 54%, 82%, and 92% uranium recovered from the adsorbent for each of the eluents, respectively. However, the authors note the MOF was "digested" during the elution process, and no PXRD data were available after elution. The conspicuous absence of these important data suggests this MOF would not be reusable and, more importantly, would not be stable for long-term deployment in environmental seawater. Labile metal-ligand bonding is well established in Zn MOFs, and decomposition is generally to be expected.

elements.content: The authors did investigate the extraction of uranium from environmentally relevant conditions, using a seawater simulant reported elsewhere. The MOF adsorbent was added at a phase ratio of 0.01 g L–1 to 1 L of artificial seawater containing 6 ppb uranium and at a pH of 7.8. The authors then claim uptake of 0.53 mg of uranium/g of ads after 1 min of contact time, using Na2CO3 as an eluent, which equals removal of more than 88% of the uranyl in solution. While these are very encouraging preliminary results, the absence of any specific experimental details is a cause for concern. Previous adsorption measurements were performed with only 10 mL of solution, and adsorbents were collected by centrifugation. It is unreasonable to centrifuge 1 L of solution following the protocol delineated by the authors, and a contact time of 1 min is not possible as discussed above. The authors claim elution of the uranium and reuse of the adsorbent, achieving uptake of 0.51 mg of uranium/g and 0.47 mg of uranium/g for the second and third trials. If the material is removed by filtration, negative controls need to be performed and reported to ensure the uranium is not extracted by the filter or bottle. Finally, the authors indicate ICP-MS analysis of the seawater simulant solution is used to determine uptake. However, ICP-MS analysis of dilute, high-matrix solutions such as seawater requires special considerations for analytical accuracy, as discussed in . Minimal details are provided in this regard, and validation of these results is essential.

elements.content: In contrast to MOFs which have been synthesized or postsynthetically functionalized with orthogonal uranyl-binding moieties, unfunctionalized MOFs have been investigated for extraction of uranium as well. Though there is minimal commentary in the publications, the precise location of uranyl binding is presumably the metal-oxo bonds in the SBU, as the unfunctionalized organic struts are devoid of any uranophilic characteristics.
elements.clean_text:
Unfunctionalized MOFs

In contrast to MOFs which have been synthesized or postsynthetically functionalized with orthogonal uranyl-binding moieties, unfunctionalized MOFs have been investigated for extraction of uranium as well. Though there is minimal commentary in the publications, the precise location of uranyl binding is presumably the metal-oxo bonds in the SBU, as the unfunctionalized organic struts are devoid of any uranophilic characteristics.

elements.content: The first use of an unfunctionalized MOF for uranium extraction was reported by Wang et al., utilizing the iconic Cu MOF HKUST-1 (6). The effect of pH was evaluated over the range of 2–10 in DI water, with capacities of 200 mg of uranium/g of ads achieved until pH 8 (). At pH 10, the adsorption decreased to approximately 140 mg of uranium/g of ads, attributed to formation of [UO2(CO3)2]2– and [UO2(CO3)3]4– from solvation of atmospheric CO2. Adsorption isotherms were performed at pH 6 at 25, 35, and 45 °C, which yielded saturation capacities of 787, 826, and 840 mg of uranium/g of ads when fitted with the Langmuir model. As the Langmuir model assumes monolayer coverage and isolated adsorption sites, the authors assert such an adsorption process must occur. The authors suggest the large number of carboxyl groups coordinating the Cu SBUs provide the uranyl adsorption sites. The SBU adopts a paddle-wheel structure, as is commonplace for Cu MOFs, where four carboxylates and two water molecules coordinate two Cu atoms. Consideration of the solvent-free formula for 6, Cu3(BTC)2, affords a molar ratio of 1.34–1.42 uranium per SBU at saturation.

elements.content: The subsequent generation of unfunctionalized MOFs for uranium extraction was reported by Shi et al., who used MOF-76 with Y SBUs (7) for sorption and Tb SBUs (8) for use as luminescent sensors. Sorption of uranium by 7 in DI water was measured as a function of pH over the range of 2.5 to 6, with the maximum observed around a pH of 3. Stability was checked over the pH range of 2–3, with crystallinity observed by PXRD. While sharp peaks are observed above pH 2.5, the authors note the onset of framework decomposition occurs around pH 2. Stability of 7 above pH 3 was assumed. Presumably investigations were not performed at higher pH due either to the stability of the MOF or due to the relatively small pore apertures (6.6 × 6.6 Å) preventing diffusion of [UO2(CO3)3]4– or uranyl colloids throughout the MOF material.

elements.content: Sorption kinetics were observed at a phase ratio of 0.4 g L–1 and a pH of 3 (). Saturation was observed at approximately 300 min when all of the uranium was extracted from solution. The authors rationalize from the changes in the rate of uptake that the rate of bulk diffusion, surface adsorption, and intraparticle diffusion all contribute to the observed uranium adsorption rate. The adsorption was also obtained for 7 at pH 3 with a phase ratio of 0.4 g L–1 and a contact time of 5 h. A saturation capacity of 298 mg of uranium/g of ads was obtained by fitting the data with the Langmuir model. Finally, extracting from a solution with competing ions assessed the selectivity of 7 for uranium. While still not containing the most environmentally relevant metals (V, Fe, and Cu), selectivity over other metals with appreciable seawater concentration was observed (e.g., Pb, Zn, Sr, and Ni).

elements.content: Synthesis of the isostructural MOF 8 was achieved using Tb to form the SBUs. While uranium adsorption data were not provided, quenching of the suspension luminescence was observed upon introduction of uranyl cations. At a concentration of 0.002 M, luminescence intensity was reduced by 50% and almost eliminated completely at 0.1 M. The authors note this characteristic allows the MOF to be used as a sensor for detecting uranium in aqueous waste; however, limits of detection were not determined. Moreover, the lowest concentration solution for which luminescence quenching was reported is equivalent to 0.5 mg of uranium/mL of solution. As 8 was added at 3 mg mL–1 to perform the luminescence experiments, significant improvements in sensitivity are needed for this MOF-based sensor to be a viable technology.

elements.content: The most recent effort in this field was reported by Yuan et al., who used UiO-66 (9) and the amine-modified UiO-66-NH2 (10) to extract uranium from aqueous solutions. Sorption was first measured as a function of pH over the range of 2–6 (). Low uptake was observed below pH 4, with maxima of 110 and 115 mg of uranium/g of ads achieved at pH 5.5 for 9 and 10, respectively. The authors indicate at lower pH the “active sites” on the sorbents are protonated and positively charged, though what specifically constituted an active site was never defined. Moreover, differences in uptake between 9 and 10 were not statistically significant, leading the authors to conclude introduction of amino functionalities do not enhance uranium sorption significantly. Some form of interaction at the MOF SBU is apparent. These results are of particular interest regarding the interpretation of earlier work presented by Lin et al., as their adsorbents displayed high uptake at pH 2.5 and significantly diminished capacity at pH 5. It is possible the sorption observed at pH 5 is attributable not to binding with the orthogonal phorphorylurea moieties of 1 and 2, but at the SBU as evidenced by sorption by 9 and 10.

elements.content: Uptake was investigated as a function of ionic strength, with NaClO4 added at various concentrations from 10–4 to 10–1 M. While it is not apparent why NaClO4 was used, rather than NaCl, uranium adsorption was not dramatically affected for either 9 or 10. Selectivity was also investigated for uranium over several transition metals and lanthanides. While 9 and 10 had minimal affinity for the competing ions, as in previous work, the most environmentally relevant metals (V, Fe, and Cu) were not investigated.

elements.content: MOFs provide an interesting new platform for the extraction of uranium from aqueous solutions, highlighted by several publications reported in a very short time frame. summarizes the uptakes reported for the MOF systems discussed in this section. Preparation of a MOF-based adsorbent can rely on the presence of orthogonal functionalities, as demonstrated by the phosphorylurea groups of 1 and 2 or carboxylic acid and acrylamide groups of 5, or on advantageous binding to the SBU as evidenced by 6–10. In both strategies, very impressive uptakes have been achieved at low pH, but limited investigations under environmentally relevant conditions are a fundamental shortcoming for most MOF systems reported. As speciation of uranyl is known to directly impact sorption results, these experiments must necessarily be performed. In many cases it can be speculated these investigations were not pursued due to the chemical stability of the material, as high pH and carbonate concentrations are known to decompose the MOFs discussed above. Development of MOFs with enhanced stabilities at high pH is essential for deployment under environmentally relevant conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Summary and Perspectives

MOFs provide an interesting new platform for the extraction of uranium from aqueous solutions, highlighted by several publications reported in a very short time frame.  summarizes the uptakes reported for the MOF systems discussed in this section. Preparation of a MOF-based adsorbent can rely on the presence of orthogonal functionalities, as demonstrated by the phosphorylurea groups of 1 and 2 or carboxylic acid and acrylamide groups of 5, or on advantageous binding to the SBU as evidenced by 6-10. In both strategies, very impressive uptakes have been achieved at low pH, but limited investigations under environmentally relevant conditions are a fundamental shortcoming for most MOF systems reported. As speciation of uranyl is known to directly impact sorption results, these experiments must necessarily be performed. In many cases it can be speculated these investigations were not pursued due to the chemical stability of the material, as high pH and carbonate concentrations are known to decompose the MOFs discussed above. Development of MOFs with enhanced stabilities at high pH is essential for deployment under environmentally relevant conditions.

Uranium uptake performance not reported.

A second area that requires further study pertains to selectivity for uranyl over other transition metals found in seawater. While several works reported impressive selectivity, these did not include the most pertinent competing metals. For those displaying some promise, namely 5, validation of the sorption results need to be performed, and a thorough investigation of the material stability is critical.

elements.content: Structure-based analysis remains an undeveloped area of research for MOFs. In light of their long-range ordering and recent development in high-performance computing, the ability to investigate the binding sites of MOFs has been investigated extensively for gas storage and separations. Similar efforts could be readily translated to predicting binding sites for extraction of uranium from aqueous solutions. Furthermore, crystallography or XAFS afford reasonable approaches for investigating and confirming the predicted binding site. High-throughput screening of MOFs could enable the discovery of a highly selective material for uranyl adsorption, as MOFs constitute one of very few materials amenable to rationale tuning and modification. Recent work was reported where computational screening allowed identification of a protein capable of femtomolar affinity for uranyl. The selectivity of this binding site was entirely structural in nature, as only amino and carboxylic acid functionalities were present in the binding pocket. Similarly, identification of a MOF possessing appropriate topology could be performed through computational screening. Subsequent incorporation of orthogonal hydroxyl- or amino- groups possessing appropriate orientation could result in a truly biomimetic binding pocket, displaying exceptional uranium selectivity and capacity.
