elements.content: Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are a class of recently developed all organic analogues to MOFs, usually constructed through dynamic covalent chemistry. These porous, crystalline organic materials consist of light elements (C, H, B, N, O, etc.) connected through strong, covalent bonds, making them significantly more chemically stable than MOFs when deployed in harsh media. While COFs can be constructed through a “building-block” type approach, where organic nodes link linear struts, the diversity of structures is far more restricted than MOFs, due primarily to limitations in the possible symmetry of the organic node and functional group compatibility for successful synthesis. Nevertheless, the combination of the inherent porosity with a composition devoid of metals results in extremely high surface areas and low material density. Moreover, due to strong material stability, postsynthetic chemical functionalization is readily achieved, while custom linkers can be designed and synthesized through well-established organic chemistry approaches. These properties of COFs have made them of significant interest for applications within separations, gas storage, and catalysis. Heavy metal extraction is one area where interest is increasing, including within seawater-based uranium extractions.
elements.clean_text:
Covalent Organic Frameworks (COFs)

Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are a class of recently developed all organic analogues to MOFs, usually constructed through dynamic covalent chemistry. These porous, crystalline organic materials consist of light elements (C, H, B, N, O, etc.) connected through strong, covalent bonds, making them significantly more chemically stable than MOFs when deployed in harsh media. While COFs can be constructed through a "building-block" type approach, where organic nodes link linear struts, the diversity of structures is far more restricted than MOFs, due primarily to limitations in the possible symmetry of the organic node and functional group compatibility for successful synthesis. Nevertheless, the combination of the inherent porosity with a composition devoid of metals results in extremely high surface areas and low material density. Moreover, due to strong material stability, postsynthetic chemical functionalization is readily achieved, while custom linkers can be designed and synthesized through well-established organic chemistry approaches. These properties of COFs have made them of significant interest for applications within separations, gas storage, and catalysis. Heavy metal extraction is one area where interest is increasing, including within seawater-based uranium extractions.

elements.content: Ma and colleagues were the first, and perhaps only, group to explore the utility of COFs for uranium extraction from seawater. The COF SCU1 was constructed from trimesoyl chloride and p-phenylenediamine in a molar ratio of 2:3 (). After treatment with “segregated” microwave irradiation, an ultramicroporous carbonaceous COF (CCOF-SCU1) was formed with a high density of nitrile functionalization, as determined by FTIR. Nitrogen isotherm analysis indicates the CCOF-SCU1 material has a large Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (507 m2/g) and is predominantly microporous (d ≈ 0.4 nm) character. When tested as a uranium sorbent, CCOF-SCU1 was able to achieve 50 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent at pH 2.5 while in the presence of 11 other competing ions (La3+, Ce3+, Nd3+, Gd3+, Sm3+, Ba2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Sr2+, Ni2+, and Zn2+).
elements.clean_text: Ma and colleagues were the first, and perhaps only, group to explore the utility of COFs for uranium extraction from seawater. The COF SCU1 was constructed from trimesoyl chloride and p-phenylenediamine in a molar ratio of 2:3 (). After treatment with "segregated" microwave irradiation, an ultramicroporous carbonaceous COF (CCOF-SCU1) was formed with a high density of nitrile functionalization, as determined by FTIR. Nitrogen isotherm analysis indicates the CCOF-SCU1 material has a large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (507 m2/g) and is predominantly microporous (d ~ 0.4 nm) character. When tested as a uranium sorbent, CCOF-SCU1 was able to achieve 50 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent at pH 2.5 while in the presence of 11 other competing ions (La3+, Ce3+, Nd3+, Gd3+, Sm3+, Ba2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Sr2+, Ni2+, and Zn2+).

elements.content: The second generation of COFs investigated for uranium extraction includes COF-COOH, which was generated with trimesoyl chloride and p-phenylenediamine, the same two building blocks as CCOF-SCU1, but at a different ratio of 4:3. Under these conditions, the excess carboxylic acid functional groups could be observed in the crystalline product. Further functionalization with 2-(2,4-dihydroxyphenyl)-benzimidazole (HBI) provided a route to a benzimidazole functional group grafted onto the surface (). The reported HBI functionalized COF (COF-HBI) also extracted uranium from a batch solution containing 11 competing ions with a very high capacity (211 g of U/g of ads) and fast kinetics (2 h), albeit at pH 4.5.

The reported HBI functionalized COF (COF-HBI) also extracted uranium from a batch solution containing 11 competing ions with a very high capacity (211 g of U/g of ads) and fast kinetics (2 h), albeit at pH 4.5.

elements.content: The most recent development in COFs for uranium adsorption involves the inclusion of conjugated carbon–carbon triple bonds into the structure of the COF, which are thus readily modified postsynthetically to afford diverse functionalities. The COF, referred to as TCD, was synthesized by microwave irradiation of trimesoyl chloride and 2,4-hexadiyne-1,6-diol, as displayed in . Postsynthetic treatment with malonitrile installs nitrile functionalities in the COF, TCD-CN, which can be subsequently transformed into amidoxime groups via reaction with hydroxylamine, forming TCD-AO (). The TCD alkynes could also be oxidized to afford the hydroxyl functionalized COF TCD–OH.

elements.content: TCD and its derivatives were investigated for the recovery of uranium from aqueous solutions. Screening of adsorption as a function of pH revealed no significant uptake until approximately pH 3, with increasing performance up to pH 4.5 where adsorption experiments were halted. Rapid kinetics were observed, with complete uptake achieved by TCD within the first 20 min of contact, though this experiment was also performed below concentrations where the adsorption sites of the material would truly saturate. An adsorption isotherm of TCD achieves a maximum uptake of approximately 140 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, again at pH 4.5 and devoid of appreciable salinity or carbonate; corresponding values for the functionalized TCD-CN, -AO, and -OH were not reported. Finally, batch adsorption experiments were performed for all materials in the presence of the 11 competing ions mentioned in their previous work, discussed above. Notable selectivity was observed for uranyl was observed, as displayed in , with the best uptake and selectivity afforded by TCD-OH, followed closely by TCD-AO. TCD-CN and TCD also had significant uptake and selectivity. While these results are promising, for application in seawater uranium recovery different screening conditions and competing ions need to be utilized to accurately replicate the pH, salinity, and concentration of environmental seawater. Nevertheless, these publications constitute the first foray into a field of interesting materials possessing great potential.

elements.content:
summarizes the uranium uptake performance for COFs and porous-organic polymers, (POPs), discussed below.

Porous Organic Polymers (POPs)

POPs, a class of highly cross-linked, amorphous polymers possessing intrinsic porosity, have recently emerged as a versatile alternative to the crystalline COFs for use in membrane separations, catalysis, and gas storage. Most of the designed POPs possess micropores (d < 2 nm), resulting in the name polymers with intrinsic microporosity (PIM). POPs that are composed of aromatic linkers are also referred to as porous aromatic frameworks, or PAFs. For the sake of simplicity and discussion, we will group all materials under the umbrella of POPs. Compared to MOFs or COFs, POPs are noncrystalline and have nonuniform pores that are typically ill-defined. Therefore, the characteristics are often more difficult to understand, and the synthesis can be more difficult to control. In general, porous polymers are synthesized by introducing ditopic or multitopic monomers into a monotopic monomer within a combined step-growth and chain-growth polymerization process to cross-link the propagating polymer chains, thus forming 3-D network materials.

Seawater simulant composition: 33.3 g of sea salts dissolved in 1 L of distilled water.

Dai and colleagues first reported a mesporous polymer created without using a porogen for the recovery of uranium from seawater. The polymer was formed from VBC and DVB comonomers, with the VBC chlorides functioning as initiators for the polymerization of AN by ATRP, as discussed in and displayed in . Following conversion of poly­(AN) to poly­(amidoxime), the adsorbent was screened in a spiked uranyl brine (6 ppm U), demonstrating a high uptake of 80 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Testing in actual seawater demonstrated a uranium-adsorption capacity of 1.99 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, surpassing the capacity of the irradiation-grafted nonwoven polyethylene fabric (0.75 mg of uranium/g of ads) from Japan Atomic Energy Agency (JAEA).

elements.content: An amidoxime functionalized POP (PPN-6-PAO) was based on the PPN-6 structure was later synthesized and functionalized with poly­(amidoxime) for recovery of uranium from seawater. While closely related to the aforementioned work, PPN-6 is composed of biphenyl struts generated by the coupling of tetrakis­(4-iodophenyl)­methane, rather than DVB (). The PPN-6 framework was postsynthetically functionalized through chloromethylation to introduce chlorine within the framework, affording efficient initiation sites for postsynthetic ATRP of AN. Following polymerization, treatment with hydroxylamine converts the nitriles of the grafted polymer (PPN-6-PAN) to amidoximes (PPN-6-PAO). After base conditioning with 3% KOH aqueous solution at room temperature, PPN-6-PAO was tested for uranium uptake in seawater spiked to 80 ppb with uranium. PPN-6-PAO demonstrated a uranium uptake of 96 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent after 42 d of contact ().

elements.content: Ma and co-workers also very recently reported a functionalized porous organic polymer for the recovery of uranium from seawater, based on the PPN-6 structure. In contrast to previous work where poly­(amidoxime) is grown from halide initiators in the POP, amidoxime groups decorated the channels of the porous support directly, providing site accessibility and rapid transport of uranium to the binding sites (). An isotherm collected in aqueous uranium solutions revealed a saturation capacity of 304 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while kinetic experiments demonstrated >95% equilibration after a mere 3 h contact. The material could be eluted with Na2CO3, affording negligible decrease in performance over two recycles. A K d of approximately 1 × 106 mL g–1 suggested very high affinity for uranium, which was supported by investigations in seawater simulant. When deployed in a brine solution containing 25.6 g L–1 NaCl and 0.198 g L–1 NaHCO3 with 7 ppm uranium, a capacity of 40 mg of uranium g–1 was obtained. Subsequent EXAFS analysis supported binding of uranium by an average of 1.4 ± 0.3 amidoxime functionalities in an η2-motif, suggesting cooperativity between adjacent amidoxime species may contribute to the observed performance.

elements.content: Finally, a PIM was synthesized from tetrafluoroterephthalonitrile and 5,5′-6,6′-tetrahydroxy-3,3,3′,3′-tetramethyl-1,1′-spirobisindane. The nitrile groups were converted postsynthetically to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine. Though negligible uptake for uranium was observed in synthetic seawater at pH 8, improved performance was observed with decreasing pH, and an optimum uptake was reported around pH 6. The authors suggested bubbling CO2 through fluidized beds to decrease the ocean pH, thereby improving uranium uptake. The technical feasibility of this was demonstrated at the laboratory scale, revealing three recycles using the aforementioned material, though industrially application of this material with commensurate acidification of the oceans is unrealistic.

elements.content: Mesoporous silicas (MS) present an interesting option as heterogeneous supports for extracting uranium from seawater. As their surface is terminated by silanol groups, facile surface modification can occur through condensation reactions with trialkoxysilane-terminated organic molecules. As MS materials are commercially available and possess high surface areas, they are a natural choice for screening experiments for newly designed chelating ligands. However, their instability under alkaline pH presents challenges for deployment under environmental seawater conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Porous Silica

Mesoporous silicas (MS) present an interesting option as heterogeneous supports for extracting uranium from seawater. As their surface is terminated by silanol groups, facile surface modification can occur through condensation reactions with trialkoxysilane-terminated organic molecules. As MS materials are commercially available and possess high surface areas, they are a natural choice for screening experiments for newly designed chelating ligands. However, their instability under alkaline pH presents challenges for deployment under environmental seawater conditions.

elements.content: Fryxell and colleagues reported the first use of MS materials for extraction of actinides with self-assembled monolayers on mesoporous supports (SAMMS). The materials possessed a surface area of approximately 1000 m2 g–1 had high binding site density and a rigid open pore structure to facilitate diffusion through the MS channels. SAMMS were functionalized with glycinyl-urea, salicylamide, and acetamide-phosphonate and then investigated for sorption of actinides at acidic pH. Impressive sorption was observed using the glycinyl-urea-functionalized SAMMS, with maximum K d of 2.4 × 105, 1.6 × 105, and 9.1 × 104 mL g–1 for Am­(III), U­(VI), and Th­(IV), respectively. As importantly, equilibrium was reached in 1–2 h, indicating rapid dissociation through the material and fast binding.
elements.clean_text: Fryxell and colleagues reported the first use of MS materials for extraction of actinides with self-assembled monolayers on mesoporous supports (SAMMS). The materials possessed a surface area of approximately 1000 m2 g-1 had high binding site density and a rigid open pore structure to facilitate diffusion through the MS channels. SAMMS were functionalized with glycinyl-urea, salicylamide, and acetamide-phosphonate and then investigated for sorption of actinides at acidic pH. Impressive sorption was observed using the glycinyl-urea-functionalized SAMMS, with maximum K d of 2.4 × 105, 1.6 × 105, and 9.1 × 104 mL g-1 for Am(III), U(VI), and Th(IV), respectively. As importantly, equilibrium was reached in 1-2 h, indicating rapid dissociation through the material and fast binding.

elements.content: Subsequent publications reported sorption with MS materials functionalized by phosphates, phosphonates, or phosphine oxides, amines, carboxylic acids, or more exotic (and less intuitive) functionalities such as transition metals or dihyrdoimidazole. One recent publication functionalizes with amidoxime, while another publication does not actually functionalize the MS, deploying it immediately following calcination.
elements.clean_text: Subsequent publications reported sorption with MS materials functionalized by phosphates, phosphonates, or phosphine oxides, amines, carboxylic acids, or more exotic (and less intuitive) functionalities such as transition metals or dihyrdoimidazole. One recent publication functionalizes with amidoxime, while another publication does not actually functionalize the MS, deploying it immediately following calcination.

elements.content: Though in principle the same type of heterogeneous support was used in all of the aforementioned studies, the differences in surface areas and pore structure between different MS materials is significant. Moreover, as different pH ranges, contact times, phase ratios, degrees of grafting, and uranyl concentrations were used, direct comparisons are challenging if not impossible. In an effort to mitigate this difficulty, Vivero-Escoto et al. synthesized a library of organo-functionalized MS materials on the commercially available silica MSU-H (). Following identical grafting and pretreatment conditions, they performed the first direct comparison of more than nine different functionalities including amidoxime, bis-amidoxime, cyclic imide dioxime, carboxylic acid, phosphate diester, phosphonate, phosphoric acid, and bis-phosphoric acid. When sorption was performed in deionized water, the unfunctionalized MSU-H outperformed all but one sorbent, indicating that nonspecific binding to the MS support is significant. This result raises concern about other MS investigations for uranium extraction, as no indication of sorption by an unfunctionalized support had previously been published, suggesting background sorption by silanol functionalities had not been considered. When sorption was performed in seawater simulant, background sorption dramatically decreased, and a phosphoric acid attached to the MS support through a urea bridge was observed to have the highest saturation capacity of around 60 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. The cyclic imide dioxime- functionalized material extracted approximately 47 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while the amidoxime-functionalized material extracted approximately 25 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent.

elements.content: Complementary information was provided by Santschi and colleagues, who reported the performance of functionalized nanoporous adsorbents, including nanoporous silica (). When investigated for recovery of uranium from Galveston Bay seawater, silica functionalized 3,4-hydroxypyridinone (HOPO) afforded a sorbent which achieved K d values more than one log unit superior to several commercial resins and nanostructured MnO2. However, when investigated for uranium recovery from Columbia River water, the aforementioned adsorbents were roughly equal.

elements.content: An interesting hybrid material was reported, formed from amidoxime-functionalized magnetic mesoporous silica (MMS-AO), synthesized through co-condensation of tetraethyl orthosilicate and 2-cyanoethyltriethoxysilane on the surface of silica-coated Fe3O4. Following transformation of the nitrile to amidoxime, a saturation capacity of 277 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained for the material at pH 5, facilitated by rapid magnetic separation. Performance was observed to be strongly pH dependent, though a respectable uptake of 83 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved at pH 8 following 24 h contact.

Following transformation of the nitrile to amidoxime, a saturation capacity of 277 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained for the material at pH 5, facilitated by rapid magnetic separation. Performance was observed to be strongly pH dependent, though a respectable uptake of 83 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved at pH 8 following 24 h contact.

elements.content: Very recently, a series of organo-functionalized silicas were surface grafted with various (di)-phosphonic acids, imino diacetic acid, and HOPO and then investigated for the recovery of uranium from environmental seawater (). Adsorption isotherms reveal saturation capacities of the phosphate functionalized silica adsorbents outperform all commercial adsorbents and activated carbon, with PropPhos- and HOPO-functionalized silica achieving capacities of approximately 60 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while Diphos-functionalized silica saturated at 128 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. K d values determined for Diphos-, PropPhos-, and HOPO-grafted materials were in excess of 3.5 × 106 mL g–1, while AcPhos- and IDAA- functionalized silica afforded values of 3.3 × 106 and 1.7 × 106 mL g–1, respectively.

K d values determined for Diphos-, PropPhos-, and HOPO-grafted materials were in excess of 3.5 × 106 mL g-1, while AcPhos- and IDAA- functionalized silica afforded values of 3.3 × 106 and 1.7 × 106 mL g-1, respectively.

elements.content: Perhaps more interestingly, in this report the authors also articulate the integration of the Diphos- and PropPhos functionalized silica with a Nafion binder for use in extraction of uranium from seawater. As noted by the authors, nanostructured materials can be processed into monolithic and particulate formats which can be implemented in standard packed-adsorbent column systems. However, in many instances the act of developing a monolith or supporting nanostructured materials on a substrate eliminates many of the advantageous properties that were afforded by the unsupported material. Furthermore, particles below a certain diameter cannot be directly integrated into column systems due to tight packing and the generation of extremely high backpressures. Finally, in light of the low concentration of uranium in seawater, active pumping approaches are not viable due to sheer volume of seawater that needs to be processed, combined with the associated energetic costs.

elements.content: Diphos-, HOPO-, and PropPhos-functionalized silica were processed into a thin film membrane, composed of 50 wt % adsorbent and 50 wt % Nafion polymeric binder. A DiPhos-functionalized silica membrane adsorbent reached equilibrium in 24 h of contact with seawater spiked to 34 ppb in uranium and at pH 7.5; 1.1 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent were recovered. Similar results were claimed for HOPO and PropPhos materials as well. When contacted with 200 mL of unspiked seawater, 0.104 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was extracted over 2 h contact time. Based on their reported Na2CO3 elution data, which show complete elution of uranium, and recycling experiments, which show no statistically significant decrease in uranium uptake over four runs for both Diphos- and PropPhos-functionalized materials following an acid regeneration step, dramatic advantages over traditional polymeric adsorbents are asserted. The authors propose a continuous-deployment system where the membrane-supported silica adsorbents are immersed in seawater, eluted with Na2CO3, pre-conditioned with acid, and then reimmersed in seawater. A graphical depiction of this system is provided in . Extrapolating their 2 h adsorption data to a continuous process, the authors calculate as much as 75 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent could be achieved over a 60 d deployment, compared to 4 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent for traditional polymer materials.

elements.content: The aforementioned work does comprise an important step toward the practical utilization of mesoporous materials for the recovery of uranium from seawater. Significant attention has been devoted by many to the development of nanoscale materials, with little to no consideration for how such materials could be effectively utilized in industrial-scale processes. However, the calculations provided in the aforementioned work do need to be tempered slightly by some additional considerations. Foremost, the elution and recycle data reported by the authors were performed on unsupported adsorbents, making additional experiments necessary to demonstrate the impressive performance indeed translates to a membrane-supported system. Second, principles of scaling have not been considered. In contrast to traditional polymer based adsorbents, where 50 mg (or more) are utilized for testing in seawater, only 5–6 mg of supported polymer were investigated in this study, assuming complete recovery of uranium from a 200 mL sample. In light of the known instability of silica in alkaline solutions, the degradation of the material over prolonged seawater exposure should also be considered. Finally, it is worth recalling early seawater deployment efforts by the Japanese relied on a much less sophisticated system, which nevertheless was the primary cost driver. Translation of the adsorbent to supported polymers was due largely to the economy of the deployment system. Nevertheless, the above work certainly comprises a forward thinking technological development with potential to fundamentally change the way materials are developed for the recovery of uranium from seawater.
elements.clean_text: The aforementioned work does comprise an important step toward the practical utilization of mesoporous materials for the recovery of uranium from seawater. Significant attention has been devoted by many to the development of nanoscale materials, with little to no consideration for how such materials could be effectively utilized in industrial-scale processes. However, the calculations provided in the aforementioned work do need to be tempered slightly by some additional considerations. Foremost, the elution and recycle data reported by the authors were performed on unsupported adsorbents, making additional experiments necessary to demonstrate the impressive performance indeed translates to a membrane-supported system. Second, principles of scaling have not been considered. In contrast to traditional polymer based adsorbents, where 50 mg (or more) are utilized for testing in seawater, only 5-6 mg of supported polymer were investigated in this study, assuming complete recovery of uranium from a 200 mL sample. In light of the known instability of silica in alkaline solutions, the degradation of the material over prolonged seawater exposure should also be considered. Finally, it is worth recalling early seawater deployment efforts by the Japanese relied on a much less sophisticated system, which nevertheless was the primary cost driver. Translation of the adsorbent to supported polymers was due largely to the economy of the deployment system. Nevertheless, the above work certainly comprises a forward thinking technological development with potential to fundamentally change the way materials are developed for the recovery of uranium from seawater.

elements.content:
summarizes uranium recovery performance by mesoporous silica adsorbents.

High Affinity Genetically-Engineered Proteins

While not fitting cleanly into the category of nanostructured sorbents, biochemical techniques have been utilized to engineer a protein with intriguing properties that display particular innovation and hold promise as potential “game-changing” technologies in the field of uranyl extraction. In contrast to polymer fibers or inorganic sorbent materials, an innovative approach using genetically engineered proteins was pursued in collaboration between the Lai and He groups. First, the Protein Data Bank was screened computationally to identify protein structures containing pockets which could accommodate the uranyl cation. Variations were created where residues lining the binding pocket were modified to contain amino acids with accessible Lewis bases for uranyl coordination in the equatorial plane. Over 5000 possible structures were identified and then refined by stability, potential steric interactions, and accessibility of the binding site (). Of 10 candidates identified, 9 were expressed well and 4 displayed selective binding for uranyl.

Primary steps in the computational screening and subsequent design of super-uranyl-binding proteins. The desired coordination features are identified (step 1), the protein database is surveyed and a protein selected for further study (step 2), possible mutations for the protein are considered (step 3), potential uranyl binding sites are searched (step 4), and uranyl coordination geometries for the selective potential binding sites are evaluated and scored (step 5). If no hits are identified, the computational algorithm returns to step 2. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2014, Nature Publishing Group.

The desired coordination features are identified (step 1), the protein database is surveyed and a protein selected for further study (step 2), possible mutations for the protein are considered (step 3), potential uranyl binding sites are searched (step 4), and uranyl coordination geometries for the selective potential binding sites are evaluated and scored (step 5). If no hits are identified, the computational algorithm returns to step 2. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2014, Nature Publishing Group.

elements.content: From these promising initial results, a super uranyl-binding protein (SUP) was designed by genetic modification of Methanobacterium thermoautotrophicum. While the wild-type protein had a modest distribution coefficient, strategic mutations resulted in nearly a 6 order of magnitude increase in affinity and a distribution coefficient of 7.4 × 10–15 M (est. 6.7 × 10–11 mL g–1) at pH 8.9. The super uranyl-binding protein could be fixed sulfhydryl resin and displayed impressive selectivity for uranyl over other competing ions present in seawater, even when added at more than 106× excess. Cu2+ and VO2+ were the only ions for which the protein had comparable affinity, but the authors note even in light of their greater concentration in seawater they would not be capable of competing with uranyl binding. Indeed, 17%, 30%, and 90% of uranyl was extracted from simulated seawater when contacted for 30 min with 1, 10, and >6000 equiv of protein. This remarkable affinity and rapid sorption reveals genetically engineered proteins could offer a viable means for extracting uranium from seawater. However, there are significant challenges to the viable deployment of engineered proteins such as cost, deployment motif, and selectivity toward uranium, specifically related to vanadium and copper.

The super uranyl-binding protein could be fixed sulfhydryl resin and displayed impressive selectivity for uranyl over other competing ions present in seawater, even when added at more than 106× excess. Cu2+ and VO2+ were the only ions for which the protein had comparable affinity, but the authors note even in light of their greater concentration in seawater they would not be capable of competing with uranyl binding. Indeed, 17%, 30%, and 90% of uranyl was extracted from simulated seawater when contacted for 30 min with 1, 10, and >6000 equiv of protein. This remarkable affinity and rapid sorption reveals genetically engineered proteins could offer a viable means for extracting uranium from seawater. elements.content: In an effort to address some of these potential challenges, very recent work articulates the integration of the SUP into a hydrogel through thiol-maleimide click chemistry (). The hydrophilicity of the SUP was improved through genetically fusing termini with elastin-like peptides, and the resulting hydrogel was subsequently formed with 4-arm PEG-maleimide cross-linkers. Using a microfluidic device, droplets of SUP hydrogels were processed and cured into microbeads 165 μm in radius. Proteins were demonstrated to remain active for uranium binding, and the uranium uptake in DI water was quite close to the theoretically determined value. However, in solutions at higher uranium concentrations, a 1.5:1 ratio of uranium:protein was obtained suggesting the presence of a secondary binding site. Using these SUP-hydrogel beads, uranium can be enriched up to 0.0092 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent upon contacted with environmental seawater spiked to 13.7 nM with uranyl.

elements.content: Further development is needed to determine whether such biologically based adsorbents are financially plausible compared to the more established polymer systems. While still early in development, this work has nevertheless demonstrated a viable approach for translation of a basic research program to a format which could be putatively deployed in bead-format on a thin film membrane. Identification of nondestructive methods for uranium recovery and assessment of scale up and deployment options merit further attention. summarizes uranium binding performance by genetically engineered proteins and materials derived for their deployment.

The extraction of uranium from seawater has experienced a renewed interest due to the anticipated growth of nuclear power as a low-carbon source for baseload energy production. This interest has undergone many transformations since its genesis, spanning solvent extraction and inorganic materials to polyolefin fiber-based adsorbents and now to areas which did not exist when this unconventional resource was identified, such as nanostructured materials, MOFs, and genetically engineered proteins. In less than five years, current state-of-the-art adsorbents have pushed the thresholds of science to more than quadruple the best adsorption capacity achieved over the past half-century.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Summary and Perspectives

The extraction of uranium from seawater has experienced a renewed interest due to the anticipated growth of nuclear power as a low-carbon source for baseload energy production. This interest has undergone many transformations since its genesis, spanning solvent extraction and inorganic materials to polyolefin fiber-based adsorbents and now to areas which did not exist when this unconventional resource was identified, such as nanostructured materials, MOFs, and genetically engineered proteins. In less than five years, current state-of-the-art adsorbents have pushed the thresholds of science to more than quadruple the best adsorption capacity achieved over the past half-century.

elements.content: Amidoxime-functionalized polymers are the most technologically mature adsorbent for this application, and have demonstrated impressive performance following protracted contact with seawater in screening studies, as well as in long-term deployment at the pilot scale in the open ocean. Quite deservedly, RIGP prepared polymer adsorbents are the benchmark against which all other adsorbents are compared. The versatility in form of polymer support, comonomer selection, and established chemistry with regards to graft chain polymerization and conversion establish this entire category of materials as an essential technology for seawater uranium recovery.
elements.clean_text: Amidoxime-functionalized polymers are the most technologically mature adsorbent for this application, and have demonstrated impressive performance following protracted contact with seawater in screening studies, as well as in long-term deployment at the pilot scale in the open ocean. Quite deservedly, RIGP prepared polymer adsorbents are the benchmark against which all other adsorbents are compared. The versatility in form of polymer support, comonomer selection, and established chemistry with regards to graft chain polymerization and conversion establish this entire category of materials as an essential technology for seawater uranium recovery.

elements.content: A great strength is the relative ease with which the polymer composition can be tuned by variation of comonomer species and ratios, as well as the inherent potential for adsorbents composed of block copolymers instead of merely random copolymers. The work of Saito and colleagues revealed the installation of a hydrophilic block to the end of the amidoxime graft chain to be an effective avenue for increasing adsorbent performance and is a representative example of how this approach could be leveraged in the future. Related work performed on polymer microspheres was achieved via RAFT polymerization, affording precise control over both atomistic and mesoscale structure to effect improvements in uranium uptake. There is great potential inherent in the translation of this technology to a more deployable format, in particular a high-surface area polymer trunk.

The work of Saito and colleagues revealed the installation of a hydrophilic block to the end of the amidoxime graft chain to be an effective avenue for increasing adsorbent performance and is a representative example of how this approach could be leveraged in the future. Related work performed on polymer microspheres was achieved via RAFT polymerization, affording precise control over both atomistic and mesoscale structure to effect improvements in uranium uptake. There is great potential inherent in the translation of this technology to a more deployable format, in particular a high-surface area polymer trunk.

elements.content: The development of ATRP approaches to adsorbent preparation may also hold great promise. A PVC-co-PVC-graft-poly­(amidoxime-co-tBA) adsorbent prepared by ATRP currently has the highest uranium uptake of any material in the open literature, achieving 5.22 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 49 d of seawater contact. However, two significant challenges require further attention. Specifically, ATRP adsorbents require higher degrees of grafting for noteworthy uptake as compared to RIGP-prepared adsorbents (e.g., 1390% vs 354%), which is a considerable cost-driver in material production, and the absence of any current industrial-scale process successfully incorporating ATRP suggests major innovations in industrial processes would be required to bring this technology to market.

A PVC-co-PVC-graft-poly(amidoxime-co-tBA) adsorbent prepared by ATRP currently has the highest uranium uptake of any material in the open literature, achieving 5.22 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 49 d of seawater contact. However, two significant challenges require further attention. Specifically, ATRP adsorbents require higher degrees of grafting for noteworthy uptake as compared to RIGP-prepared adsorbents (e.g., 1390% vs 354%), which is a considerable cost-driver in material production, and the absence of any current industrial-scale process successfully incorporating ATRP suggests major innovations in industrial processes would be required to bring this technology to market.

elements.content: Introduction of GMA-grafted adsorbents comprise another promising avenue. Computational work has demonstrated great potential for the de novo design of metal chelating ligands which would, at least theoretically, possess exquisite selectivity. However, inclusion of such receptors onto an adsorbent polymer is not expected to be achieved through traditional RIGP approaches due to challenges synthesizing stable ligands with polymerizable groups, significant steric hindrance impeding access of any polymerizable group to a growing graft chain, and issues with side-reactions and radiolysis of such rationally designed chelators. In contrast, inclusion of a functionality capable of ring-opening the GMA epoxide is comparatively simple would enable polymer functionalization and would facilitate investigation of these rationally designed ligands in environmental seawater.
elements.clean_text: Introduction of GMA-grafted adsorbents comprise another promising avenue. Computational work has demonstrated great potential for the de novo design of metal chelating ligands which would, at least theoretically, possess exquisite selectivity. However, inclusion of such receptors onto an adsorbent polymer is not expected to be achieved through traditional RIGP approaches due to challenges synthesizing stable ligands with polymerizable groups, significant steric hindrance impeding access of any polymerizable group to a growing graft chain, and issues with side-reactions and radiolysis of such rationally designed chelators. In contrast, inclusion of a functionality capable of ring-opening the GMA epoxide is comparatively simple would enable polymer functionalization and would facilitate investigation of these rationally designed ligands in environmental seawater.

elements.content: Despite the rapid progress in this field and promise evidenced by the aforementioned materials, significant difficulties nevertheless remain. For example, a major challenge faced by the majority of inorganic adsorbents and all nano- or nanostructured materials is the issue of practical deployability. While it is easy to point out seawater investigations have not been performed, this is certainly not for lack of desire but limitations in how unbound powders can be efficiently deployed under environmental conditions. Fixation upon a monolithic support or polymer may seem a straightforward route at first glance, but the mass of substrate and fraction of surface area obstructed by this approach would have severely deleterious effects on the final sorption capacity. This remains an area that is largely unexplored, and until a reasonable method can be established whereby only modest mass is added and little surface area impeded, development of new nanostructured materials may amount to little more than a novelty with no practical application. Rather than focusing on developing new materials, the authors believe pursuit of deployment platforms is a more worthwhile investment of effort and time.

Rather than focusing on developing new materials, the authors believe pursuit of deployment platforms is a more worthwhile investment of effort and time.

elements.content: Similarly, while investigations of unsupported hydrogels or adsorbents grafted from polymer beads may afford exciting preliminary results, the influence of the polymer trunk material has not been considered. The behavior of tethered polyelectrolytes, such as polyolefin-supported poly­(amidoxime-co-AA), remains an active area of both experimental and theoretical research. It is known that, at high graft densities, polymer chains crowd each other and induce stretching away from the surface of the support, with further complexity added from electrostatic repulsion and subsequent charge screening. Nevertheless, such work is relegated to planar polyelectrolyte brushes and has not developed to consider the myriad of supports which have been discussed above. Translation of technology developed on unsupported hydrogels or polymer beads to a deployable trunk polymer is likely to result in new graft chain morphology and commensurate changes in performance, with uptake further diminished by inclusion of the additional mass from the polymer support and reduced surface area.

The behavior of tethered polyelectrolytes, such as polyolefin-supported poly(amidoxime-co-AA), remains an active area of both experimental and theoretical research. It is known that, at high graft densities, polymer chains crowd each other and induce stretching away from the surface of the support, with further complexity added from electrostatic repulsion and subsequent charge screening. Nevertheless, such work is relegated to planar polyelectrolyte brushes and has not developed to consider the myriad of supports which have been discussed above. Translation of technology developed on unsupported hydrogels or polymer beads to a deployable trunk polymer is likely to result in new graft chain morphology and commensurate changes in performance, with uptake further diminished by inclusion of the additional mass from the polymer support and reduced surface area.

elements.content: Perhaps the largest challenged faced by all materials is the lack of selectivity observed between seawater-prevalent transition metals and uranium. Exchanging the uptake of Ni, Fe, or V for uranium would increase the uptake by 2, 4, and 10×, respectively. It is worth considering that many of the inorganic adsorbents or nanostructured materials have capabilities that either engender them with intrinsic selectivity or could potentially afford such a level of separation, while ion-imprinted polymers are the only soft-material that have also demonstrated distinct potential to these ends. Most notably, the structural rigor of hard-matter materials could be used to engineer pore architectures or arrange adsorbent groups to facilitate cooperative adsorbent interactions. Identifying how pore curvature influences sorption capacity and selectivity for a monolayer-functionalized material could provide insights to how to improve performance for other materials. Alternatively, materials with appreciable ordering, like MOFs or COFs, could be used to investigate the role of cooperative sorbent interactions or in the design of 3-D host architectures. A particular opportunity appears to lend itself to the application of high-performance computing to the design of structurally based adsorbents. These materials could conceivably achieve selectivity rivaling genetically engineered proteins, while providing superior saturation capacity and demonstrating amenability to industrial-scale processing. However, several of the promising nanostructured materials, specifically MOFs and mesoporous silica, suffer from an innate instability under basic conditions, which must be addressed before further research should be pursued.

Exchanging the uptake of Ni, Fe, or V for uranium would increase the uptake by 2, 4, and 10×, respectively. It is worth considering that many of the inorganic adsorbents or nanostructured materials have capabilities that either engender them with intrinsic selectivity or could potentially afford such a level of separation, while ion-imprinted polymers are the only soft-material that have also demonstrated distinct potential to these ends. Most notably, the structural rigor of hard-matter materials could be used to engineer pore architectures or arrange adsorbent groups to facilitate cooperative adsorbent interactions. Identifying how pore curvature influences sorption capacity and selectivity for a monolayer-functionalized material could provide insights to how to improve performance for other materials. Alternatively, materials with appreciable ordering, like MOFs or COFs, could be used to investigate the role of cooperative sorbent interactions or in the design of 3-D host architectures. A particular opportunity appears to lend itself to the application of high-performance computing to the design of structurally based adsorbents. These materials could conceivably achieve selectivity rivaling genetically engineered proteins, while providing superior saturation capacity and demonstrating amenability to industrial-scale processing. However, several of the promising nanostructured materials, specifically MOFs and mesoporous silica, suffer from an innate instability under basic conditions, which must be addressed before further research should be pursued.

elements.content: In contrast, polymer adsorbents afford little opportunity for structural engineering, as most properties can only be imparted by manipulation of the bulk material. Accordingly, detailed fundamental studies of polymer structure and characterization of current top-performers are necessary to determine the role of local chemistry and graft chain morphology in observed uptake. Promising initial research in this area involves the direct functionalization of poly­(AN) with various comonomers, but further work is necessary to achieve definitive conclusions and deconvolute the many factors influencing the observed behavior. For instance, use of a metallocene catalyst to generate highly iso- or syndiotactic polymers or copolymers which can then be attached to a polymer core in a “grafting-to” approach could enable rational investigation of polymer morphology and begin unraveling some of the unanswered questions. Alternatively, investigations of unbound oligomers of appropriate composition and molecular weight could facilitate fundamental understanding of the influence of morphology, comonomer, polyolefin support, and graft chain length on adsorbent performance. Without understanding of the current adsorbent technologies, further investigation of exotic comonomers and screening studies constitute little more than a shotgun approach.

elements.content: Finally, while tremendous work has been performed in order to obtain data for uranium uptake in environmental seawater, additional effort is necessary to validate promising results which are reported in the literature and to ensure a head-to-head comparison is achieved. A critical review of experimental conditions reveals many data sets are of very little relevance to the alleged application. Inappropriate pH, phase ratios, uranium concentrations, and meaningless competing ions are but a few of the more obvious flaws which remove much, if not all, utility from numerous literature reports. The establishment of facilities where samples can be screened in environmental seawater is an important step in the right direction, and opportunities need to be made available for universities to access these resources.

elements.content: More than six decades after the foundational studies of Project Oyster, the recovery of uranium from seawater remains a challenging and ambitious goal. Nevertheless, dramatic improvements have been achieved in the traditional technologies, in the process affording novel conceptual approaches with potential for exceptional gains in selectivity and performance as well as a greater fundamental understanding of polymer behavior and advances in the rational design and preparation of functional soft matter. While not yet within our grasp, the successful recovery of uranium from seawater remains a technologically viable alternative to terrestrial mining and with continued effort can ensure effectively limitless uranium availability for future generations.

Carter W. Abney is a Eugene P. Wigner Fellow at Oak Ridge National Laboratory. He received dual B.S. degrees in chemistry and theoretical mathematics from the University of Wisconsin in 2007, under the supervision of Professor Clark Landis. He received a M.S. degree in inorganic chemistry from the University of North Carolina in 2009, under the guidance of Professor Wenbin Lin. After working as an analytical research chemist at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, he earned his Ph.D. in chemistry from the University of Chicago in 2015, again advised by Professor Wenbin Lin. He has been a Eugene P. Wigner Fellow at Oak Ridge National Laboratory since 2015. His research involves development of nanostructured materials for separations and catalysis, understanding the relationship between structure and performance in ionic liquids and soft matter, and the application of neutron/X-ray scattering and spectroscopy techniques to unresolved energy-related science questions.

He received dual B.S. degrees in chemistry and theoretical mathematics from the University of Wisconsin in 2007, under the supervision of Professor Clark Landis. He received a M.S. degree in inorganic chemistry from the University of North Carolina in 2009, under the guidance of Professor Wenbin Lin. After working as an analytical research chemist at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, he earned his Ph.D. in chemistry from the University of Chicago in 2015, again advised by Professor Wenbin Lin. He has been a Eugene P. Wigner Fellow at Oak Ridge National Laboratory since 2015. His research involves development of nanostructured materials for separations and catalysis, understanding the relationship between structure and performance in ionic liquids and soft matter, and the application of neutron/X-ray scattering and spectroscopy techniques to unresolved energy-related science questions.

elements.content: Richard T. Mayes is a Staff Inorganic Chemist in the Chemical Sciences Division at Oak Ridge National Laboratory. He received his B.S. and M.S. degrees from Tennessee Technological University working with Dr. Edward Lisic. He received his Ph.D. in chemistry from the University of Tennessee in 2009 under the guidance of Dr. Craig E. Barnes. In 2009, he accepted a position as an ORISE Postdoctoral Researcher at Oak Ridge National Laboratory with Dr. Sheng Dai, transitioning to staff in 2011. His research involves the development and application of soft-templated mesoporous carbon materials, heavy metal extraction from complex fluids, and high temperature molten salt chemistry.

His research involves the development and application of soft-templated mesoporous carbon materials, heavy metal extraction from complex fluids, and high temperature molten salt chemistry.

elements.content: Tomonori Saito is a R&D staff at Chemical Sciences Division at Oak Ridge National Laboratory. He received his Ph.D. in Chemistry (Organic Polymers) from Virginia Tech in 2008. He did postdoctoral research at The Pennsylvania State University and Oak Ridge National Laboratory prior to becoming a staff member at Oak Ridge National Laboratory in 2012. He has utilized his expertise in polymer science (especially polymer synthesis) to tackle various energy-related research projects including CO2 separation membranes, polymer electrolytes for batteries, ionic block copolymers, thermoplastic elastomers, additive manufacturing, carbon fibers and composites, lignin-based carbon materials and polymers, polymer nanocomposites, flow battery, and hydrogen and microbial fuel cells, in addition to uranium polymer fiber adsorbents from seawater.

elements.content: Sheng Dai obtained his B.S. degree (1984) and M.S. degree (1986) in Chemistry at Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China and his Ph.D. (1990) in Chemistry at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. He is currently a corporate fellow and group leader at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory and a Professor of Chemistry at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. His current research interests include ionic liquids, porous carbon and oxide materials, advanced materials and their applications for separation sciences and energy storage, as well as catalysis by nanomaterials. He has published over 600 peer-reviewed journal papers and holds 26 U.S. patents.

cln_elements.content:
A Mg–Co layered double hydroxide (LDH) possessing hierarchical structuring was synthesized from a sacrificial zeolite-imidizole framework (ZIF) template, which doubled as the Co source. Mg­(NO3)2 was added to the ZIF-67 template in an aqueous/ethanolic system, promoting growth of nanosheets on the facets of the template and ultimately affording hollow rhombic dodecahedron structures (). These adsorbents were contacted with a brine screening solution at a phase ratio of 0.5 g L–1 for 3 h contact time. Isothermal investigations revealed pH 5 is optimal for uranium recovery, with saturation greater than 850 mg of uranium g–1 achievable at high uranium concentrations. When contacted with a brine solution containing an environmentally appropriate 3 ppb uranium concentration, an uptake of 0.006 mg of uranium g–1 was achieved. This uptake increased up to 0.4 mg of uranium g–1 when contacted with a brine solution possessing 200 ppb uranium concentration.

To investigate uranium uptake performance, 18 mg adsorbents were deployed in 200 mL of 12 ppm aqueous uranyl solution. For the adsorbent prepared from poly­(AO)40-block-poly­(St)9 with a propyl spacer, an adsorption optimum of approximately 65 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained a pH 7, but a statistically insignificant decrease was observed for pH 8. As the poly­(AO) block was increased, leaving the carbon bridge between the zwitterion and AO function unchanged, an uptake maximum of 170 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained when n = 82. Additionally, while performance was comparable for the carbon bridge of 1 and 3 atoms, distancing the AO functionality from the quaternary ammonium bromide by 6 carbons resulted in a significant decrease in performance.

The same group reported a parametric study on RIGP of adsorbents for recovery of heavy metals, investigating the effect of cumulative dose, time exposed to air, atmosphere of radiation, and reaction temperature on final grafting yield. PP fiber sheets were irradiated and subsequently immersed in AN dissolved in DMF, followed by conversion of poly­(AN) to poly­(amidoxime) by treatment with hydroxylamine. When irradiated in air, the Dg increases with cumulative dose, reaching 80 wt % around 220 kGy. In contrast, when irradiated under an inert N2 environment, a plateau of 20 wt % is reached around 180 kGy. Exposure of the irradiated sample to air for 15 min prior to contact with the monomer solution improved the grafting to 90 wt % Dg, while heating the polymerization solution to 60 °C yielded further improvements and a Dg of 130 wt %. These data are summarized in . Performance was analyzed by oceanic deployment at the Trombay estuary submergence facility, with the optimized adsorbent achieving 0.6 × 10–3 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 13 d of contact at the pilot scale.

Poly­(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) was investigated as a trunk material for preparation of PVA-graft-poly­(AO) adsorbents. Following preirradiation, the PVA trunk was immersed in the AN monomer solution, and a 43.5 wt % Dg was obtained. Following conversion with hydroxylamine to form amidoximes, the saturation capacity of the adsorbent was determined through production of an isothermal study. A theoretical saturation capacity of 69 mg of uranium/g of adsobent was obtained by linearization of the Langmuir isotherm, while the experimental maximum was 43 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. While the maximum adsorption in screening experiments was obtained at pH 8.5, pertinent to seawater, isotherms and all reported values were obtained at pH 4, making relevant comparisons difficult.

Uranium uptake experiments were performed in a brine solution of seawater-relevant salinity and carbonate, with pH adjusted to 8. When contacted with brine spiked with 7.2 ppm uranium, capacities were correlated with polymer Dg. Inclusion of the cationic species appeared to improve performance, as isothermal studies afforded a saturation capacity of 100 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, compared to 20 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent for the neutral poly­(amidoxime). While clearly displaying a solid trend, significant differences in polymer degree of grafting prevent an ideal comparison. When the cationic adsorbent was immersed in a 1.7 ppb solution, a capacity of 0.04 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved following 8 days contact.

AN/AA comonomers were also copolymerized with DVB on a mesoporous carbon framework, initiated thermally with an AIBN activator. The ratio of AN:AA:DVB was maintained at 7:2:1 (w/w) while the carbon:monomer ratios were varied from 1:3 to 1:25. Screening of uranium uptake was performed following conversion of the nitrile groups to amidoximes via treatment with hydroxylamine. Approximately 15 mg of adsorbents were suspended in 250 mL of a 700 ppb uranium brine solution for 24 h. The highest screening capacity of 63 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved for a 1:12 carbon:monomer ratio, though performance by 1:15, 1:20, and 1:25 were similar. The material possessing a 1:12 carbon:monomer ratio was investigated for recovery of uranium from 5 gallons of filtered environmental seawater over 4 weeks via a batch contact, affording an uptake of 0.55 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent.

cln_elements.content:
Efforts of these early decades focused on development of inorganic adsorbents deployed either as fixed or floating adsorbent beds. The performance of 81 different inorganic materials are reported as of 1979, with lead sulfide, lead naphthalene, and hydrous titanium dioxide all achieving uranium capacities exceeding 1 mg of uranium/g of metal in adsorbent. Despite the ultimate consensus that hydrous titanium dioxide was the best material, the number of lead-based inorganic adsorbents that were investigated is approximately equal to the number of nonlead-based adsorbents.

Large scale marine experiments were also performed by the Japanese, with the longest lasting from 1999–2001. Noting the additional energy demand from pumping seawater across an adsorbent bed, they sought to use passive diffusion of seawater through adsorbent stacks deployed in the ocean. Adsorbent stacks were prepared from amidoxime-functionalized polyethylene fabric, which was then cut into smaller sheets. 144 adsorbent stacks were placed into a 16 m2 adsorption bed, of which three were suspended from an 8 m × 8 m floating frame anchored to the seafloor. displays an example of the adsorbent stack as well as a scheme of the floating frame and adsorbent beds. A crane ship extracted adsorbent beds every 20–40 days for fractional elution with 0.5 M HCl. Over the two year study, approximately 1 kg yellowcake was collected, affording an average of 0.5 mg uranium/g-adsorbent every 30 days.

It was determined the most expensive part of the experiment with sorbent stacks was the floating frame. An innovative redesign involved preparation of a braided adsorbent that could be anchored to the seafloor, creating a sorbent bed biomimetic of a kelp farm. Attaching a float to the top of the sorbent braid allowed their suspension in seawater, and upon wireless release from the anchor, facilitated their recovery with a fishing boat. After 30 days of soaking, the polymer fiber recovered 1.5 mg uranium g–1 adsorbent. displays the proposed deployment system for the braided adsorbent.

A very recent report from the same group depicts use of polysulfide/layered double hydroxide composite materials for uranyl sequestration. When added at a reasonable phase ratio of 1 g L–1, the layered double hydroxide materials were able to extract 96–99% of uranium from deionized water, achieving a sorption capacity of 330 mg g–1. While significant variation in initial pH values for isotherm solutions adds uncertainty the accuracy of this number, the results are impressive nevertheless. Distribution coefficients (K d) as high as 3.4 × 106 were achieved, which are competitive with the best inorganic uranium sorbents reported in the literature. These results were decreased by 1–2 orders of magnitude upon addition of Ca2+ and Na+ but remain among the best literature results for uranyl extraction. The authors subsequently investigated these materials for extracting uranium from environmental seawater from near Tianjin City, China. The report that 78% of uranium was removed over 24 h would suggest rapid kinetics and great promise as an adsorbent material. However, a close reading reveals adsorbents were added at a phase ratio of 15 g L–1 for this experiment. Furthermore, control experiments reveal the concentration of uranium in this seawater exceeded 9 ppb, more than 2.5× the concentration of uranium typically anticipated under open ocean conditions. External validation of the performance for this material is essential, in particular when deployed at a reasonable phase ratio and in environmentally relevant uranium concentrations.

The sorbents were investigated for 99Tc and 238U sorption at a phase ratio of 50–100 g L–1 in deionized water for 1 week, with radionuclide removal ranging from 57–98% for 99Tc and 68–99% for 238U. Sorption of iodine was measured by flowing gaseous I2 over a sorbent bed at 125 °C. All chalcogel materials bound >99% of all iodine, as determined by ICP-MS of a 0.1 M NaOH solution through which chalcogel-filtered gas was bubbled. The ability to process these chalcogels into monolithic materials makes them a potentially useful technology for uranyl extraction from seawater; however, the use of expensive, rare, and toxic metals limits their applicability in current form. Furthermore, external validation must be performed, as the current report only discusses performance when deployed at phase ratios which are untenable for environmental conditions and large-scale deployment.

Uranium uptake studies reveal optimal performance is achieved at pH 5 in a 25 ppm uranium solution, while approximately 90% of the uranium is recovered at pH 8, affording an uptake of 4.5 mg of uranium g–1. The material saturation capacity was investigated through an isotherm, but a modest maximum uptake of approximately 10 mg g–1 was observed. Comparatively poor performance at acidic pH was ascribed to competition of the uranium with the proton in solution, suggesting an ion exchange mechanism and anticipation of poor performance in solutions with high ionic strength, such as seawater.

An inorganic/organic composite, zirconyl-molybdopyrophosphate-tributyl phosphate (ZMPP-TBP), was prepared by coprecipitation of sodium molybdate and potassium pyrophosphate with zirconyl oxychloride. While a maximum uptake was observed at pH 6, there was minimal performance variation across a wide pH range, and >99% of the uranium was recovered from a 5 ppm aqueous solution when contacted at a 1 g L–1 phase ratio. Inclusion of various mono- or divalent cations (Zn2+, Na+, Ca2+, and Mg2+) or carbonate effected a < 5% decrease in uranium uptake, suggesting promising performance in complex matrixes. The saturation isotherm was also obtained, yielding a maximum capacity of 196 mg of uranium g–1 and achieving equilibrium in 80 min. In contrast to most adsorbents, variable temperature investigations with ZMPP-TBP reveal uranium uptake is inversely related to temperature. A negative Gibbs free energy for uranyl complexation was experimentally determined, demonstrating adsorption to be a spontaneous reaction, while the inverse relationship with temperature attests to a enthalpically driven process. Finally, the uranium could be easily eluted with dilute HCl and the material recycled up to four-times with negligible loss of performance. Although not investigated directly for recovery of uranium from seawater or an appropriate brine, the performance is promising and may merit further investigation.

Magnetic Adsorbents

Several magnetic inorganic adsorbents have also been reported of recent for uranium recovery from seawater. A magnetic cobalt ferrite/multiwalled carbon nanotube (CoFe2O4/MWCNT) system was investigated for uranium extraction from several aqueous solutions. When contacted at a phase ratio of 0.4 g L–1 in a 50 ppm uranium solution, a strong pH dependence was observed, with a maximum uptake of 212.7 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent reported at pH 6. When the pH increased to 8, a 33% decrease in performance was reported. Experiments performed in solutions containing alkaline and alkali earth cations reveal preferential uptake of uranium.

Later work articulated the use of zerovalent iron nanocomposites, surface functionalized with AN and subsequently converted to amidoxime. When used to recover uranium from aqueous solutions, a maximum uptake was achieved at pH 5. Increasing ionic strength up to 0.5 M NaCl results in a decrease of adsorption at lower pH, but no decrease from pure aqueous solutions were observed at pH 6 or 7. Investigation of the uranium-contacted material by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) reveals a shoulder in the uranium 4f spectrum, indicative of partial reduction from U­(VI) to U­(IV), an oxidation state of uranium known to be much less soluble in water and part of the driving force for uranium binding. A saturation capacity of 206 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved at pH 5 by application of an adsorption isotherm.

The adsorbents were investigated for uranium uptake from an 8 ppm uranyl nitrate brine solution, also containing 193 ppm sodium bicarbonate and 25 600 ppm sodium chloride. The sample that was not heat-treated achieved an uptake of approximately 175 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while maximum uptake for samples receiving post-amidoximation heat-treatment in DMSO, DMF, and propylene carbonate achieved uptake of approximately 225, 220, and 185 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, respectively. Further investigations were performed using adsorbents heated in DMSO, which displayed more rapid uranyl-binding kinetics compared to the untreated material and improvement in recovery of uranium following 56-days of contact with seawater from Sequim Bay, WA in flow through columns. A seawater uranium recovery capacity of approximately 4.2 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved for the DMSO-treated sample, while 3.5 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent were obtained for the untreated analogue. However, increases in uptake were also observed in the binding of numerous other metals present in seawater, in particular Ca, Mg, Fe, V, Mn, and Cr. Taken comprehensively, it is clear the cyclic imidedioxime plays a critical role in the performance of amidoxime-functionalized polymer adsorbents, though achieving the necessary selectivity and chemical stability for repeated use remains an elusive and highly desirable objective.

Polymer Adsorbents Prepared by Neither RIGP Nor ATRPSuspension/Emulsion Polymerization

The first amidoxime-functionalized polymer-based adsorbents were prepared by thermally initiated suspension polymerization of (AN) and divinylbenzene (DVB) dissolved in toluene and dispersed in water (). As discussed above, subsequent treatment of the poly­(AN-co-DVB) with hydroxylamine generates the amidoxime (AO) functionality and the final poly­(AO-co-DVB) adsorbent. An identical polymerization approach was implemented by Hirotsu, who investigated the role of the hydrophilicity of the cross-linking comonomer on adsorbent performance. Substituting tetraethylene glycol dimethacrylate (4EGDM) for divinylbenzene resulted in an adsorbent with superior kinetics compared to poly­(AO-co-DVB). A 40-day test of the best performing poly­(AO-co-DVB) afforded an uptake of approximately 0.2 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while the poly­(AO-co-4EGDM) achieved 0.4 mg of uranium/g in only 28 days. Follow up work with poly­(AO) adsorbents cross-linked with different ratios of DVB/4EGDM revealed by X-ray microanalysis that uranium was more homogeneously distributed throughout the adsorbent as more 4EGDM was incorporated, whereas binding in the poly­(AO-co-DVB) was localized to the surface. While the DVB cross-linked adsorbent displayed the lowest capacity and slowest kinetics, the 100% 4EGDM adsorbent was only marginally better. The materials with the best kinetics were composed of different ratios of DVB/4EGDM, indicating hydrophilicity of the adsorbent is not the only consideration for effective uranium uptake. The poly­(AO-co-4EGDM) nevertheless displayed an impressive 4.5 mg of uranium/g uptake when deployed in a glass column and contacted with seawater for 180 days at 25 °C and 250 mL min–1.

A St/AN copolymer was prepared by emulsion polymerization with potassium persulfate radical initiator and a sodium lauryl sulfate emulsifier. Following polymerization, the nitriles were converted to amidoxime groups. Different St:AN ratios were used to prepare materials (40:60, 30:70, 20:80), which were subsequently screened for uranium uptake from a 45 ppm solution at pH 2.2, achieving capacities as high as 0.85 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Introduction of competing metals, increasing ionic strength, or pre-exposure of the adsorbent to solutions containing 1.4 ppm chlorine reduced the performance. Nevertheless, when 35.8 L of filtered environmental seawater was passed through 2 g of adsorbent, an uptake of 0.0145 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was realized, equating to 25% the total quantity of uranium dissolved in the seawater.

Anionic Polymerization

Kabay reported the application of anionic polymerization to adsorbent development in the mid-90s, where methacrylonitrile was polymerized with the anionic initiators BuLi or Et2Mg. The resulting polymers possessed high molecular weight, ranging from 105 to 106 g mol–1. Upon conversion of the nitrile group to AO, pretreatment with 1 M NaOH, and subsequent neutralization, the best performing material achieved an uptake of 0.176 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent/day deployment in 5 L of natural seawater.
