ATRP has also been applied to the synthesis of mesoporous polymer adsorbents, functionalized with poly(amidoxime). As first reported by Yue and co-workers, a copolymer monolith support was synthesized by conventional free radical polymerization of VBC and DVB in the presence of AIBN. A surface area of 572 m2 g-1 was achieved by optimizing the ratio of the two comonomers. Subsequent ATRP of AN was initiated from the chloride in the poly(VBC-co-DVB), which was subsequently converted to amidoxime by treatment with hydroxylamine.  displays a representative schematic of the synthesis process.

When screened for uranium adsorption in a 6.8 ppm uranyl brine solution at pH 8, the material achieved an uptake of 80 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, outperforming several commercially available adsorbent materials. Furthermore, when deployed in 5 gallons (18.92 L) of environmental seawater for 27 d, an uptake of 2.0 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved. 

The same group applied ATRP to the functionalization of a porous aromatic framework (PAF) with poly(AN), followed by conversion to PAF-graft-poly(AO) with hydroxylamine. Uranium uptake was assessed in laboratory screening tests using a 6 ppm uranium brine solution, where the adsorbent outperformed several commercially available adsorbents as well as a reference fiber obtained from the JAEA. Uptakes of 64.1 and 65.2 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent were obtained for the "as prepared" sample, as well as following a KOH-conditioning step. The statistically insignificant difference in uranium uptake indicates the alkaline preconditioning normally required for polymer adsorbents is not necessary for this particular material. While easy to overlook this important detail, the identity of the trunk is the primary difference that differentiates this polymer adsorbent from the many different adsorbent materials discussed above, and further research is warranted to elucidate the relationship between trunk material and need for KOH conditioning prior to achieving promising performance.

The adsorbent was also tested via batch-contact in filtered environmental seawater spiked to an 80 ppb uranium concentration. Following 42 d of contact, an adsorption capacity of 4.81 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved. Furthermore, kinetics analysis revealed approximately 80% of all uranium was adsorbed after 2 weeks of contact, suggesting a reduced deployment time would be plausible. Nevertheless, no appreciable uranium uptake was detected by the authors when the material was deployed in unspiked seawater, though the low concentration of uranium was near the limits of their analytical quantification. 

Chi and co-workers further developed the above work, varying the ratio of DVB:VBC and polymerizing AN by ATRP. As in the work by Yue and colleagues, the surface area and pore architectures of the poly(DVB:VBC) could be tuned as a function of the DVB:VBC ratio. Furthermore, the authors noted that poly(AN) length varied as the structure of the poly(DVB-co-VBC) support changed. While the highest Dg was obtained for the material formed on the 1:1 DVB:VBC support, the best performing adsorbent was prepared on 2:1 DVB:VBC, suggesting the structure of the support may supersede Dg in determining adsorbent performance. When contacted with a 100 ppm aqueous uranyl solution at pH 8.3, a uranium uptake of 75 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved. When the concentration was reduced to 10 ppb, an uptake of 2 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was reported.

The first instance of functionalized carbon for extraction of uranium was by Starvin et al. in 2004. An activated carbon compound was functionalized with diarylazobisphenol through treatment in an aqueous solution, similar to previously reported functionalization of single-wall carbon nanotubes through chemical modification with a diazonium compound. No information is provided regarding surface area coverage or even characterization of the carbon material. It was packed into a column and investigated for preconcentration of uranium in the pH range of 4-5, saturating at approximately 18 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. 

Unfunctionalized activated carbon was also investigated for batch adsorption. Varying contact time, pH, concentration of uranium, and temperature, a maximum uptake of 28 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained at pH 3 and 20 °C with 4 h contact time. Uranium sorption was observed to decrease significantly below pH 2 and above pH 6. It was suggested optimal saturation occurs at pH 3 because this is the acidity at which "free" uranium is maximized, meaning uranyl speciates to a penta-aqua complex and there is minimal formation of dimers or tetramers. Sorption data were not collected above pH 7, but this study reveals negligible sorption would be expected by unfunctionalized activated carbon under seawater conditions. 

Electrosorption using activated carbon slurries prepared with polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) has also been studied. This technique utilizes the conductivity of the carbon to extract ions through isolation within the electrical double layer formed when a bias potential is applied to the electrodes. Through optimizing the applied potential at +0.4 V (), uranyl can be selectively separated from seawater. A capacity after 300 min of applied potential was reported as 3.4 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, comparable to high surface area adsorbents recently developed at ORNL. The authors speculate that no cationic species is adsorbed; therefore, the triscarbonatouranyl(VI) anion must be the electrosorbed species. However, the calcium and magnesium response, two cations reported to have strong binding affinity to the triscarbonatouranyl(VI) anion, do not appear to increase with the uranium uptake. While this work is promising, more work is required due to the large decrease in surface area from the use of 50 wt % binder (PVDF) to stabilize the activated carbon electrode. Further work is required to understand the electrosorption process and further characterize the ion extraction as no high valent metals are discussed outside of uranium. The high oxidation state transition metals should be electrosorbed as well and will impact the reported economics of the process.

The authors first tested the amidoxime-functionalized carbon electrode and HW-ACE method in seawater spiked with uranium concentrations ranging from 150 ppb to 2000 ppm, revealing the formation of (UO2)O2⋅2H2O crystals on the surface of the electrode. In a head-to-head comparison against pure physicochemical adsorption, performance improvements through application of the HW-ACE approach were obvious. Near 100% recovery of uranium was achieved by HW-ACE across all concentrations, while physicochemical adsorption varied from approximately 10% to 80%, as displayed in . The difference in performance was also observed by EDX using a poly(amidoxime)-coated electrode patterned with parallel Pt lines on an insulating quartz substrate. After extraction of uranium, EDX mapping clearly revealed uranium binding to map directly on the conduction Pt pattern on the electrode (), confirming that the application of the bias and resulting uranium concentration resulted in the improved uranium uptake. When subsequently tested in filtered, unspiked, environmental seawater, the HW-ACE approach achieved a uranium uptake of 1.62 μg, compared to 0.55 μg for physicochemical adsorption.

Benzoylthiourea-functionalized activated carbons were prepared through in situ generation of diazonium cations. These materials were investigated for uranyl sorption from pH 1-5, with differing speciation of uranyl again providing the rationale for why sorption was not continued to environmental pH. A saturation capacity of 82 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained, which surpassed the unmodified activated carbon by three times. The binding motif for the benzoylthiourea-functionalized carbon was proposed to be chelation of one uranyl by two cooperating benzoylthiourea functionalities through the carboxylic oxygen and thiourea sulfur, while the imide and amine nitrogen were proposed to be Lewis bases donating electron pairs to other uranyl molecules. 

CMK-3, a nanoporous ordered carbon, was functionalized with a carboxymethylated polyethylenimine substrate. Upon functionalization, the surface area of the material decreased by approximately 50%, while degree of functionalization was estimated at 24% by total organic carbon analysis. Sorption isotherms displayed good sorption from pH 3-4, with saturation capacities of 119 and 222 mg g-1, respectively. It was proposed further deprotonation of the imine and carboxylic acids resulted in the improved sorption capacity at higher pH. CMK-3 was also functionalized by oxidation to generate a surface carboxylic acid. A maximum saturation capacity of 190 mg g-1 was observed at pH 5.5, decreasing to 160 mg g-1 at pH 7.5. Interestingly, the pristine CMK-3 also displayed a maximum sorption capacity of 120 mg g-1 at pH 6, decreasing to 90 mg g-1 at pH 7.5. 

A related activated carbon material, CMK-5, was functionalized with 4-acetophenone oxime by thermally induced diazonitization with isoamyl nitrite (). Batch sorption experiments were performed to investigate uranyl sorption from simulated effluent from nuclear processing. The simulant contained multiple competing di- and trivalent transition metals as well as several lanthanides. While poor sorption was observed below pH 3, a maximum sorption capacity around 65 mg g-1 was obtained at pH 4.5. This was rationalized by the extent to which the oxime could be deprotonated, forming a proposed uranyl complex of four equatorial monodentate-coordinating oxime ligands. 

A salicylaldeneimine-functionalized hydrothermal carbon was prepared by functionalizing an activated hydrothermal carbon with ethylenediamine. Condensation with salicylaldehyde resulted in the final material, which was investigated for extraction of uranyl over the pH range of <1-4.5. Uptake increased with increasing pH, with a maximum uptake of 261 mg g-1 obtained at pH 4.3, while kinetic studies revealed more than 80% of the total adsorption occurred in the first minute. Competitive adsorption of uranyl from simulated nuclear processing effluent revealed remarkable selectivity for uranyl, with a K d of approximately 9.5 × 104 mL g-1. 

In an effort to provide a more direct basis for comparison, Carboni et al. prepared a library of organic functional groups and grafted them to commercially available mesoporous carbon through formation of in situ diazonium cations (). Containing many functional groups investigated on MS materials by Vivero-Escoto, a similar result was obtained: a phosphylated mesoporous carbon material possessed the highest sorption capacity, at both pH 4 and 8.2. Saturation capacities of 85 and 50 mg g-1 were obtained under these conditions, respectively. Not surprisingly, sorption of uranyl was pH-dependent, with a dramatic increase observed above pH 3.5 attributed to the first deprotonation of the surface phosphoryl groups.

cln_elements.content:
Sonochemical grafting of AN into mesoporous carbon was also pursued for development of uranyl-extracting materials. The authors report an increase in degree of grafting through sonochemical approaches compared to efforts with free radical polymerization. They propose pore blockage occurs during free radical polymerization, but penetration of the monomer is encouraged through sonication. The authors reported that a high intensity ultrasonication, using an ultrasonic horn as the source, provided more conformal polymer coatings within the pores compared to the standard lab bath ultrasound. This was observed through the nitrogen sorption isotherms where a hysteresis of the lab bath ultrasound was extended instead of sharply closing, as in the case of the high intensity ultrasound, a phenomenon attributed to pore constrictions (). Homogeneous polymerization of poly­(AN) throughout the mesoporous material was coupled with nitric acid surface oxidation and CO2 pore activation to achieve enhanced sorbent performance. Modest sorption capacities of <1–4 mg g–1 were obtained, but these experiments were performed in a seawater simulant at pH 8.2 with carbonate sources, which typically reduces sorption dramatically.

Carbon nanotubes have also been investigated for uranium sorption. First reports involve acid treatment for enhancing colloidal stability, with sorption capacities of approximately 45 mg g–1 achieved at pH 5. Similar results were obtained by oxidation of multiwalled carbon nanotubes, affording a sorption capacity of 36 mg g–1. Finally, carboxymethyl cellulose was also attached to the surface of multiwalled carbon nanotubes by plasma induced grafting. After exposure to an N2 plasma, the nanotubes were combined with carboxymethyl cellulose and heated to 80 °C for 1 week with stirring. Sorption isotherms obtained at pH 5 yield a sorption capacity of approximately 110 mg g–1.

Very recently, a graphene oxide (GO)/amidoxime hydrogel adsorbent was developed for the removal of uranium from aqueous solution, including seawater simulant. Amino acids, polyamines, and metformin possess multiple nitrogen basic moieties which bind with carboxylic or alcohol groups on GO sheets, forming hydrogels. Iminodiacetonitirle (IDAN) was treated with hydroxylamine to form the amidoxime derivative, AO-IDAN, which was then used as a cross-linking agent in the GO dispersion. Uranium adsorption experiments reveal pH affects performance significantly, with maximum uptake achieved from pH 5–7. A slight decrease was observed at pH 8, followed by a precipitous drop at higher pH. When contacted with a 3.7 ppb uranium seawater simulant at a phase ratio of 0.5 mg L–1, the hydrogel adsorbed 88% of the uranium in solution, affording an uptake of 0.006 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent over 6 h. An isotherm performed at pH 6 yields a saturation capacity of 398 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent.

Applying this process yielded supports with degree of grafting ranging from 280–509 wt %, displaying a linear correlation with density of initiator sites. The authors do note extensive grafting may ultimately fill or block mesopores, a phenomenon discussed previously regarding functionalization of mesoporous carbon. Deployment of the mesoporous copolymer sorbents in simulated seawater at environmental pH resulted in adsorption capacities as high as 80 mg g–1, surpassing that of four commercially available adsorbent materials (12–50 mg g–1) and that of nonwoven amidoxime-functionalized polyethylene fabric (0.75 mg g–1). Batch experiments involving 5 gallons of seawater were performed using the ATRP-grafted mesoporous polymer. A uptake behavior of the mesoporous polymer sorbent, 0.33 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent/day, was observed with a moderate capacity of 1.99 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. This behavior is similar to that of an poly­(amidoxime-co-MA) sorbent produced by ORNL (0.30 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent/day).

All three MOFs were investigated for the extraction of uranium from several aqueous solutions. Measurements were made at pH 2.5 and 5 in DI water, with maximum saturation capacities of 217 and 109 mg of uranium/g of ads obtained at pH 2.5 for 1 and 2, respectively. When the pH was elevated to 5, saturation capacities decreased to 152 and 104 mg of uranium/g of ads accordingly. No uptake was observed for 3 under any conditions. MOFs 1 and 2 were also tested in a seawater simulant containing various sodium salts, carbonate, and both Mg and Ca cations. For both materials, a reduced uptake was observed, with 188 and 32 mg of uranium/g of ads obtained at pH 2.5 for 1 and 2. Isotherms are displayed in . Subsequent DFT calculations suggested the uranium was bound cooperatively by two adjacent ligands through monodentate coordination with the phosphoryl oxygen. This DFT-proposed 2:1 ligand to metal ratio (L:M) was supported by investigation of the uranyl uptake, as experimental L:M of 2:1 and 2.3:1 were obtained for MOF 1 in DI water and seawater simulant, respectively.

MOFs 4, 4-NH2, 4-ED, and 4-DETA were investigated for uranium sorption in DI water over the pH range of 3–6. Uptake was negligible for all materials at pH < 4, but rose dramatically up to pH 6, while kinetic studies performed at pH 5.5 revealed rapid saturation of all materials occurred in less than 1 h of contact time. Sorption isotherms, again at pH 5.5 in DI water, afforded saturation capacities of 20, 90, 200, and 350 mg of uranium/g of ads for 4, 4-NH2, 4-ED, and 4-DETA, respectively. These results are displayed in . The authors noted the trend in capacity was inversely correlated with coverage of the functional groups. Though correlation breaks down for 4, which was unfunctionalized, the implication is that sorption is related to the accessibility of the binding sites located in the center of the MOF, in conjunction with the enhanced Lewis basicity of an aliphatic amine (as on 4-ED and 4-DETA) as opposed to an aromatic amine (4-NH2). The flexibility of the binding moiety on the SBU-functionalized 4-ED and 4-DETA was also proposed to enhance uptake.

Selectivity studies on a series of metals at pH 5.5 were also performed, with high K d values achieved for uranium (>6000 mL g–1) in contrast to relatively low values for competing ions (<100 mL g–1) when all are present at an 0.5 mM initial concentration (). While these results are interesting, the selection of metals contains six lanthanides which are not present in seawater at appreciable concentrations and three transition metals, none of which are known to strongly compete for uranyl-binding sites in previously reported adsorbents. Most conspicuously absent are V, Fe, and Cu from the list of competing metals.

Similar work was reported shortly thereafter by Zhang et al., again using MIL-101­(Cr) and functionalizing at the metal SBU with ED. While much of this report duplicates previous work, the authors do perform sorption experiments up to pH 9, where a dramatic decrease in uptake is observed (). The pH of the sorption solution was adjusted with small amounts of HNO3 or Na2CO3, which suggests that at higher pH there would be an appreciable effect from formation of [UO2(CO3)3]4–. A capacity of approximately 200 mg of uranium/g of ads was obtained for 4-ED at pH 5, essentially identical to previously reported data. The capacity at pH 8 decreased to approximately 150 mg of uranium/g of ads, while at pH 9 the capacity was around 80 mg of uranium/g of ads. Interestingly, negative uptake was reported at pH 2.

Rapid absorption uptake was observed in a kinetics investigation, with complete uptake achieved in less than 1 min. However, this experimental setup does not provide meaningful information, as the experiment was performed at a concentration where the adsorbent was not saturated. Similar kinetics would be observed for most materials where absorption kinetics are performed below saturation concentrations. Moreover, the instantaneous completion of adsorption casts doubt on the analytical rigor. The only data point which was not 90 ± 5 mg of uranium/g of ads was the data point at t = 0. Moreover, adsorbents were collected by centrifugation for 10 min, which makes the measurements at t < 10 questionable. Subsequent adsorption isotherms reveal a saturation capacity of 126 mg of uranium/g of ads at pH 2 in DI water, despite only having a contact time of 5 min. These results do support rapid uranyl sorption.

The first use of an unfunctionalized MOF for uranium extraction was reported by Wang et al., utilizing the iconic Cu MOF HKUST-1 (6). The effect of pH was evaluated over the range of 2–10 in DI water, with capacities of 200 mg of uranium/g of ads achieved until pH 8 (). At pH 10, the adsorption decreased to approximately 140 mg of uranium/g of ads, attributed to formation of [UO2(CO3)2]2– and [UO2(CO3)3]4– from solvation of atmospheric CO2. Adsorption isotherms were performed at pH 6 at 25, 35, and 45 °C, which yielded saturation capacities of 787, 826, and 840 mg of uranium/g of ads when fitted with the Langmuir model. As the Langmuir model assumes monolayer coverage and isolated adsorption sites, the authors assert such an adsorption process must occur. The authors suggest the large number of carboxyl groups coordinating the Cu SBUs provide the uranyl adsorption sites. The SBU adopts a paddle-wheel structure, as is commonplace for Cu MOFs, where four carboxylates and two water molecules coordinate two Cu atoms. Consideration of the solvent-free formula for 6, Cu3(BTC)2, affords a molar ratio of 1.34–1.42 uranium per SBU at saturation.

Sorption kinetics were observed at a phase ratio of 0.4 g L–1 and a pH of 3 (). Saturation was observed at approximately 300 min when all of the uranium was extracted from solution. The authors rationalize from the changes in the rate of uptake that the rate of bulk diffusion, surface adsorption, and intraparticle diffusion all contribute to the observed uranium adsorption rate. The adsorption was also obtained for 7 at pH 3 with a phase ratio of 0.4 g L–1 and a contact time of 5 h. A saturation capacity of 298 mg of uranium/g of ads was obtained by fitting the data with the Langmuir model. Finally, extracting from a solution with competing ions assessed the selectivity of 7 for uranium. While still not containing the most environmentally relevant metals (V, Fe, and Cu), selectivity over other metals with appreciable seawater concentration was observed (e.g., Pb, Zn, Sr, and Ni).

Synthesis of the isostructural MOF 8 was achieved using Tb to form the SBUs. While uranium adsorption data were not provided, quenching of the suspension luminescence was observed upon introduction of uranyl cations. At a concentration of 0.002 M, luminescence intensity was reduced by 50% and almost eliminated completely at 0.1 M. The authors note this characteristic allows the MOF to be used as a sensor for detecting uranium in aqueous waste; however, limits of detection were not determined. Moreover, the lowest concentration solution for which luminescence quenching was reported is equivalent to 0.5 mg of uranium/mL of solution. As 8 was added at 3 mg mL–1 to perform the luminescence experiments, significant improvements in sensitivity are needed for this MOF-based sensor to be a viable technology.

cln_elements.content:
The most recent effort in this field was reported by Yuan et al., who used UiO-66 (9) and the amine-modified UiO-66-NH2 (10) to extract uranium from aqueous solutions. Sorption was first measured as a function of pH over the range of 2–6 (). Low uptake was observed below pH 4, with maxima of 110 and 115 mg of uranium/g of ads achieved at pH 5.5 for 9 and 10, respectively. The authors indicate at lower pH the “active sites” on the sorbents are protonated and positively charged, though what specifically constituted an active site was never defined. Moreover, differences in uptake between 9 and 10 were not statistically significant, leading the authors to conclude introduction of amino functionalities do not enhance uranium sorption significantly. Some form of interaction at the MOF SBU is apparent. These results are of particular interest regarding the interpretation of earlier work presented by Lin et al., as their adsorbents displayed high uptake at pH 2.5 and significantly diminished capacity at pH 5. It is possible the sorption observed at pH 5 is attributable not to binding with the orthogonal phorphorylurea moieties of 1 and 2, but at the SBU as evidenced by sorption by 9 and 10.

Ma and colleagues were the first, and perhaps only, group to explore the utility of COFs for uranium extraction from seawater. The COF SCU1 was constructed from trimesoyl chloride and p-phenylenediamine in a molar ratio of 2:3 (). After treatment with “segregated” microwave irradiation, an ultramicroporous carbonaceous COF (CCOF-SCU1) was formed with a high density of nitrile functionalization, as determined by FTIR. Nitrogen isotherm analysis indicates the CCOF-SCU1 material has a large Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (507 m2/g) and is predominantly microporous (d ≈ 0.4 nm) character. When tested as a uranium sorbent, CCOF-SCU1 was able to achieve 50 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent at pH 2.5 while in the presence of 11 other competing ions (La3+, Ce3+, Nd3+, Gd3+, Sm3+, Ba2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Sr2+, Ni2+, and Zn2+).

Dai and colleagues first reported a mesporous polymer created without using a porogen for the recovery of uranium from seawater. The polymer was formed from VBC and DVB comonomers, with the VBC chlorides functioning as initiators for the polymerization of AN by ATRP, as discussed in and displayed in . Following conversion of poly­(AN) to poly­(amidoxime), the adsorbent was screened in a spiked uranyl brine (6 ppm U), demonstrating a high uptake of 80 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. Testing in actual seawater demonstrated a uranium-adsorption capacity of 1.99 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, surpassing the capacity of the irradiation-grafted nonwoven polyethylene fabric (0.75 mg of uranium/g of ads) from Japan Atomic Energy Agency (JAEA).

An amidoxime functionalized POP (PPN-6-PAO) was based on the PPN-6 structure was later synthesized and functionalized with poly­(amidoxime) for recovery of uranium from seawater. While closely related to the aforementioned work, PPN-6 is composed of biphenyl struts generated by the coupling of tetrakis­(4-iodophenyl)­methane, rather than DVB (). The PPN-6 framework was postsynthetically functionalized through chloromethylation to introduce chlorine within the framework, affording efficient initiation sites for postsynthetic ATRP of AN. Following polymerization, treatment with hydroxylamine converts the nitriles of the grafted polymer (PPN-6-PAN) to amidoximes (PPN-6-PAO). After base conditioning with 3% KOH aqueous solution at room temperature, PPN-6-PAO was tested for uranium uptake in seawater spiked to 80 ppb with uranium. PPN-6-PAO demonstrated a uranium uptake of 96 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent after 42 d of contact ().

Ma and co-workers also very recently reported a functionalized porous organic polymer for the recovery of uranium from seawater, based on the PPN-6 structure. In contrast to previous work where poly­(amidoxime) is grown from halide initiators in the POP, amidoxime groups decorated the channels of the porous support directly, providing site accessibility and rapid transport of uranium to the binding sites (). An isotherm collected in aqueous uranium solutions revealed a saturation capacity of 304 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while kinetic experiments demonstrated >95% equilibration after a mere 3 h contact. The material could be eluted with Na2CO3, affording negligible decrease in performance over two recycles. A K d of approximately 1 × 106 mL g–1 suggested very high affinity for uranium, which was supported by investigations in seawater simulant. When deployed in a brine solution containing 25.6 g L–1 NaCl and 0.198 g L–1 NaHCO3 with 7 ppm uranium, a capacity of 40 mg of uranium g–1 was obtained. Subsequent EXAFS analysis supported binding of uranium by an average of 1.4 ± 0.3 amidoxime functionalities in an η2-motif, suggesting cooperativity between adjacent amidoxime species may contribute to the observed performance.

Fryxell and colleagues reported the first use of MS materials for extraction of actinides with self-assembled monolayers on mesoporous supports (SAMMS). The materials possessed a surface area of approximately 1000 m2 g–1 had high binding site density and a rigid open pore structure to facilitate diffusion through the MS channels. SAMMS were functionalized with glycinyl-urea, salicylamide, and acetamide-phosphonate and then investigated for sorption of actinides at acidic pH. Impressive sorption was observed using the glycinyl-urea-functionalized SAMMS, with maximum K d of 2.4 × 105, 1.6 × 105, and 9.1 × 104 mL g–1 for Am­(III), U­(VI), and Th­(IV), respectively. As importantly, equilibrium was reached in 1–2 h, indicating rapid dissociation through the material and fast binding.

Though in principle the same type of heterogeneous support was used in all of the aforementioned studies, the differences in surface areas and pore structure between different MS materials is significant. Moreover, as different pH ranges, contact times, phase ratios, degrees of grafting, and uranyl concentrations were used, direct comparisons are challenging if not impossible. In an effort to mitigate this difficulty, Vivero-Escoto et al. synthesized a library of organo-functionalized MS materials on the commercially available silica MSU-H (). Following identical grafting and pretreatment conditions, they performed the first direct comparison of more than nine different functionalities including amidoxime, bis-amidoxime, cyclic imide dioxime, carboxylic acid, phosphate diester, phosphonate, phosphoric acid, and bis-phosphoric acid. When sorption was performed in deionized water, the unfunctionalized MSU-H outperformed all but one sorbent, indicating that nonspecific binding to the MS support is significant. This result raises concern about other MS investigations for uranium extraction, as no indication of sorption by an unfunctionalized support had previously been published, suggesting background sorption by silanol functionalities had not been considered. When sorption was performed in seawater simulant, background sorption dramatically decreased, and a phosphoric acid attached to the MS support through a urea bridge was observed to have the highest saturation capacity of around 60 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. The cyclic imide dioxime- functionalized material extracted approximately 47 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while the amidoxime-functionalized material extracted approximately 25 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent.

An interesting hybrid material was reported, formed from amidoxime-functionalized magnetic mesoporous silica (MMS-AO), synthesized through co-condensation of tetraethyl orthosilicate and 2-cyanoethyltriethoxysilane on the surface of silica-coated Fe3O4. Following transformation of the nitrile to amidoxime, a saturation capacity of 277 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was obtained for the material at pH 5, facilitated by rapid magnetic separation. Performance was observed to be strongly pH dependent, though a respectable uptake of 83 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was achieved at pH 8 following 24 h contact.

Very recently, a series of organo-functionalized silicas were surface grafted with various (di)-phosphonic acids, imino diacetic acid, and HOPO and then investigated for the recovery of uranium from environmental seawater (). Adsorption isotherms reveal saturation capacities of the phosphate functionalized silica adsorbents outperform all commercial adsorbents and activated carbon, with PropPhos- and HOPO-functionalized silica achieving capacities of approximately 60 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent, while Diphos-functionalized silica saturated at 128 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent. K d values determined for Diphos-, PropPhos-, and HOPO-grafted materials were in excess of 3.5 × 106 mL g–1, while AcPhos- and IDAA- functionalized silica afforded values of 3.3 × 106 and 1.7 × 106 mL g–1, respectively.

Diphos-, HOPO-, and PropPhos-functionalized silica were processed into a thin film membrane, composed of 50 wt % adsorbent and 50 wt % Nafion polymeric binder. A DiPhos-functionalized silica membrane adsorbent reached equilibrium in 24 h of contact with seawater spiked to 34 ppb in uranium and at pH 7.5; 1.1 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent were recovered. Similar results were claimed for HOPO and PropPhos materials as well. When contacted with 200 mL of unspiked seawater, 0.104 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent was extracted over 2 h contact time. Based on their reported Na2CO3 elution data, which show complete elution of uranium, and recycling experiments, which show no statistically significant decrease in uranium uptake over four runs for both Diphos- and PropPhos-functionalized materials following an acid regeneration step, dramatic advantages over traditional polymeric adsorbents are asserted. The authors propose a continuous-deployment system where the membrane-supported silica adsorbents are immersed in seawater, eluted with Na2CO3, pre-conditioned with acid, and then reimmersed in seawater. A graphical depiction of this system is provided in . Extrapolating their 2 h adsorption data to a continuous process, the authors calculate as much as 75 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent could be achieved over a 60 d deployment, compared to 4 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent for traditional polymer materials.

From these promising initial results, a super uranyl-binding protein (SUP) was designed by genetic modification of Methanobacterium thermoautotrophicum. While the wild-type protein had a modest distribution coefficient, strategic mutations resulted in nearly a 6 order of magnitude increase in affinity and a distribution coefficient of 7.4 × 10–15 M (est. 6.7 × 10–11 mL g–1) at pH 8.9. The super uranyl-binding protein could be fixed sulfhydryl resin and displayed impressive selectivity for uranyl over other competing ions present in seawater, even when added at more than 106× excess. Cu2+ and VO2+ were the only ions for which the protein had comparable affinity, but the authors note even in light of their greater concentration in seawater they would not be capable of competing with uranyl binding. Indeed, 17%, 30%, and 90% of uranyl was extracted from simulated seawater when contacted for 30 min with 1, 10, and >6000 equiv of protein. This remarkable affinity and rapid sorption reveals genetically engineered proteins could offer a viable means for extracting uranium from seawater. However, there are significant challenges to the viable deployment of engineered proteins such as cost, deployment motif, and selectivity toward uranium, specifically related to vanadium and copper.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The most recent effort in this field was reported by Yuan et al., who used UiO-66 (9) and the amine-modified UiO-66-NH2 (10) to extract uranium from aqueous solutions. Sorption was first measured as a function of pH over the range of 2-6 (). Low uptake was observed below pH 4, with maxima of 110 and 115 mg of uranium/g of ads achieved at pH 5.5 for 9 and 10, respectively. The authors indicate at lower pH the "active sites" on the sorbents are protonated and positively charged, though what specifically constituted an active site was never defined. Moreover, differences in uptake between 9 and 10 were not statistically significant, leading the authors to conclude introduction of amino functionalities do not enhance uranium sorption significantly. Some form of interaction at the MOF SBU is apparent. These results are of particular interest regarding the interpretation of earlier work presented by Lin et al., as their adsorbents displayed high uptake at pH 2.5 and significantly diminished capacity at pH 5. It is possible the sorption observed at pH 5 is attributable not to binding with the orthogonal phorphorylurea moieties of 1 and 2, but at the SBU as evidenced by sorption by 9 and 10.

cln_elements.content: In an effort to address some of these potential challenges, very recent work articulates the integration of the SUP into a hydrogel through thiol-maleimide click chemistry (). The hydrophilicity of the SUP was improved through genetically fusing termini with elastin-like peptides, and the resulting hydrogel was subsequently formed with 4-arm PEG-maleimide cross-linkers. Using a microfluidic device, droplets of SUP hydrogels were processed and cured into microbeads 165 μm in radius. Proteins were demonstrated to remain active for uranium binding, and the uranium uptake in DI water was quite close to the theoretically determined value. However, in solutions at higher uranium concentrations, a 1.5:1 ratio of uranium:protein was obtained suggesting the presence of a secondary binding site. Using these SUP-hydrogel beads, uranium can be enriched up to 0.0092 mg of uranium/g of adsorbent upon contacted with environmental seawater spiked to 13.7 nM with uranyl.

<table-wrap-foot>
<fn id="t3fn1">
<label>a</label>
<p>Unless otherwise stated, adsorption
experiments were performed in DI water and pH was unadjusted.</p>
</fn>
<fn id="t3fn2">
<label>b</label>
<p>Contacted in ASTM D1141 artificial
seawater; composition: NaCl (24.53 g L<sup>–1</sup>), MgCl<sub>2</sub> (5.20 g L<sup>–1</sup>), Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> (4.09 g L<sup>–1</sup>), CaCl<sub>2</sub> (1.16 g L<sup>–1</sup>), KCl (0.695 g L<sup>–1</sup>), and NaHCO<sub>3</sub> (0.201
g L<sup>–1</sup>).</p>
</fn>
<fn id="t3fn3">
<label>c</label>
<p>Maximum capacity at saturation.</p>
</fn>
<fn id="t3fn4">
<label>d</label>
<p>Competing cation composition: 2.7
× 10<sup>–4</sup> M of Fe<sup>3+</sup>, Na<sup>+</sup>, Mg<sup>2+</sup>, Co<sup>2+</sup>, Ni<sup>2+</sup>, Zn<sup>2+</sup>, or Pb<sup>2+</sup>.</p>
</fn>
</table-wrap-foot>
</table-wrap>

<fn id="t4fn1">
<label>a</label>
<p>Unless otherwise stated, adsorption
experiments were performed in DI water and pH was unadjusted.</p>
</fn>
<fn id="t4fn2">
<label>b</label>
<p>Average of six replicates; error
is the standard deviation.</p>
</fn>
<fn id="t4fn3">
<label>c</label>
<p>Maximum capacity at saturation.</p>
</fn>
<fn id="t4fn4">
<label>d</label>
<p>Seawater simulant contains 175 g
of sea salt and 0.2 g of Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> dissolved in
5 L of deionized water with uranium and transition metals added to
100× environmental concentration.</p>
</fn>
<fn id="t4fn5">
<label>e</label>
<p>Average of two replicates; error
is the standard deviation.</p>
</fn>
<fn id="t4fn6">
<label>f</label>
<p>Salinity normalized to 35 psu.</p>
</fn>
<fn id="t4fn7">
<label>g</label>
<p>Data insufficient to calculate precise
uranium uptake.</p>
</fn>
</table-wrap-foot>

cln_elements.content: Development of representative adsorbent technologies throughout history for the extraction of uranium from seawater. Only adsorbents contacted with environmental seawater are displayed. References for displayed materials are provided in brackets. Triangular markers denote open ocean deployments.

cln_elements.content: Primary steps in the computational screening and subsequent design of super-uranyl-binding proteins. The desired coordination features are identified (step 1), the protein database is surveyed and a protein selected for further study (step 2), possible mutations for the protein are considered (step 3), potential uranyl binding sites are searched (step 4), and uranyl coordination geometries for the selective potential binding sites are evaluated and scored (step 5). If no hits are identified, the computational algorithm returns to step 2. Figure reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2014, Nature Publishing Group.
